From jeme at brelin.net  Sun Sep  1 02:51:30 2002
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Sun, 1 Sep 2002 02:51:30 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] cdrecord howto
In-Reply-To: <E17lPOV-000138-00@sire.mail.pas.earthlink.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0209010248380.6475-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Sun, 1 Sep 2002, Rick Konold wrote:
> I did cp -r /mnt/cdrom redhat7.3-1.iso from the first disk, and that
> copied it to a directory called redhat7.3-1.iso, but note I have NOT
> run mkisofs on that directory.  Should I? or is it already an iso as
> copied?

Don't mount the CD.  Just dump the image off the disk
$ dd if=/dev/cdrom of=/path/to/disk_image bs=2048

Then you can burn the image with cdrecord:
$ cdrecord -v speed=8 dev=0,0,0 -data /path/to/disk_image

Of course, the speed and the device ID may vary.

> Also, since it is a bootable cdrom, do I need to add that option to
> cdrecord, or can I skip that, since the file system already has an
> autorun file on it?

Autorun files are for Windows.  The boot block should be part of the disk
image, no?

J.

From fedorp at wv.mentorg.com  Sun Sep  1 10:02:09 2002
From: fedorp at wv.mentorg.com (Fedor G. Pikus)
Date: Sun, 1 Sep 2002 10:02:09 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] cdrecord howto
In-Reply-To: <E17lSVV-0000p2-00@atlantic.mail.pas.earthlink.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.31.0209010950140.18327-100000@lorien.wv.mentorg.com>

First of all, if you just want to copy CDs, you can get xcdroast from
http://www.xcdroast.org/, click "Copy CD" and let it do the work for you.

On Sun, 1 Sep 2002, Rick Konold wrote:
> > Don't mount the CD.  Just dump the image off the disk
> > $ dd if=/dev/cdrom of=/path/to/disk_image bs=2048
>
> I didn't think I was mounting the cd with cp -r, I thought it just copied the
No, but you need to mount the CD before cp will work. Otherwise you were
not copying the CD. BTW, you should have used cp -a, not cp -r, if you wanted
to create full copy of the CD file by file (it's not used for copying CDs,
it's for creating the directory structure and all files from CD on hard disk).

> cd already be correct (2048)? [just wondering if it is necessary to tell dd
> what bs, or if it would just copy as is without that specification]
Not really necessary, it'll work without bs too.

> > Then you can burn the image with cdrecord:
> > $ cdrecord -v speed=8 dev=0,0,0 -data /path/to/disk_image
>
> Hmmm more of that conflicting advise stuff.  I was told I did not need to use
> the -data, and the man page seemed to confirm that when I read that it was
You can leave off -data.

> Yep, dev=1,0,0  , and the speed is another question.  I see posts
I always burn at 12x and never made a bad CD. At such speeds you need to
either fully dedicate your machine to burning (don't do anything else
while cdrecord runs, don't touch it at all, and make sure you don't have
any powersave modes kicking in), or you need a CD-writer with burnproof,
then just add -burnproof to cdrecord options, Then you can suspend cdrecord
with Ctrl-Z and it'll continue just fine when you resume.

> > Autorun files are for Windows.  The boot block should be part of the disk
> > image, no?
>
> boot.cat (unknown file type, per nautilus) is there, perhaps that is it.

Neither of these has anything to do with being bootable. Autorun is not
about booting from it, it's what runs when you stick the CD into already
running windows. There are cd-watching daemons for Linux (Gnome and KDE run
them by default), they could execute something on CD if there was a
convention how to name it, but there isn't so they don't. What you need
to boot is a boot sector with bootloader in it, and then the kernel in the
location expected by the loader. Since you will just copy CDs sector by sector
with dd, you don't have to worry about this.

> eth0	Link encap:Ethernet HWaddrr 00:A0:C9:FB:C5:8E
> 	BROADCAST MULTICAST MTU:1500 Metric:1
> 	RX packets:0 errors:0 dropped:0 overrun:0 frame:0
> 	TX packets:7 errors:0 dropped:0 overrun:0 carrier:0
> 	collisions:0 txqueuelan:100

Ok, let's try this:

# /sbin/ifconfig eth0 192.168.1.106 broadcast 192.168.1.255 \
	netmask 255.255.255.0

Then, instead of attempting to ping your router, try pinging another
system on the network.

Then try this:

# /sbin/route add default gw 192.168.1.1 metric 1

And try pinging things again.

Do you know for sure your network card works and the network cable is
good?  That is, did it work in Windows or something?

From jeme at brelin.net  Sun Sep  1 12:58:35 2002
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Sun, 1 Sep 2002 12:58:35 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] cdrecord howto
In-Reply-To: <E17lSVV-0000p2-00@atlantic.mail.pas.earthlink.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0209011247020.14578-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Sun, 1 Sep 2002, Rick Konold wrote:
> On Sunday 01 September 2002 02:51, you hammered the keyboard to write:
> > On Sun, 1 Sep 2002, Rick Konold wrote:
> > > I did cp -r /mnt/cdrom redhat7.3-1.iso from the first disk, and that
> > > copied it to a directory called redhat7.3-1.iso, but note I have NOT
> > > run mkisofs on that directory.  Should I? or is it already an iso as
> > > copied?
> >
> > Don't mount the CD.  Just dump the image off the disk
> > $ dd if=/dev/cdrom of=/path/to/disk_image bs=2048
> 
> I didn't think I was mounting the cd with cp -r, I thought it just
> copied the files in the same manner you indicate with dd.

You weren't mounting the CD with the cp command, the CD was mounted
beforehand.  I knew because the location on the filesystem
(/mnt/cdrom) that you were using as the cp source is where some systems
mount cdroms.  It is NOT the raw device from which you could dump data
blocks whole.

> Is there a difference in what I would get from cp as compared to dd?  

As Fedor wrote, cp will copy the files off the disk, but dd will copy the
sectors in raw mode.  The disk image produced by dd will be identical to
the disk image burned to the CD in the first place.  You don't have to
then construct your own image and include a boot block and all that; it's
already done.

> wouldn't the block size copied from a distro cd already be correct
> (2048)?

It'll work fine without specifying block size as there is a default value
for this.  However, I tend to specify things rather than relying on
defaults.  Defaults can change over time and different systems might use
different wrapper scripts or aliases that modify default command-line
options.  By specifying the parameters yourself, you minimize the risk of
sending commands to the system that you did not intend.

> > Then you can burn the image with cdrecord:
> > $ cdrecord -v speed=8 dev=0,0,0 -data /path/to/disk_image
> 
> Hmmm more of that conflicting advise stuff.  I was told I did not need
> to use the -data, and the man page seemed to confirm that when I read
> that it was the default if no other flag.  But you and the howto's
> always seem to include the -data.  I guess I should also, just to be
> sure.

Again, you're relying on defaults that might not be the same on every
system or in every revision of a given piece of software.  You should
really get in the habit of specifying things.  That's just personal
advice, of course.

> > Of course, the speed and the device ID may vary.
> Yep, dev=1,0,0 , and the speed is another question.  I see posts
> recommending using a lower speed than the burner's max.  Is that just
> for audio or would it be recommended for data as well.  I was making
> about 20% coasters at Free Geek the other day, doing iso's at the max
> 4x, burning knoppix.

20% is kind of insane.  Were you doing other disk intensive things on your
system? (that could include using swap space)

On my system, I burn at my drive's maximum speed, but I have to watch the
buffer capacity and make sure it doesn't ever underrun.  I can still use
my system (dual processor, dual disk, dual IDE controller, no swap) for
almost anything, but if I try, say, indexing a large AVI file that resides
on the same disk as the disk image being burned, I can underrun the buffer
and halt the CD burn prematurely.

> boot.cat (unknown file type, per nautilus) is there, perhaps that is
> it.

There is no file on the filesystem that represents bootability.  The boot
block is part of the disk image headers.  This boot block is included when
the ISO image is made.  When you are simply dumping an existing disk image
with dd, you get that boot block.  If you copy the files and then create
an ISO by hand, you must manually include the boot block.

Does that make sense?

> The Free Geek Store wants to make disks available, so I need to spend
> some time burning copies here in my spare time.  The burner they have
> is slow (about 25min per disk), and I can't hang around to baby sit
> it.  Anyone want to donate something faster than the 4x they have down
> there? [donations are tax deductible]

Gosh, surely we could fill a SCSI enclosure with CD-R drives and do some
mass replicating, no?

I don't have any spare drives (or money) right now, but I could probably
cough up an enclosure, if pressed.

J.

The fact that you got the eth0 information is good. It means the board is up
and ready to receive an IP. The next issue is to make sure you DHCP client is
looking for a lease. 

I don't have a Redhat system or I would post the output of ps ax. dhcpcd,
dhclient, pump or something else, might be your client. Maybe some RedHat user
could post what the default DHCP client is and the output of ps ax. You will
need to make sure you have it on your system and that it is started.

Russell

From jeme at brelin.net  Sun Sep  1 15:29:17 2002
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Sun, 1 Sep 2002 15:29:17 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] New Linux Install
In-Reply-To: <1030911638.10709.4.camel@linux>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0209011523100.15286-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>

On 1 Sep 2002, Robbert van Andel wrote:
> I'm thinking it's a compatibility issue with my NIC and will look into
> getting another one.  Thanks for all the help.

On what are you basing that conclusion?

You're able to configure the device, which means that the module is
loading properly.  That's usually a pretty good sign that it's not a
compatibility problem (not 100%, but it's a good start).

You haven't mentioned anything about the link lights, the far end
equipment, or the cable.  All of those things could be a factor.

Sure, "it worked in Windows", but when was the last time?  And what has
changed since?  Did you move the machine?

You haven't really given a complete report on the configuration including
what tools and command lines you're using to change the settings.

I think it's rash to claim some kind of compatibility problem.

This isn't Windows.  The software is flexible enough to allow for all
kinds of configurations that won't work in your environment.  Blaming
hardware or "compatibility issues" is almost always a cop out, usually one
foisted on us by the software vendors who have a vested interest in making
you believe that the software is totally usable and bug-free and that your
hardware is the problem.

I truly believe that if you walk through this problem systematically,
you'll get the system working with no changes to the hardware inside the
box.

J.

From jeme at brelin.net  Sun Sep  1 15:52:23 2002

Date: Sun, 1 Sep 2002 15:52:23 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] New Linux Install
In-Reply-To: <1030916826.10760.7.camel@linux>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0209011545340.16332-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>

On 1 Sep 2002, Robbert van Andel wrote:
> The last time it worked was the about 5 minutes before I began
> installing RedHat.  So physical connections are not an issue.

They're still an issue, but it's less likely they were changed much and a
simple look-see should take care of that part (and a quick check of your
memory to see if any furniture was moved or anything).

> (Yes, the link lights are on).

Which link lights?  And what about activity lights?  Do your activity
lights blink when you try to send packets to the gateway?

What equipment is on the far end of the cable coming from your on-board
network interface?  Does that have a link light?  Activity light?  How is
that device configured?  Is it a pass-through bridge or does it route or
filter?

Can you show us what the kernel thinks about your network configuration in
each of the two modes (static and dynamic)?  ifconfig and route (and
saying "looks the same except..." isn't really good enough.  To the
thousand eyes, all bugs are transparent)?

By the way, sendmail will not prevent a machine from booting.  It might
hang for a long time trying to resolve itself, but eventually the system
will come up.

J.

From creswick at cs.orst.edu  Sun Sep  1 15:57:42 2002
From: creswick at cs.orst.edu (Rogan Creswick)
Date: Sun, 1 Sep 2002 15:57:42 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Debian Power Down doesn't
In-Reply-To: <3D723AF0.4BA85827@attbi.com>
References: <3D7148E1.FDBA004E@attbi.com> <20020831232348.GA20829@silver.CS.ORST.EDU> <3D7157B6.A2367FCA@attbi.com> <20020901020804.2FFF22F5F0@einstein.seansdomain.org> <3D723AF0.4BA85827@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <20020901225742.GB21041@silver.CS.ORST.EDU>

> I downloaded kernel-source-2.4.18.tar.bz2, figured out what bz2 was, and
> tried to unzip it in /usr. Looks like my partitioning scheme needs
> adjusting. I ran out of room in about 10 seconds. I can unzip it in
> another partition (/home has lots of room), but I assume that for things
> to be predictable, I should make more room in /usr, unzip it there. 

Many programs look for kernel headers in /usr/src/linux, so when you compile
things it is always a good idea to have the source tree for your
_current_ kernel in /usr/src/linux.

What I do is this (once the kernel is downladed)

1) su to root,
2) cd /usr/src
3) if there exists a linux directory, move it.
4) tar Ixvf /path_to_downloaded_kernel/linux-...tar.bz2
5) move the extracted kernel to linux-<version> ie:
   mv linux linux-2.4.18
6) make a symlink to the new directory from linux, that is:
	ln -s linux-2.4.18 linux
	you can now act as if the kernel saurce is in "linux" rather than
	"linux-2.4.18". This is invaluable when you upgrade kernels, as a ls -l
	will tell you which version is being used.

7) cd into the linux directory, and run "make menuconfig" or "make xconfig",
   they are two interfaces to the same thing, try them both and use what you
	like.


You can place the source anywhere you want, just make the symlink in step 6
in /usr/src/ and you should not have any problems due to that.



> 
> Now, what was that utility for editing partitions Rich needed last
> weekend -- parted?
> 
> > Also copy /boot/config to your /usr/src/linux folder, that way you are
> > starting from a known good configuration.

If you copy /boot/config to /usr/src/linux/.config after step 6 above, it
will be loaded automatically.


HTH, 
Rogan

> 
> In my /usr/src directory, I have only an rpm directory. Do I need to
> create the linux directory myself, or is something I haven't done from
> the unzipping and untaring process going to do that for me?

On Sun, 1 Sep 2002, Rogan Creswick wrote:
> Many programs look for kernel headers in /usr/src/linux, so when you compile
> things it is always a good idea to have the source tree for your
> _current_ kernel in /usr/src/linux.
> 
> What I do is this (once the kernel is downladed)
> 
> 1) su to root,
> 2) cd /usr/src
> 3) if there exists a linux directory, move it.
> 4) tar Ixvf /path_to_downloaded_kernel/linux-...tar.bz2
> 5) move the extracted kernel to linux-<version> ie:
>    mv linux linux-2.4.18
> 6) make a symlink to the new directory from linux, that is:
> 	ln -s linux-2.4.18 linux
> 	you can now act as if the kernel saurce is in "linux" rather than
> 	"linux-2.4.18". This is invaluable when you upgrade kernels, as a ls -l
> 	will tell you which version is being used.

> 7) cd into the linux directory, and run "make menuconfig" or "make xconfig",
>    they are two interfaces to the same thing, try them both and use what you
> 	like.

> You can place the source anywhere you want, just make the symlink in
> step 6 in /usr/src/ and you should not have any problems due to that.

Do you actually know of something that looks in /usr/src/linux and not
/usr/include/linux where the headers belong?

You should always always always make sure that the versions of the kernel
headers you are using are the same ones that were used to build your
version of libc... even if that is not the same as the kernel version
you're running.

So, build your kernel, build glibc against it, then COPY the kernel
headers from /usr/src/linux/include/linux to /usr/include/linux and from
/usr/src/linux/include/asm/ to /usr/include/asm/

Thanks.
J.

From jeme at brelin.net  Sun Sep  1 21:12:39 2002
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Sun, 1 Sep 2002 21:12:39 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] USB
In-Reply-To: <200209011857.25104.hapibeli@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0209012110400.18456-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Sun, 1 Sep 2002, Dirk Ouellette wrote:
> I thought I had the usb modules in the kernel but lsmod gives me this;
> ]# lsmod    
[snip]
> and I see no usb modules there. How do I set the kernel up with them
> so my usb camera can be seen?

lsmod only shows modules currently loaded in the kernel.  The kernel does
its best to load and unload dynamic modules as needed.

Check /lib/modules/<kernel-rev>/modules.dep or your kernels .config to see
what you've actually got.

You can try to manually insmod the appropriate modules and see what
happens as well.

J.

Vincent,

I am only one dimensional in that I run exclusively Redhat distributions.
In Redhat there is a command chkconfig:
chkconfig --list
will give you all the startup states.
chkconfig --level 345 pump on  
turns pump on for boot levels 3, 4 , and 5.  See /etc/inittab for explanation 
of boot levels.

Another dhcp client is dhcpcd.  There is another explanation at:
www.scroung.org/dhcpcd.html.

HTH, Good Luck
-- 
Ken Stephens
www.cad2cam.com
www.cadtocam.com

From bspears at easystreet.com  Sun Sep  1 22:07:20 2002
From: bspears at easystreet.com (Bill Spears)
Date: Sun, 1 Sep 2002 22:07:20 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] cdrecord howto
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0209011247020.14578-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0209011247020.14578-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>
Message-ID: <200209021701.g82H1SX06129@smtp.easystreet.com>

On Sunday 01 September 2002 12:58 pm, you wrote:
> On Sun, 1 Sep 2002, Rick Konold wrote:
> > On Sunday 01 September 2002 02:51, you hammered the keyboard to write:
> > > On Sun, 1 Sep 2002, Rick Konold wrote:
> > > > I did cp -r /mnt/cdrom redhat7.3-1.iso from the first disk, and that
> > > > copied it to a directory called redhat7.3-1.iso, but note I have NOT
> > > > run mkisofs on that directory.  Should I? or is it already an iso as
> > > > copied?
> > >
> > > Don't mount the CD.  Just dump the image off the disk
> > > $ dd if=/dev/cdrom of=/path/to/disk_image bs=2048
> >
> > I didn't think I was mounting the cd with cp -r, I thought it just
> > copied the files in the same manner you indicate with dd.
>
> You weren't mounting the CD with the cp command, the CD was mounted
> beforehand.  I knew because the location on the filesystem
> (/mnt/cdrom) that you were using as the cp source is where some systems
> mount cdroms.  It is NOT the raw device from which you could dump data
> blocks whole.
>
> > Is there a difference in what I would get from cp as compared to dd?
>
> As Fedor wrote, cp will copy the files off the disk, but dd will copy the
> sectors in raw mode.  The disk image produced by dd will be identical to
> the disk image burned to the CD in the first place.  You don't have to
> then construct your own image and include a boot block and all that; it's
> already done.
>
> > wouldn't the block size copied from a distro cd already be correct
> > (2048)?
>
> It'll work fine without specifying block size as there is a default value
> for this.  However, I tend to specify things rather than relying on
> defaults.  Defaults can change over time and different systems might use
> different wrapper scripts or aliases that modify default command-line
> options.  By specifying the parameters yourself, you minimize the risk of
> sending commands to the system that you did not intend.
>
> > > Then you can burn the image with cdrecord:
> > > $ cdrecord -v speed=8 dev=0,0,0 -data /path/to/disk_image
> >
> > Hmmm more of that conflicting advise stuff.  I was told I did not need
> > to use the -data, and the man page seemed to confirm that when I read
> > that it was the default if no other flag.  But you and the howto's
> > always seem to include the -data.  I guess I should also, just to be
> > sure.
>
> Again, you're relying on defaults that might not be the same on every
> system or in every revision of a given piece of software.  You should
> really get in the habit of specifying things.  That's just personal
> advice, of course.
>
> > > Of course, the speed and the device ID may vary.
> >

FWIW, I had trouble with a making iso images, until one day I was sitting 
around cursing the guy that had stable instead of woody for a 'woody' network 
install and I noticed that my spindle of cdr's says 12x on the lable. I 
switched to that speed and have never had trouble again.

> figured out how to set it up, except that I need to
> run pump to get the thing started. I've been running
> it manually until now, but I need it to run when I
> boot my computer. Which script would I edit, and where

I just logged in to drizzle to see if I could figure out the init
sequence, and, I think, it is a little different than most.

I can't find an rc.local, which is what at least a few distros use that
would be perfect in a situation like this... but oh well, we can work
around it.

If nobody comes up with a tool you can easily use for this, I would make
a script in /etc/init.d running the command you need to run.  Then
symlink it to your runlevel scripts, which are /etc/rcY.d where Y is
your runlevel.

I like BSD-style init script, myself!  :-)

I may not understand what you are asking, but I will try.  Under debian,
you define your network interfaces in "/etc/network/interfaces".  To get
debian to use dhcp to get the address you use a line like

"iface eth0 inet dhcp"

check "man interfaces"

From aschlemm at attbi.com  Mon Sep  2 10:36:26 2002
From: aschlemm at attbi.com (Anthony Schlemmer)
Date: Mon, 2 Sep 2002 10:36:26 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Debian question, running pump on boot
In-Reply-To: <1030986099.20945.9.camel@duron>
References: <20020902131425.9445.qmail@web13807.mail.yahoo.com> <1030986099.20945.9.camel@duron>
Message-ID: <200209021036.26437.aschlemm@attbi.com>

I setup my own Sys V init script that runs "dhcpcd" for me for my cable 
modem service. If "dhcpcd" is successful and gets an IP address from 
AT&T it then runs my firewall script so my system is protected. Since 
my DHCP client system is used as a network gateway/firewall I also have 
the script enabling IP forwarding and spoof protection.

I don't care for the BSD-style as it's a bit simplistic with all of the 
local customizations in a single file. The Sys V init setup is more 
flexible as it's just a matter of setting a few symbolic links to the 
init script in the proper runlevel directory.

I haven't seen a BSD-style init setup in Linux since I used Slackware. I 
do have one OpenBSD system that I'm working on but so far my local init 
setup is quite simple.

Tony

From aschlemm at attbi.com  Mon Sep  2 10:45:04 2002
From: aschlemm at attbi.com (Anthony Schlemmer)
Date: Mon, 2 Sep 2002 10:45:04 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Re:USB
In-Reply-To: <200209021019.11086.hapibeli@attbi.com>
References: <200209021019.11086.hapibeli@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <200209021045.04671.aschlemm@attbi.com>

Do you have the camera dock? I don't use RedHat but I've found at least 
on my system that my camera is automatically detected when I press the 
button on the camera dock. I'm using SuSE 8.0 and it has a "hotplug" 
service that automatically detects my camera when I enable it. If 
you're not using the dock, then make sure your camera is turned on when 
you plug it in. The other problem I've seen is that by default only 
root can access the camera through the hotplug service. To work around 
that a usermap needs to be setup for the camera that allows a non-root 
user to access the camera.

You might try posting to the "gphoto" general mailing list. I've gotten 
some good information there that helped me get my "hotplug" service 
setup so I didn't have to be root to access my camera. Information 
regarding the various "gphoto2" mailing lists can be found here:

http://www.gphoto.net/lists.html

Here's the user manual for gphoto2 that may also be of help. The one on 
sourceforge.net is out of date compared to the manual that can be found 
at this link:

http://n-dimensional.de/projects/digicam/The_gPhoto2_Manual/html/

Tony

On Mon, 2002-09-02 at 10:36, Anthony Schlemmer wrote:

> I don't care for the BSD-style as it's a bit simplistic with all of the 
> local customizations in a single file. The Sys V init setup is more 
> flexible as it's just a matter of setting a few symbolic links to the 
> init script in the proper runlevel directory.
> 
> I haven't seen a BSD-style init setup in Linux since I used Slackware. I 
> do have one OpenBSD system that I'm working on but so far my local init 
> setup is quite simple.

I think BSD vs SysV style inits are just a matter of personal opinion. 
You like SysV because you can just go in and change a symlink... I like
BSD because I can just go in and comment out a line.

I always feel like I get a better grasp of what is happening with the
BSD inits, I can *read* the sequence from start to finish.  :-)

But, it isn't for everybody.  I guess if you had a ton of things
starting up with the system (Slackware keeps it somewhat minimal) SysV
might be better from an administrative point of view.  Drizzle has a
billion things starting up, I saw.  I always keep my system running as
few things on startup as possible... and what it does start up, odds are
I compiled it from source with as many optimizations as I could safely
get it to compile with.  :-)

-- 
Rob
"Google is your friend"




From dealy at deatech.com  Mon Sep  2 11:01:01 2002
From: dealy at deatech.com (Shannon C. Dealy)
Date: Mon, 2 Sep 2002 11:01:01 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Re:USB
In-Reply-To: <200209021019.11086.hapibeli@attbi.com>

On Mon, 2 Sep 2002, Dirk Ouellette wrote:

[snip]
> /lib/modules/2.4.18-3/kernel/drivers/usb/usb-ohci.o
> /lib/modules/2.4.18-3/kernel/drivers/usb/usb-uhci.o
> /lib/modules/2.4.18-3/kernel/drivers/usb/usbcore.o
[snip]
>  It looks like I have all of the necessary modules. Why wouldn't the Kodak
> dx3900 on one of my USB ports not be found? I have 2 ports and have tried
> both. I'm using gtkam with gPhoto on RedHat 7.3.
[snip]

I haven't been following this thread to closely, and I use gphoto2 rather
than gphoto, but the only way I could get it to work with my Kodak DC3400
is as follows:

1- usbcore and usb-ohci must be loaded (I think that usb-ohci is
   specific to the USB controller hardware on your system, for some people
   usb-uhci or another similar module may be required instead).

2- usbdevfs must be mounted

3- the usb module for my camera must NOT be loaded (gphoto2 talks directly
   to the camera, if the module is loaded, it can't get access). Everytime
   I plug my camera in, the module is automatically loaded, so I have to
   manually unload it before I can access the camera.

4- I have to run gphoto2 as root

Perhaps this will give you some ideas for things to try.

FWIW

only service beyond the basics I have running under OpenBSD is Samba.

I know Kodak has quite few cameras out there but I don't know if the 
usbdevfs needs to be mounted for any of the EasyShare cameras like the 
DX3900. I have an EasyShare DX4900 and I access the camera directly 
though "gphoto2". 

The only special setup I did was to make it so my "hotplug" service sets 
up the USB port permissions for me so I don't have to be root to access 
my camera. All I did was to place an entry for my camera in the 
/etc/hotplug/usb.usermap file.

>    specific to the USB controller hardware on your system, for some
> people usb-uhci or another similar module may be required instead).
>
> 2- usbdevfs must be mounted
>

> directly to the camera, if the module is loaded, it can't get
> access). Everytime I plug my camera in, the module is automatically
> loaded, so I have to manually unload it before I can access the
> camera.

From fedorp at wv.mentorg.com  Mon Sep  2 12:35:29 2002
From: fedorp at wv.mentorg.com (Fedor G. Pikus)
Date: Mon, 2 Sep 2002 12:35:29 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] USB
In-Reply-To: <200209011857.25104.hapibeli@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.31.0209021231220.10654-100000@lorien.wv.mentorg.com>

Read USB HOWTO at http://www.linux-usb.org/ for detailed instructions.

You need to find out what your USB controller is, most use usb-uhci or
usb-ohci module. Try "modprobe usb-uhci", if it fails, try the other one.
Then, when it works, add this to your modules.conf:

alias usb-controller usb-uhci # or usb-ohci

and may be modules for your USB peripherals,
alias char-major-13 mousedev
is USB mouse, for example (this is usually not necessary, hotplug loads
them automatically, but it stops those messages in the log about "cannot
find module char-major-13").

From aschlemm at attbi.com  Mon Sep  2 13:24:36 2002
From: aschlemm at attbi.com (Anthony Schlemmer)
Date: Mon, 2 Sep 2002 13:24:36 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Re:USB
In-Reply-To: <200209021254.11751.hapibeli@attbi.com>
References: <200209021254.11751.hapibeli@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <200209021324.36406.aschlemm@attbi.com>

I'm sorry that I don't use RedHat but if you do have the "hotplug" 
service on your system you should have an "/etc/hotplug" directory on 
your system. I only had to add my own usermap entry for my DC4900 to 
the /etc/hotplug/usb.usermap file.

You can use "ghoto2" to get a list of the various "usbcam" usermap 
entries for all of the cameras "gphoto2" supports. To get a list use 
the "--print-usb-usermap" option. You mentioned your camera is a Kodak 
EasyShare DX3900 so that would be the user map with a vendor id of 
0x040a and there is a product ID but since I don't have a DX3900 I'm 
not sure what the product ID is exactly. 

With your camera in the dock, press the button on the dock and then when 
your logged in as root run "lsusb". Can you see your camera in the list 
of detected USB devices? You can get the product ID from that list.

Tony

On Sun, 1 Sep 2002, Jeme A Brelin wrote:

>
> On Sun, 1 Sep 2002, Rogan Creswick wrote:
> > Many programs look for kernel headers in /usr/src/linux, so when you compile
> > things it is always a good idea to have the source tree for your
> > _current_ kernel in /usr/src/linux.
> >
> > What I do is this (once the kernel is downladed)
> >
> > 1) su to root,
> > 2) cd /usr/src
> > 3) if there exists a linux directory, move it.
> > 4) tar Ixvf /path_to_downloaded_kernel/linux-...tar.bz2

with some versions of tar replace I with j, or use
bzip2 -cd /path_to_downloaded_kernel/linux-...tar.bz2 | tar xvf -

That tip is just meant as an FYI for newbies.

> You should always always always make sure that the versions of the kernel
> headers you are using are the same ones that were used to build your
> version of libc... even if that is not the same as the kernel version
> you're running.
>

Is it safe to not touch them?  I never realized that a person vould
want to change /usr/include/linux.  Is this going to hurt me if I have
never changed them, since a 2.2 kernel?  And is there an easy way to
check what version is in /usr/include/linux? (I don't have a linux
system infront of me), can you just open one of the files and see the
version in the header?  Is there a way to query glibc to find out what
version of the kernel it was compiled against?

Thanks,
Jason

From cschluti at pdx.edu  Tue Sep  3 11:18:25 2002
From: cschluti at pdx.edu (Charlie Schluting)
Date: Tue, 3 Sep 2002 11:18:25 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Apache Question
In-Reply-To: <E50C78AF1CD9C7468CE52A3399B617440169740C@ljcbs067>
Message-ID: <001b01c25376$4e8c2950$4500000a@SERVANYA>

> I have one FreeBSD box running Apache and am doing some simple hosting
> currently
> for one domain name.  However, I have the possibility of hosting some
> other
> domain names.  My question is how do I set this up such that for a
given
> name it goes to the individual directory on the web server.  For
instance
> I want www.url1 to go to /www/url1 and www.url2 to go to /www/url2,
etc...
> 
Hello, 
I am assuming that you are going to use only one IP address.
Go here: http://httpd.apache.org/docs/vhosts/
And click on Name-based Virtual Hosts.

Depending on your version of apache, you probably have a separate Vhosts
directory and Vhosts.conf file to put the settings in. If I remember
correctly, older versions of apache just take these settings in
httpd.conf.
-Charlie

the camera dock. Once I  figured out my problem my system finally 
detected the camera when I pressed the button on the dock.

I don't know about the other DHCP clients but back when I had @Home I 
used "dhcpcd" because I was required to include my assigned @Home 
hostname to get an IP Address from their DHCP server(s). I'm not sure 
if some of the other DHCP client's supported that ability or not. Since 
AT&T took over after @Home dumped me I don't need to specify a hostname 
any more when I run "dhcpcd". I do see that I still get my old hostname 
back in the DHCP reply when I look at the info file "dhcpcd" creates.

From dmandel at pdxLinux.org  Tue Sep  3 14:02:34 2002
From: dmandel at pdxLinux.org (David Mandel)
Date: Tue, 3 Sep 2002 14:02:34 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] [OT] Women in Computing
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0209030733470.6609-100000@main.cyber-office.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0209031220280.17403-100000@sco302.DavidMandel.com>

I don't think this is ROT (Really Off Topic).

My wife, Nancy, is a mathematical statistician specializing in forest
genetics.  Thus, her profession is at the intersection of two male dominated
professions.  She makes good money, likes her colleagues, and enjoys her
work; and she doesn't think it is a big deal to work in a male
dominated field.

However, she does say a number of things about being a woman in
a male dominated profession.

First, it is a lot easier if people respect you for your technical
ability.  Otherwise, people think you got hired as part of some
"quota program", and they will make life hard on you.  Also, watch
men with second rate technical skills.  They find women and minorities
much more threatening than most men do.

Second, Nancy talks a lot about the social aspects of working in a male
dominated profession.  A professional woman has to figure out how
to fit in and relate to her professional colleagues - most of whom
are men; and also how to relate to the organization's secretaries
and clerical staff - most of whom are women - without becoming one
of them.

In any case, I would recommend that you have your female student talk
to a couple real women in computing about their experience.  I think
this might be more revealing than pointing out a number of famous
woman in computer science.

                                                 David Mandel

It is possible. I had a 3-4 year old PC with a usb controller that
wouldn't work under Linux (the drivers loaded fine but devices were never
recognized.) This weekend I upgraded to RedHat 7.3, disabled the on-board
USB, and installed a cheap d-link USB card and it "just worked".

From 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com  Tue Sep  3 15:03:19 2002
From: 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com (Steve Bonds)
Date: Tue, 3 Sep 2002 15:03:19 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Making web browsing fun again
Message-ID: <822159988.1031091826553.JavaMail.root@monkey>

On Thu, 29 Aug 2002, Rich Shepard rshepard at appl-ecosys.com XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX wrote:

>   Has anyone mentioned junkbuster? We've been running it for a few years now
> and it works _very_ well.

I run Junkbuster, and it has worked well for a long time.  Unfortunately,
I've recently started to notice problems with it which I have not been
able to nail down.  Blocked URLs will get requested (I can see them in a
packet trace) but they will not be blocked (action completes, no log in
the junkbuster log even in debug mode.)  This is particularly annoying
when requests for http://page.i.want.com gets mixed with requests for
http://evil.doubleclick.net in the same TCP stream.  I suspect that some
recent MSIE enhancement is responsible for this.  (I've already tried
disabling HTTP/1.1 from within MSIE, but it doesn't seem to make any
difference.)

For that reason I've started to look at squid + adzapper
(http://www.zip.com.au/~cs/adzap/index.html).  Unfortunately, this combo
seems to have some issues transparently passing NTLM authentication on to
the !@#$@* proxy I'm forced to use at work.  I have not had time to
investigate fully.  (It seems like NTLM gets passed properly for the first
request, but not for subsequent requests.  It's wierd.)

  -- Steve

From jeme at brelin.net  Wed Sep  4 00:48:05 2002
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Wed, 4 Sep 2002 00:48:05 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] [OT] Women in Computing
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0209030733470.6609-100000@main.cyber-office.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0209040043430.13097-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Tue, 3 Sep 2002, Roderick A. Anderson wrote:
> I'm teaching "Computer Science Orientation" at the local community
> college this semester (first time for me) and only have one woman in
> the class.  She's a little uncertain about being in there because the
> 'the guys' seem to know so much.  My thought was to have a quick
> project for fun on Women in Computing.

Well, first, I think your use of the word "fun" for a project on women in
computing belies a certain attitude that is perhaps part of the reason
women are pushed away from the field.  "Isn't this silly?  GIRLS did it!"

Second, I think the idea of "Women in Computing" as a subject creates one
of them there "separate but equal" fallacies.  Separate is inherently
unequal.

While the thought is sort of sweet and quaint, it's also antiquated and
not helpful.  It sounds like the 1950s approach.  You can probably achieve
something a little more progressive and enlightened.

Perhaps you should just make a point of mentioning the women in computing
during your anecdotal material related to the history of computer science
and maybe go a bit out of your way to find relevant quotes in the
prominent newsgroups and mailing list archives by female hackers to
illustrate points made in the lectures.

J.

From jeme at brelin.net  Wed Sep  4 01:12:32 2002
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Wed, 4 Sep 2002 01:12:32 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Apache Question
In-Reply-To: <E50C78AF1CD9C7468CE52A3399B617440169740C@ljcbs067>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0209040107530.13097-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Tue, 3 Sep 2002, Olds, Aaron M wrote:
> I have one FreeBSD box running Apache and am doing some simple hosting
> currently for one domain name.  However, I have the possibility of
> hosting some other domain names.  My question is how do I set this up
> such that for a given name it goes to the individual directory on the
> web server.  For instance I want www.url1 to go to /www/url1 and
> www.url2 to go to /www/url2, etc...

It's actually really super easy.

First, I'm going to just suggest that you RTFM.
<URL: http://httpd.apache.org/docs/vhosts/index.html > (for 1.3)

You are best off, in my opinion, using mod_vhost_alias if you'll be
hosting multiple named sites (either by hostname or domain) on a single
IP.  This allows you to specify information for virtual hosts based on
parsed data from the name given to the httpd server by the client.  You
can read all about that here:
<URL: http://httpd.apache.org/docs/mod/mod_vhost_alias.html >

If you have more specific questions, please direct them to the list.
J.

From karlheg at hegbloom.net  Wed Sep  4 09:41:04 2002
From: karlheg at hegbloom.net (Karl M. Hegbloom)
Date: 04 Sep 2002 09:41:04 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] USB
In-Reply-To: <200209011857.25104.hapibeli@attbi.com>
References: <200209011857.25104.hapibeli@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <8765xlg127.fsf@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>

Dirk Ouellette <hapibeli at attbi.com> writes:

> How do I set the kernel up with them so my usb camera can be seen?

If you run Debian GNU/Linux, it's as simple as running a stock kernel
or one configured starting with a stock configuration, then running:

 # apt-get install hotplug hotplug-utils

That will give you USB hotplug support, amoung other things.  It
should "Just Work" from that point forward.  (Though I don't know if
it automaticly creates device nodes on a non-devfs system; you may
like to start using devfs for this; apt-get install devfsd and add
"devfs=mount" to your boot loader append line)

Sean Whitney <sean at fork.com> writes:

> Try apt-get install kernel-source and it will give you a list of
> kernels that you can download for installation.

It's also best to use "apt-get install kernel-package", "man
make-kpkg" to build a Debian kernel package, since that gives you the
postinstall Lilo/Grub setup hooks and initrd building (if configured).

After you install "kernel-package", run:

man kernel-pkg.conf
man kernel-img.conf
man make-kpkg

"lhomer" <lhomer at attbi.com> writes:

> I would like to be able to annotate various manuals distributed as
> ps or pdf files with my own notes and experiences. Does anyone know
> of a utility that would invert the usual process and make a latex
> input file from a pdf or ps file?

You could try using ghostscript to turn it into bitmap files, running
gocr on them to get ASCII, then writing in the markup.  Or you could
use ps2text on them, if that works.

The best thing is to just try and find the original document source.
Perhaps the author will share it with you?  Tell them you want to
learn LaTeX.

From dmandel at pdxLinux.org  Wed Sep  4 10:37:40 2002

Subject: [PLUG] A training cooperative? (fwd)

On Thu, 29 Aug 2002, Tyler F. Creelan wrote:

>
> Charging people for the class would place pressure on the teacher to
> make it high quality. Since we don't have a lot of
> time to dedicate towards teaching, this pressure might not be welcome.

Actually, this is the good thing about charging.
The instructor and students tend to show up when there is a tuition,
even when the tuition is small.
On the other hand, students shouldn't expect too much for $5 per
student per hour.  At this pay level, instructors couldn't afford
much preparation, so they would be more like expert coordinators
than professional trainers with lots of fancy prepared materials.

> Charging by the hour might also pressure the teacher to keep the class
> under an hour and could discourage questions. Personally, I would also
> feel discouraged from teaching subjects that I enjoy but am less
> knowledgeable in.
>

Actually, I didn't really mean that one should charge by the hour.
Instead, one would use these rates to set a tuition for a class.
Thus, a class scheduled to meet for 3 hours per week for two weeks
would have a retail tuition of 3x2x($15) = $90.00.  Like a college
class, the actual time with the instructor might be a bit less than
this or a bit more than this.

> So generally I would prefer a free class, both as teacher and student.
>

If anyone can put together a program of free classes, more power to them.
I personally don't think this is practical.
I personally would want to be paid a bit for my facilities if I had
classes in my home.
I personally would want to be paid a bit for my time if I taught a class.
Maybe other people would do this for free.  If so, go for it.

                                                     Dave Mandel

P.S.  Maybe one should vary the fee to fit the instructor and facility.
      (In other words, they would set them.  That is fair.)

From rsteff at attbi.com  Wed Sep  4 12:04:00 2002
From: rsteff at attbi.com (Richard Steffens)
Date: Wed, 04 Sep 2002 12:04:00 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Debian Power Down doesn't - Resolved
References: <3D7148E1.FDBA004E@attbi.com> <87sn0pema5.fsf@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>
Message-ID: <3D765920.D0399D91@attbi.com>

"Karl M. Hegbloom" wrote:

> > Avatar:~# modprobe apm
> > modprobe: Can't locate module apm
> 
> Ok, it's probably built into the kernel already.  Boot with "apm=on"
> once and try again.  If that does not work, rebuild or install a stock
> 2.4.18 kernel.

I watched for a reference to apm in the messages scrolling up the
screen during boot. I saw:

apm: BIOS version 1.2 Flags 0X03 (Driver version 1.13)
apm disabled on user request

After a bit of man page reading and google searching, I learned that I
needed to edit lilo.conf, uncomment the append="" line and stick apm=on
inside those quotes, and also to run lilo before rebooting.

During the reboot, I saw only one apm message:

apm: BIOS version 1.2 Flags 0X03 (Driver version 1.13)

Sure enough, the system powers down, now.

Thanks for the hint, Karl, and also for not giving me the whole answer.
I learned a few other things about lilo in the process.

-- 
Regards,

Dick Steffens
"Quando Omni Flunkus Moritati"
http://rsteff.home.attbi.com/

From dagit at engr.orst.edu  Wed Sep  4 16:14:45 2002
From: dagit at engr.orst.edu (Jason Dagit)
Date: Wed, 4 Sep 2002 16:14:45 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Quirky Mouse
In-Reply-To: <3D7691AC.90D320AE@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0209041608580.18049-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>


On Wed, 4 Sep 2002, Richard Steffens wrote:

> Rogan Creswick wrote:
>
> > Have you tried it with gpm disabled?
> > /etc/init.d/gpm stop
> > will stop gpm, then restart X and see if that helps.
>
> I'm going to get a new keyboard tomorrow, one that will let me switch
> between virtual consoles. Then, I'll give that a try.
>
> > I've also found that controlling the mouse behavior through X directly,
> > rather than through a WM is more reliable.
>
> What do I have to change to do that? I assume it's a configuration file
> entry somewhere. Which one, and what should I be reading for background
> so I understand what I'm doing?

I think this depends on which one you are using.  To test the X
drivers, you could create the file ~/.xsession (or is it ~/.xinit, i
usually create one and make it a symlink to the other), with just one
line that says xterm.  Then type startx, you should get a gray lined
background and a single xterm window.  Hit ctrl+alt+backspace to
exit. If your mouse works better than normal when you do that, then
your WM is conflicting with the X driver.  Then we need to know which
WM you are using.  Is it Gnome, KDE, enlightenment, there are many
choices.

HTH,
Jason

From creswick at cs.orst.edu  Wed Sep  4 16:35:08 2002
From: creswick at cs.orst.edu (Rogan Creswick)
Date: Wed, 4 Sep 2002 16:35:08 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Quirky Mouse
In-Reply-To: <3D7691AC.90D320AE@attbi.com>
References: <3D767B95.4EA7211A@attbi.com> <20020904214919.GA23670@silver.CS.ORST.EDU> <3D7691AC.90D320AE@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <20020904233508.GB23766@silver.CS.ORST.EDU>

> I'm going to get a new keyboard tomorrow, one that will let me switch
> between virtual consoles. Then, I'll give that a try.

I find init 3 to be good for debugging, but that's just me.

> 
> > I've also found that controlling the mouse behavior through X directly,
> > rather than through a WM is more reliable.
> 
> What do I have to change to do that? I assume it's a configuration file
> entry somewhere. Which one, and what should I be reading for background
> so I understand what I'm doing?
> 

The file is /etc/X11/XF86Config or XF86Config-4, depending on your version
of X (< 4 and 4, respectivly). If you have a lot of config files in there
with similar names, you will have to confirm which one is being used. An
easy way to do this is to put some plain text at the top of the file (not in
a comment). If X starts, that wasn't the correct file :).

I use X 4.??, so your file may look different, but here is my mouse section:

Section "InputDevice"
   Identifier  "Configured Mouse"
   Driver      "mouse"
   Option      "CorePointer"
   Option      "Device"    "/dev/psaux"  #ps/2 mouse on /dev/psaux
   Option      "Protocol"     "ImPS/2"   
   Option      "Emulate3Buttons" "false" #I have a 3 button mouse.
   Option      "ZAxisMapping"    "4 5"   # ...with a wheel
   Option      "Resolution"      "200"   # this affects how sensative the
	                                      # mouse is. IIRC, higher is faster.
EndSection


In X 3.3.6, I _think_ you want something like this for the resolution line:

Resolution	200


I've never really read/seen/looked for any Xconfig documentation, I've done
a lot of trial&error work and cannabalized from many subject-specific
how-to's and random XF86Config files.

--Rogan



From derek at infotects.com  Wed Sep  4 16:58:51 2002
From: derek at infotects.com (Derek Loree)
Date: 04 Sep 2002 16:58:51 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Quirky Mouse
In-Reply-To: <3D767B95.4EA7211A@attbi.com>
References: <3D767B95.4EA7211A@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <1031183932.14021.25936.camel@dereklinux>

On Wed, 2002-09-04 at 14:31, Richard Steffens wrote:
> In searching for some hint as to why my mouse behaves strangely on my
> newly installed Debian system (cursor doesn't move when mouse is moved
> slowly), I came across this on google:
> 
> gpm and X problem investigated
> http://lists.debian.org/debian-testing/2000/debian-testing-200008/msg00064.html
> 
> While I don't fully understand it yet, it appears to me that I need to
> figure out if I'm using gpm, and how it is configured. Where do I look
> for that information? man gpm reports: No manual entry for gpm. Could it
> be that there is a misprint on that whole page and that I should be
> looking at gdm?

Since man gpm didn't return anything, you don't have gpm installed.  I,
personally, like to use gpm because it adds an interpretive layer
between the mouse device (/dev/psaux or whatever) and the X-server, as
well as making it possible to copy and paste between consoles. The basic
concept is that the gpm daemon reads the mouse device, then it can
modify the data and writes the new information to another device:
/dev/gpmdata.  If your X-server is configured to read /dev/gpmdata as
the mouse device, then it will see the filtered signal instead of the
"raw" event.  The huge advantage here is that you can start the X-server
(it will start as long as /dev/gpmdata exists) with a broken mouse
configuration, and just by changing gpm settings you can reconfigure the
mouse and get it working WITHOUT restarting your X-server.

This does have limitations, the protocol you pick for the X-server must
be close to the actual protocol, use ImPS/2 for most PS2 mice, use ms
for most serial mice.  Getting gpm to work correctly is usually a
serious round of trial and error, mainly because there is no standard
for mouse data and some manufacturers tried really hard to not be
standard.


> 
> One of the comments on that page is:
> 
> 6. My personal experience shows that, with gpm repeating in the ms3
>    protocol, the middle mouse button is very hard to get working in X,
> if
>    at all. Also, movement data of the mouse appears to get lost,
> resulting
>    in erratic and uncomfortable mouse behaviour.
> 
> That sounds like the behavior my mouse is exhibiting. Is this the
> direction I should be pursuing?
> 
I think so, the mouse, in general, behaves much better when filtered
through gpm and the gpm daemon has many more protocols available than
the X-server.

HTH

Derek Loree

From rsteff at attbi.com  Wed Sep  4 17:37:19 2002
From: rsteff at attbi.com (Richard Steffens)
Date: Wed, 04 Sep 2002 17:37:19 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] parted advice, please
Message-ID: <3D76A73E.CCFCBEA2@attbi.com>

For some reason, when I set up the partitions for my new Debian install,
I made a poor choice regarding the sizes of /usr and /home. I've
installed parted (I guessed that apt-get -install parted would do it,
and it did!) and now I'm studying the instructions for how to change
things. I have some questions about what I'm planning to do:

1. Unless I decide to change the size of the Windows partition, do I
need to do anything about the warning I get when I start parted?

  Using /dev/hda
  Warning: The operating system thinks the geometry on /dev/hda is
  1583/255/63. Therefore, cylinder 1024 ends at 8032.499M.  You have
  Windows FAT partition(s) that are not using LBA.  If your BIOS
  supports LBA, then you should switch to LBA by setting the LBA flag
  on all FAT partitions.  Otherwise, make sure the operating system and
  the BIOS have the same geometry before resizing any FAT partitions.

2. Is what I describe below correct, or did I miss something important?
Also, is 1G reasonable for /home, or should I be planning something more
involved?

When I created the partitions, I made /usr 1G and /home 4G. I should
have done that the other way around, but since they are adjacent, it
should be relatively painless to fix. From what I'm reading at:

http://www.gnu.org/manual/parted-1.6.1/html_node/parted_32.html

I should be able to shrink /home, create a new partition at the end of
/home's old space, copy /home to that partition, delete the old /home,
and then add the leftover space from the to /usr. Have I missed anything
important that would prevent me from doing that, or cause me serious
grief? 

Here's the details:

Parted's print command reports:

  Disk geometry for /dev/hda: 0.000-12419.056 megabytes
  Disk label type: msdos
  Minor    Start       End     Type      Filesystem  Flags
  1          0.031   4141.757  primary   FAT         boot
  2       4141.758   4235.888  primary   ext2
  3       4235.889  12417.429  extended
  5       4235.919   4361.396  logical   linux-swap
  6       4361.427   5334.082  logical   ext2
  7       5334.113   9240.512  logical   ext2
  8       9240.543   9287.578  logical   ext2
  9       9287.609  12417.429  logical   ext2

df -h reports:

  Filesystem          Size   Used Avail Use% Mounted on
  /dev/hda2            91M    28M   58M  33% /
  /dev/hda6           957M   772M  137M  85% /usr
  /dev/hda7           3.8G   271M  3.2G   8% /home
  /dev/hda8            45M    22k   43M   1% /tmp
  /dev/hda9           3.0G    89M  2.7G   4% /var

The sequence of instructions would be as follows:

Shrink /home to about 1G.

(parted) resize 7 5334.113 6358.113

Make a new, 1G partition at the end of the free space. It will be #10.

(parted) mkpartfs logical ext2 8216.512 9240.512

Copy the old /home to its new location.

(parted) cp 7 10

Delete the old /home.

(parted) rm 7

Resize /usr to use up the newly available space.

(parted) resize 6 4361.427 8216.511

Quit parted and edit /etc/fstab.

Since deleting the old #7 caused 8, 9, and 10 to be renumbered 7, 8, and
9, then the new /home is 9, /tmp is 7, and /var is 8. So, I'd need to
change some lines in fstab from:

/dev/hda7     /home   ext2   defaults         0     2
/dev/hda8     /tmp    ext2   defaults         0     2
/dev/hda9     /var    ext2   defaults         0     2

to:

/dev/hda9     /home   ext2   defaults         0     2
/dev/hda7     /tmp    ext2   defaults         0     2
/dev/hda8     /var    ext2   defaults         0     2

Then, after I reboot, I should have more room in /usr, less room in
/home, and everybody else stayed the same.

On Wed, 2002-09-04 at 17:34, Richard Steffens wrote:
> Derek Loree wrote:
> 
> > Dick Steffens wrote:
> > > man gpm reports: No manual entry for gpm. Could it
> > > be that there is a misprint on that whole page and that I should be
> > > looking at gdm?
> > 
> > Since man gpm didn't return anything, you don't have gpm installed.
> 
> So, it wasn't a misprint.
> 
> > I, personally, like to use gpm because it adds an interpretive layer
> > between the mouse device (/dev/psaux or whatever) and the X-server, as
> > well as making it possible to copy and paste between consoles.
> 
> I like this concept. I seem to recall, now that you mention it, having
> read something about being able to unplug keyboards if gpm is in use.
> While not something I'd need to do every day, it could come in handy
> from time to time, like the other day when I managed to disconnect my
> keyboard while shifting some things around on the desk.

Unplugging a keyboard is usually no big deal, but gpm is only for the
mouse, it does nothing with the keyboard.  With gpm, you should be able
to stop the server (/etc/init.d/gpm stop), unplug your mouse, plug in a
new one and run gpmconfig to get it working; all without rebooting.
> 
> So, if I run apt-get install gpm, that should set it up, and give me a
> man page, but I'd have to reboot in order for it to run, right?

No reboot required, it will be running when the installation is
finished. However, you will need to restart your X-server after you have
modified the configuration file.  The config file has the command to
re-run the debconf script, if you are using debconf to handle your
X-server configuration.  <crtl>+<alt>+<Backspace> will restart it, or
kill it, depending on your system configuration.

Derek

From heinlein at attbi.com  Thu Sep  5 06:21:33 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Thu, 5 Sep 2002 06:21:33 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] .tgz
In-Reply-To: <1031193119.14056.0.camel@duron>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0209050617320.3950-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On 4 Sep 2002, AthlonRob wrote:

> Otherwise, try tar -xvzf filename.tgz
> 
> tgz==tar.gz

My understanding is that the .tgz extension was developed as a
workaround for certain ancient filesystems that restricted filenames
to an 8.3 format (up to 8 characters, followed by a dot (.), followed
up up to three characters). Those filesystems couldn't handle, say,
foo.tar.gz, so it was trunctated to foo.tgz.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>




From raanders at acm.org  Thu Sep  5 06:24:51 2002
From: raanders at acm.org (Roderick A. Anderson)
Date: Thu, 5 Sep 2002 06:24:51 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] .tgz
In-Reply-To: <200209041859.50595.hapibeli@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0209050619030.28985-100000@main.cyber-office.net>

On Wed, 4 Sep 2002, Dirk Ouellette wrote:

> How do I install a .tgz file? AS opposed to a tar.gz file.

The .tgz extension is/was a kludge for PC/MS DOS filenaming.  As you may
not know DOS is limited to 1-8 characters in the filename and 0-3 in the
extension sometimes represented by 'FILENAME.EXT'.  Since the period (or
dot) is a separator/delimiter in DOS (verses an actual character in
UNIX/Linux and some other OS') you can't use more than one.
   So you get filename.tgz instead of filename.tar.gz.

And to finally answer your question - the same way you do the .tar.gz 
files.


Rod
-- 
  "Open Source Software - Sometimes you get more than you paid for..."

From richard.langis at sun.com  Thu Sep  5 10:55:56 2002
From: richard.langis at sun.com (Richard Langis)
Date: Thu, 05 Sep 2002 10:55:56 -0700
Subject: Solaris Tip (was: Re: [PLUG] Quirky Mouse)
References: <3D767B95.4EA7211A@attbi.com>	<1031183932.14021.25936.camel@dereklinux> <3D76A69B.8BE70380@attbi.com>	<1031187881.14011.25962.camel@dereklinux> 	<20020905090006.GD23828@silver.CS.ORST.EDU> <1031247423.2524.25979.camel@dereklinux>
Message-ID: <3D779AAC.7030102@sun.com>

Since Rogan (I think?) said he fubared his manpath entry on his Solaris 
box, I figured I'd share a little thing I did during a class I took on 
Solaris System Administration.

I'm used to using 'locate' when I need something.  Of course, Solaris 
doesn't provide that feature natively, and our class machines didn't 
have internet access, so I couldn't see if the GNU Tools had it either. 
  I remembered from poking around at the scripts that update the locate 
database (updatecb) that all it really does is a 'find' and drops that 
data into a file for later lookup.  So this is exactly what I 
implemented on my Solaris box.

First, I created a script that created the database.  I called it 
updatedb.  It called find, indexing from root, not looking at remote 
filesystems, and dumping everything it found into a file somewhere in /var.

Secondly, I created the locate command itself.  Basically all it did was 
grep that created file for whatever argument you specified.

Then, I created a cron job that would run updatedb every evening.

I'm sure the data file structure could have been more elegant, but I was 
really more interested in getting functionality out of the program than 
making it pretty.  It took me a few minutes of class to get it working 
the way I wanted (while the teacher was tutoring the less enlightened 
students) and I learned quite a bit just doing stuff on my own.

FYI Rogan - my current MANPATH looks like so:

/usr/man:/usr/openwin/man:/usr/local/tools/man:/usr/local/man

[10:51:35] $  uname -a
SunOS ecola 5.8 Generic_108528-15 sun4u sparc SUNW,Ultra-80

-Richard

all free software and can be compiled on Solaris without any
difficulty:

ftp://ftp.geekreview.org/slocate/src/slocate-2.6.tar.gz

Another data point:

  [heinlein]$ uname -a
  SunOS hepburn 5.8 Generic_108528-14 sun4u sparc SUNW,Ultra-5_10
  [heinlein]$ echo $MANPATH
  /usr/share/man:/usr/man:/usr/java/man:/usr/openwin/man:/usr/dt/man

Other good candidates for $MANPATH include /usr/local/man, 
/usr/local/share/man, and a host of more obscure directories:

  /opt/SUNWspro/man      -- Sun Workshop compilers
  /usr/j2se/man          -- Java 1.4
  /usr/openwin/share/man -- new-style X man dir
  /usr/dt/share/man      -- new-style cde man dir
  /usr/perl5/man         -- system perl
  /opt/TWWfsw/man        -- for The Written Word packages
  /opt/gnome-1.4/man     -- for Sun's gnome package

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

From cbrown at woods.net  Thu Sep  5 12:02:00 2002
From: cbrown at woods.net (Christopher E. Brown)
Date: Thu, 5 Sep 2002 13:02:00 -0600 (MDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Fwd: gphoto2 error
In-Reply-To: <200209042125.09146.hapibeli@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0209051256250.22952-100000@spruce.woods.net>



You need to mount the USBdevfs under /proc.  The generic usb libs that
gphoto2 uses can detect a device, but to do IO with it they use the
/proc/bus/usb entries.

*If* you will be using the devices as a normal user (non-root) you
need to install the hotplug system and configure its scripting to set
permissions on the usb device as it becomes active.


Anyway to make it work as root, add

none   /proc/bus/usb   usbdevfs   defaults   0 0

or similar to your fstab, and make sure usbdevfs is compiled in or
module is loaded.

 --
I route, therefore you are.

Not that I have ever heard of.  They will both do RAID0, but with
defferent on disk layouts.  It would be like trying to swap an array
between 2 different hardware RAID controllers, they both do the same
thing, but the minor stuff (disk id headers, exact layout, etc)
caries.

From AthlonRob at data.lm.ro  Thu Sep  5 13:41:20 2002
From: AthlonRob at data.lm.ro (AthlonRob)
Date: 05 Sep 2002 13:41:20 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] NTFS stripped RAID-0 and Linux?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0209051318360.20625-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>
References: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0209051318360.20625-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>
Message-ID: <1031258480.4666.3.camel@duron>

On Thu, 2002-09-05 at 13:22, Jason Dagit wrote:

> What about having linux put it's filesystem on top on NTFS.  I know
> slackware could do this back in the days of win95 because that was the
> way I installed it....ah my first linux install...those were the days
> :)

I don't think you can put a filesystem in NTFS and have it work very
well.

I think you're thinking of ZipSlack/BigSlack, which were just regular
ol' Linux, made to install easily onto a UMSDOS system.  UMSDOS is just,
essentially, an interesting extention to the FAT filesystem which
allowed Linux-style permissions with the use of extra files in each
directory.

UMSDOS wouldn't work with NTFS.

You could, I suppose, create a loopback filesystem on the NTFS
partition, but you'd be asking for trouble.  It would probably be a wee
bit on the slow side, and likely unstable... Linux's ability to write to
NTFS was still 'experimental' or 'dangerous' last I looked.

-- 
Rob
 "The nice thing about standards is that you have so many to choose
from."
 - Andrew S. Tanenbaum

This is not so in some cases. I access my Kodak DX4900 directly using 
"gphoto2" without using the USBdevfs support. I have found that KDE 
incorrectly assumes that all digital cameras require the usbdevfs 
through a "kioslave" for digital camera access and I get I/O errors 
because of it. It is true that some cameras are accessed through a USB 
filesystem but there are quite a few cameras that aren't as well. I 
believe in the case of a camera that is mounted using the USBdevfs that 
there is no need to use "gphoto2" at all since I assume the pictures 
would be accessed like any other mounted filesystem Linux supports 
using common file utilities like "ls", and "cp" to list and copy the 
files from the camera to another location.

You are correct about the use of the "hotplug" service so permissions 
can be set to allow non-root users access to a digital camera.

On Thursday 05 September 2002 12:02 pm, Christopher E. Brown wrote:
> You need to mount the USBdevfs under /proc.  The generic usb libs
> that gphoto2 uses can detect a device, but to do IO with it they use
> the /proc/bus/usb entries.
>
> *If* you will be using the devices as a normal user (non-root) you
> need to install the hotplug system and configure its scripting to set
> permissions on the usb device as it becomes active.
>
>
> Anyway to make it work as root, add
>
> none   /proc/bus/usb   usbdevfs   defaults   0 0
>
> or similar to your fstab, and make sure usbdevfs is compiled in or
> module is loaded.
>

From cbrown at woods.net  Thu Sep  5 14:33:25 2002
From: cbrown at woods.net (Christopher E. Brown)
Date: Thu, 5 Sep 2002 15:33:25 -0600 (MDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Fwd: gphoto2 error
In-Reply-To: <200209051429.13838.aschlemm@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0209051529090.22952-100000@spruce.woods.net>

On Thu, 5 Sep 2002, Anthony Schlemmer wrote:

> This is not so in some cases. I access my Kodak DX4900 directly using
> "gphoto2" without using the USBdevfs support. I have found that KDE
> incorrectly assumes that all digital cameras require the usbdevfs
> through a "kioslave" for digital camera access and I get I/O errors
> because of it. It is true that some cameras are accessed through a USB
> filesystem but there are quite a few cameras that aren't as well. I
> believe in the case of a camera that is mounted using the USBdevfs that
> there is no need to use "gphoto2" at all since I assume the pictures
> would be accessed like any other mounted filesystem Linux supports
> using common file utilities like "ls", and "cp" to list and copy the
> files from the camera to another location.
>
> You are correct about the use of the "hotplug" service so permissions
> can be set to allow non-root users access to a digital camera.


No, usbdevfs is like devfs.  It *DOES NOT* provide access to the
cameras filesystem.  What it does is create block/char devices
automagicly based on the bus/device id.  usbdevfs is *required* for
every USB interfaced camera I have worked with, though I understand a
few don't use the default interface (direct camera specific module
instead of the generic one).  Of course serial, parallel and SCSI
cameras do not require usbdevfs devices.

I think you are thinking of camera filesystem access via a CardFlash
or CompactFlash reader.  These allow you to mount the filesystem on
the flash directly.

 --
I route, therefore you are.

From ckuskie at dalsemi.com  Thu Sep  5 16:43:26 2002
From: ckuskie at dalsemi.com (Colin Kuskie)
Date: Thu, 5 Sep 2002 16:43:26 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Network card problem
In-Reply-To: <002001c25534$4629a570$8701a8c0@barkingcorndog>; from josh@barkingcorndog.homelinux.org on Thu, Sep 05, 2002 at 04:30:48PM -0700
References: <000e01c25532$5eabd340$8701a8c0@barkingcorndog> <20020905162159.G11458@dalsemi.com> <002001c25534$4629a570$8701a8c0@barkingcorndog>
Message-ID: <20020905164326.H11458@dalsemi.com>

On Thu, Sep 05, 2002 at 04:30:48PM -0700, josh zeckser wrote:
> 
>     I need to be more clear. The system with the misbehaving network card is
> a desktop PC. It's a PCI card. Actually, my laptop with the PCMCIA card
> works just fine under Debian.

My apologies.  When you said you removed and re-inserted, I assumed
that it was a 15-second job instead of opening the case.

In that case, the odds are pretty good that either:

1) It's still a bad network driver. (not PCMCIA)
  - Check /var/log/messages for strange messages during the boot
    sequence.

  - Make sure that the driver is loaded by typing lsmod (being root
    will help due to the path).

  - See if it's being seen by the PCI bus by doing lspci.

  - Make sure that the kernel versions in Woody and RH 7.3 are similar.
    If Woody's is much different than 7.3, then I'd see if you can get
    a similar kernel from Woody to what you were using before.
    That won't be fun because you don't have a network interface.
    Good alternatives are burning CDROM's, or you could get a USB to
    ethernet converter.  Of course, you may have as many problems
    with that as the network card.

2) Bad hardware.  Then you have no other option except to try it out
   with what you knew was working before and see it still works.

Good luck, and sorry for the earlier slip,
Colin

Hi Josh,

On Thu, 2002-09-05 at 16:17, josh zeckser wrote:
> Hello everyone!
> 
>     I have recently changed my system from Red Hat 7.3 to Debian Woody. After installing Debian, I can't seem to figure out the problem with the network card. I can't give you the ifconfig info right now, since I'm sending this mail from work and don't have access to my machine right now. Here's the info I have:
> Card: Netgear FA312

I've heard of lots of problems with these cards.

> Driver: natsemi

Is this with the 2.4.18 kernel?

>         Everything I saw online regarding this card said to use this driver. Also, that's the one that kudzu chose for me.
> I have the interface configured with:
> IP: 192.168.0.5
> gateway: 192.168.0.1
> netmask: 255.255.255.0
> network: 192.168.0.0
> my /etc/network/interfaces file is identical to another machine on my network (except for the ip address, of course), also running Debian, which works just fine. 
> When I try to ping anything on the network (gateway, mail server, my wife's machine, laptop), I don't get anything at all. No 'network unreachable', etc. It just sits there until I ctrl-c, then it tells me how many packets were sent, 100%failure, etc.

Did you try pinging itself with the 192.168.0.5 address?  Does ifdown
and ifup work?
 
> ifconfig shows all of the info correctly, so I can see that it's configured.
> Here's where the problem gets interesting: none of the lights do anything on my card at all. at all. Nothing when I'm trying to ping, nothing when I boot, nothing when it's just sitting there. I tried removing and re-inserting the card, but still nothing. It worked just fine under Red Hat a couple of days ago. I really don't want to reinstall Red Hat just to see if the card still works. Any ideas on where to look next?

No link light is not good, that usually means the hardware has a
problem.  In this case, you should test the cable and the device at the
other end. (Does the link light lite up on the other end?)  If you are
sure that the cable and other end device are good, then do a complete
power cycle, not just a reboot, but power down, wait 30 seconds, then
power up.  Remember, nothing is going to happen if you don't have a link
light on both ends.

If none of this works, we'll need more juicy details.

HTH

Derek Loree

> that it was a 15-second job instead of opening the case.
>
> In that case, the odds are pretty good that either:
>
> 1) It's still a bad network driver. (not PCMCIA)
>   - Check /var/log/messages for strange messages during the boot
>     sequence.
>
>   - Make sure that the driver is loaded by typing lsmod (being root
>     will help due to the path).
>
>   - See if it's being seen by the PCI bus by doing lspci.
>
>   - Make sure that the kernel versions in Woody and RH 7.3 are similar.
>     If Woody's is much different than 7.3, then I'd see if you can get
>     a similar kernel from Woody to what you were using before.
>     That won't be fun because you don't have a network interface.
>     Good alternatives are burning CDROM's, or you could get a USB to
>     ethernet converter.  Of course, you may have as many problems
>     with that as the network card.
>
> 2) Bad hardware.  Then you have no other option except to try it out
>    with what you knew was working before and see it still works.
>
> Good luck, and sorry for the earlier slip,
> Colin
>
> _______________________________________________
> PLUG mailing list
> PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
> http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug
>




From aschlemm at attbi.com  Thu Sep  5 16:51:48 2002
From: aschlemm at attbi.com (Anthony Schlemmer)
Date: Thu, 5 Sep 2002 16:51:48 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Fwd: gphoto2 error
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0209051529090.22952-100000@spruce.woods.net>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0209051529090.22952-100000@spruce.woods.net>
Message-ID: <200209051651.48775.aschlemm@attbi.com>

I've looked when I've had my camera enabled and I don't see any USB 
related modules being used by the kernel so I figured I wasn't using 
the usbdevfs stuff in Linux. I admit it's a blackbox for me as I just 
use "gphoto2" and it works. :)

Tony

On Thursday 05 September 2002 14:33 pm, Christopher E. Brown wrote:
> On Thu, 5 Sep 2002, Anthony Schlemmer wrote:
> > This is not so in some cases. I access my Kodak DX4900 directly
> > using "gphoto2" without using the USBdevfs support. I have found
> > that KDE incorrectly assumes that all digital cameras require the
> > usbdevfs through a "kioslave" for digital camera access and I get
> > I/O errors because of it. It is true that some cameras are accessed
> > through a USB filesystem but there are quite a few cameras that
> > aren't as well. I believe in the case of a camera that is mounted
> > using the USBdevfs that there is no need to use "gphoto2" at all
> > since I assume the pictures would be accessed like any other
> > mounted filesystem Linux supports using common file utilities like
> > "ls", and "cp" to list and copy the files from the camera to
> > another location.
> >
> > You are correct about the use of the "hotplug" service so
> > permissions can be set to allow non-root users access to a digital
> > camera.
>
> No, usbdevfs is like devfs.  It *DOES NOT* provide access to the
> cameras filesystem.  What it does is create block/char devices
> automagicly based on the bus/device id.  usbdevfs is *required* for
> every USB interfaced camera I have worked with, though I understand a
> few don't use the default interface (direct camera specific module
> instead of the generic one).  Of course serial, parallel and SCSI
> cameras do not require usbdevfs devices.
>
> I think you are thinking of camera filesystem access via a CardFlash
> or CompactFlash reader.  These allow you to mount the filesystem on
> the flash directly.
>
>  --
> I route, therefore you are.
>
>

> PLUG mailing list
> PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
> http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug

Anthony Schlemmer

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Thu Sep  5 15:34:54 2002

  This one machine boots only into linux, but I have a VFAT partition with a
couple of small apps that I access via dosemu. However, GRUB sees the
partition filesystem and puts the choice in menu.lst:

# grub.conf generated by anaconda
#
# Note that you do not have to rerun grub after making changes to this file
# NOTICE:  You have a /boot partition.  This means that
#          all kernel and initrd paths are relative to /boot/, eg.
#          root (hd0,1)
#          kernel /vmlinuz-version ro root=/dev/hda1
#          initrd /initrd-version.img
#boot=/dev/hda
default=0
timeout=10
splashimage=(hd0,1)/grub/splash.xpm.gz
title linux (2.4.18-3)
	root (hd0,1)
	kernel /vmlinuz-2.4.18-3 ro root=/dev/hda1
	initrd /initrd-2.4.18-3.img
title DOS
	rootnoverify (hd0,9)
	chainloader +1

  I learned the hard way that I cannot just comment out the line that reads,
"title DOS", for that prevents the system from booting. Of course, that
makes sense when I look at the file, for GRUB is trying to use a chain
loader with linux and gets terribly confused. That makes two of us.

  Anyway, I want to remove all mention of the DOS filesystem and the
splashimage. I read a rather comprehensive web page on GRUB and the GRUB
info pages without seeing explicit confirmation that just removing them will
be OK. Implicit confirmation, but I don't want to put the system into a
potentially unstable state if I need to reboot.

  So, can I just remove the last three lines and the one that starts,
'splashimage=...'?

Thanks,

Rich




From creswick at cs.orst.edu  Thu Sep  5 19:43:35 2002
From: creswick at cs.orst.edu (Rogan Creswick)

Subject: [PLUG] Network card problem
In-Reply-To: <003501c25538$b9947900$8701a8c0@barkingcorndog>
References: <000e01c25532$5eabd340$8701a8c0@barkingcorndog> <1031269850.14011.26007.camel@dereklinux> <003501c25538$b9947900$8701a8c0@barkingcorndog>
Message-ID: <20020906024335.GA24519@silver.CS.ORST.EDU>

Another few ideas:

1) Test the port on the hub, either with another computer, or put a
crossover cable into the port in question, and a good port on the same hub
(a standard cable will work if you have an uplink port that you know works).

2) Try a different pci slot. You mentioned that you removed the card and put
it back in again, but it could be a problem with that specific pci slot.

-Rogan

From rsteff at attbi.com  Thu Sep  5 21:10:47 2002
From: rsteff at attbi.com (Richard Steffens)
Date: Thu, 05 Sep 2002 21:10:47 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] parted advice, never mind!
References: <3D76A73E.CCFCBEA2@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <3D782AC7.32CA8C3B@attbi.com>

Richard Steffens wrote:

>From reading the thread from Rich last week about parted, I got the idea
that it was something I shouldn't try without running it by someone who
"knows what they're doing." Well, I decided to try it myself, anyway. It
worked the first time. The directions at:

http://www.gnu.org/manual/parted-1.6.1/html_node/parted_32.html

were mostly clear. I guessed that when they said the filesystems
shouldn't be active that I should be working at run level 1 and that I
should umount the systems on who's partitions I wanted to work. After I
was done shrinking /home, and growing /usr, I had to edit /etc/fstab.
Guess where the editors are kept! /usr, which of course, was no longer
available. There's probably a better way, but I simply used cat to
reconstruct fstab. I kept a copy of the old one, displayed it for
reference, and ran "cat > fstab" to create a new one. (If I ever have to
do this again, I'll remember to create the new fstab before I start
parted, since I'll have planned it thoroughly enough to know what fstab
should look like before I start.)

When I rebooted, every thing looked just fine! While I managed this one
on my own, I want to thank this list for all the help over the last few
days, that gave me the confidence to try something "dangerous." 

--

Dick Steffens
