These are some of the tools I know when troubleshooting pci issues.

	lspci

	cat /proc/pci

	dmesg

	scanpci

Also, some bioses will display a listing of pci based devices and their 
irq's at the tail end of the "post" sequence and just before the os loads 
the bootloader.

> So...How do I find out what is conflicting, which IRQ I can use, and how
> to change IRQ settings?

More often than not, linux just uses the IRQ that the BIOS assigned to
the card.  The BIOS should display the IRQ assignments at the end of the
POST cycle.  The easiest way (and often the only way) to change the IRQ
is to stuff the card into another PCI slot.  Check your motherboard
manual for a list of the IRQ's that are shared.

Derek




From russj at dimstar.net  Fri Sep  6 09:50:23 2002
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: Fri, 06 Sep 2002 09:50:23 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Network card problem
References: <000e01c25532$5eabd340$8701a8c0@barkingcorndog> 	<20020905162159.G11458@dalsemi.com> <1031305931.574.23.camel@flyingpenguin>
Message-ID: <3D78DCCF.6020109@dimstar.net>

Joshua Jacob Zeckser wrote:

>eth0: NatSemi DP8381[56] at 0xd48a5000, 00:a0:cc:a2:97:e1, IRQ 10.
>eth0: Too much work at interrupt, status=0xd9000010.
>eth0: Too much work at interrupt, status=0xd9000038.
>eth0: increased Tx theshold (that isn't a typo), txcfg 0x10f0103e.
>eth0: PCI error 0x800000
>
>Those are all the messages with 'eth0'.
>The only other message with a reference to 'IRQ 10' is:
>PCI: Found IRQ 10 for device 00:12.0
>
>So...How do I find out what is conflicting, which IRQ I can use, and how
>to change IRQ settings?
>
That's not an interupt issue. Changing the IRQ the cards on will simply 
change the message. The issue appears to be the module not being able to 
keep up with the traffic the nic is sending to it.

I've had the same issue with Intel EEPRO 10/100 cards. I found out the 
module has a problem with high bandwidth levels. Unfortunately, the 
"high bandwidth level" they were talking about was able to be reach on a 
10 mbit segment of my network.

I tried increasing the tx and rx buffers, which resolved the problem for 
a short time. Eventually, traffic increased (mostly broadcasts from 
Winblows boxes). The way I fixed it finally, was to use a different 
network card.

I use Netgeat FA310s in my linux boxes. I believe Netgear has 
discontinued that model.

I know that's a different chipset (tulip, I think) than your FA312.

Another alternative would be to see if a newer kernel has fixes for your 
NIC module.

From karlheg at hegbloom.net  Fri Sep  6 12:23:08 2002
From: karlheg at hegbloom.net (Karl M. Hegbloom)
Date: 06 Sep 2002 12:23:08 -0700
Subject: Fwd: Re: [PLUG] Debian Power Down doesn't
In-Reply-To: <20020902231733.D81752EE7E@einstein.seansdomain.org>
References: <20020902231733.D81752EE7E@einstein.seansdomain.org>
Message-ID: <87k7lyylb7.fsf@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>

Sean Whitney <sean at fork.com> writes:

> Yes but I should have said
>  
> 
> cp /boot/config /usr/src/linux/.config

On a Debian GNU/Linux system, it will be named:

 "/boot/config-$(uname -r)"

The Debian packaged kernel source is always renamed also, so that when
you unpack it, it creates:

 "kernel-source-$VERSION.$PATCHLEVEL.$SUBLEVEL/"

... rather than "linux/".  Has anyone ever untarred a new kernel
source right over the top of the old, by mistake?  The linux headers
that software is compiled against are shipped with libc-dev, NOT
symlinked to "/usr/src/linux/include".  If there was need to have that
symlink, that would imply that the software has a tight dependancy on
the particular kernel version it was built against.  This implies that
upgrading the kernel requires rebuilding that software.  There are few
programs for which this is actually true, and that is certainly by
design.  (iptables is one, IF you have applied any of the POM patches)

> The dot in .config is significant.  Anyone know why this file is
> .config and not config?????

"ls" hides files whos names begin with "." by default, unless you
specify the "-a" switch.  Whoever named that file thought it should
normally be "hidden".

From 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com  Fri Sep  6 12:48:04 2002
From: 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com (Steve Bonds)
Date: Fri, 6 Sep 2002 12:48:04 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] vmware-2.x with 2.4.x kernel
Message-ID: <994876195.1031341687090.JavaMail.root@monkey>

On Fri, 6 Sep 2002, Rich Shepard rshepard at appl-ecosys.com wrote:

>   Is anyone here running vmware-2.x with a 2.4.x kernel? I'm wondering if I
> must upgrade to vmware-3.x just to have it run with the 2.4.19 kernel. I
> certainly don't need the USB, XP and other "features" to run my two, legacy
> apps now and then.

Rich:

Here's the patch vs. the current version of the VMWare module sources
found at http://www.vmware.com/download/modules/modules_ws.html#204.

You also need to have the linux kernel source installed.  There is
probably a way to work around this requirement, but since I almost always
have the source there anyhow, I didn't spend any time figuring out how.

Getting to the source can be tricky.  Untar/gzip the
"VMwareKernelModules-2.0.4-1401.tar.gz" file and look in
vmware-modules/lib/modules/source/ for three tar files.

Untar those three files and they'll create the directories:

vmmon-only
vmnet-only
vmppuser-only

Copy the patch below into your current directory (one level above those 
three new directories) and apply it.

For example:
$ patch -p0 < vmware-patch

Hand-patch the Makefiles to fix the line:

HEADER_DIR = /lib/modules/2.4.9-21/build/include/

to match the proper location for your kernel revision.

Run "make" in the three directories to test that everything is working OK.  
I get lots of warnings like:

warning: #warning linux/malloc.h is deprecated, use linux/slab.h instead.

I plan to ignore these until it breaks.  ;-)

After the "make" works, do a "make clean".

Now, we need to overwrite those tar files.  Just re-tar the appropriate
directory into the tar file of the correct name.  Locate those same tar
files on your system (usually /usr/lib/vmware, but I don't have a VMWare
2.0.4 system here to double check with) and copy these newly tarred files
over the top of them.  The "vmware-config.pl" script is hardcoded to
always use these files when installing kernel modules, so they have to
keep the same names.

Once you've installed the tar files, run "vmware-config" and let it build
the modules.  Hope they work.  ;-)

  -- Steve

PS: This patch was based on work done by someone else I found about two
years ago via Google.  I have no idea who it was now and have since added
my own changes.

From rsteff at attbi.com  Fri Sep  6 12:52:55 2002
From: rsteff at attbi.com (Richard Steffens)
Date: Fri, 06 Sep 2002 12:52:55 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Debian auto logout?
Message-ID: <3D790797.420933BE@attbi.com>

for some period of time? Last night, I started apt-get install cupsys

From derek at infotects.com  Fri Sep  6 14:33:48 2002
From: derek at infotects.com (Derek Loree)
Date: 06 Sep 2002 14:33:48 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Debian auto logout?
In-Reply-To: <3D790797.420933BE@attbi.com>
References: <3D790797.420933BE@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <1031348029.14011.26035.camel@dereklinux>

On Fri, 2002-09-06 at 12:52, Richard Steffens wrote:
> Does Debian have a feature that logs out a user who had been inactive
> for some period of time? Last night, I started apt-get install cupsys
> and let it run overnight. I found a login screen this morning. I logged
> in and found that cups is running. I opened the documentation via
> http://localhost.... and started reading. I had to go out for a few
> hours. When I came back, I found another login screen.

I've never had a debian box automatically logout a user.  I'm pretty
sure you would have to purposely implement such a feature.

If you have a GUI login manager (xdm, gdm or kdm), then after your
X-server crashes (for whatever reason), it will respawn and give you the
login prompt, making it seem like you were logged out (well, I guess you
were, but not because of a set timeout).

I've given up on GUI login managers, they are a real pain if your
X-server has a problem and you just want the thing to stop all
together.  Without a GUI login manager, the X-server crash will dump you
back to the console.  The command startx is easy enough to remember, my
kids can even do it.

HTH

Derek Loree




From creelan at engr.orst.edu  Fri Sep  6 15:44:30 2002
From: creelan at engr.orst.edu (Tyler F. Creelan)
Date: Fri, 6 Sep 2002 15:44:30 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Debian auto logout?
In-Reply-To: <001401c255e9$d8c930c0$02a8a8c0@Jim>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0209061530110.26573-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>

On Fri, 6 Sep 2002, Jim Webb wrote:
> How do I get access to csh/tcsh shells to use this feature?

I don't use csh or tcsh, but "set autologout=10" should work for
example, where 10 is the number of minutes. Under the default tcsh
compilation, this variable is set to 60 minutes for all users, if you find
that annoying "autologout=0" or "unset autologout" should work.

FYI, the document below on csh drawbacks can be worth reading if you
haven't seen it before.

http://www.faqs.org/faqs/unix-faq/shell/csh-whynot/

Tyler

Microsoft is able to claim no more BSODs with XP. ;)

From richard.langis at sun.com  Fri Sep  6 16:23:41 2002
From: richard.langis at sun.com (Richard Langis)
Date: Fri, 06 Sep 2002 16:23:41 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Debian auto logout?
References: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0209061323250.26123-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU> <3D79355F.FBA6AEEC@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <3D7938FD.6090403@sun.com>

You might leave the system on for a while, note the time it was turned 
on and log in.  Leave it running, see if when you get back it's at the 
xdm login prompt.  If so, drop to console mode and check the uptime.  If 
it's LESS than what you'd calculate it to be from your poweron time, 
then it's rebooting, not simply restarting X.

You might also check /var/log with 'ls -lt | head' to get the top 10 
most recently modified files, and start tailing them to see what's going on.

-R

From derek at infotects.com  Fri Sep  6 16:58:10 2002

On Fri, 2002-09-06 at 16:22, Anthony Schlemmer wrote:
> If the default runlevel is set to 5 on a system, if X dies, XDM, KDM or 
> whatever is being used for handling logins automatically restarts. 

Debian only uses the first 2 run levels, any higher ones are just a
duplicate of 2.  The same principle holds though, the login manager will
respawn the X-server if it dies.

> 
> XP is really something but with it rebooting when a serious error occurs 
> Microsoft is able to claim no more BSODs with XP. ;)

This actually started with 2k, the feature can be disabled, which is
handy for figuring out why the damn thing rebooted on its own.  I'd
rather get the BSOD than have it reboot for no apparent reason, usually
in the middle of something important, with no warning _at all_.

I better stop before I really start ranting.

Derek

Richard Langis wrote:

> You might leave the system on for a while, note the time it was turned
> on and log in.  Leave it running, see if when you get back it's at the
> xdm login prompt.  If so, drop to console mode and check the uptime.  If
> it's LESS than what you'd calculate it to be from your poweron time,
> then it's rebooting, not simply restarting X.

While I was reading e-mail on this machine, I noticed a blink on the
screen of the Debian machine. I watched as it changed a few times and
finally settled at an X login. I went to a console, logged in and
checked uptime: 

16:52:26 up 19:59, 1 user, load average: 0.00, 0.00, 0.00

The uptime sounds correct. I had the machine off to install the new USB
board yesterday, plus I booted to Win98SE to install the HP 656c driver
software. So, about 20 hours ago, I booted into Linux.

XFree86.0.log, daemon.log and the directory gdm. some of these files are
not human readable. Here are some of the other ones:

tail messages produces 10 lines that, with the exception of the time,

Sep 6 13:33:38 Avatar -- MARK --

But, the lines just before that are:

Sep 6 15:00:38 Avatar kernel: ide0: reset: success
Sep 6 15:13:13 Avatar -- MARK --

Sep 6 15:24:19 Avatar kernel: ide0: reset: success
Sep 6 13:13:02 Avatar kernel: hda: status timeout: status-0xd0 { Busy }
Sep 6 13:13:02 Avatar kernel: ide0: reset: success
Sep 6 13:33:38 Avatar -- MARK --

The time seems a little odd, but I recall looking at the clock on the
Gnome screen after lunch and seeing a time that was morning. At that
time I ran ntpdate and the clock reset. I'm not sure what went wrong
with the time. When I log in to Windows, I have a similar utility set
the clock using utcnist.colorado.edu, or one of several others the
utility went out and found, so the clock should have been close to
correct. Anyway, that may account for some events occurring later in
time, but earlier in the log. Although, those aren't the correct "wrong"
times. Wierd.

daemon.log also has some of the same messages from gdm and
gnome-name-server plus a couple of others:

cnx[IDL:GNOME/Panel2:1.0] = 0x8055160

cnx[IDL:GNOME/Panel2:1.0] = 0x8055748
Sep 6 15:50:25 Avatar gnome-name-server[2609]: input condition is: 0x10,
exiting

- Restarting :0
Sep 6 16:26:31 Avatar modprobe: modprobe: Can't locate module
char-major-13

- Restarting :0

char-major-13

Looks like gnome, gdm and modprobe don't like something.

From creelan at engr.orst.edu  Fri Sep  6 19:10:15 2002
From: creelan at engr.orst.edu (Tyler F. Creelan)
Date: Fri, 6 Sep 2002 19:10:15 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Debian auto logout?
In-Reply-To: <3D794EA1.B121258F@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0209061849220.26573-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>

On Fri, 6 Sep 2002, Richard Steffens wrote:
> I went to a console, logged in and checked uptime:
>
> 16:52:26 up 19:59, 1 user, load average: 0.00, 0.00, 0.00

I think Richard was suggesting to compare your xserver uptime
to your system uptime... the output above looks like system uptime, which
might not be useful by itself since it wouldn't be affected by restarting
X.

Unfortunately I don't know the canonical method for checking the uptime of
the X server... I suppose you could hunt around for X processes and check
their execution length but some processes would remain running and
some would be respawned during both a crash and a regular logout. Perhaps
the xserver or xfree86 manuals have info on where X keeps activity logs.

HTH,

Tyler

> may find this pretty boring. Hostname can be anything I want like
> web.mydomain.com? And do I have to use a domain that I registered or is
> this just arbitrary? I have also kind of looked ahead in trying to setup
> apache using virtualhost, I believe thats what I need to do, and it talks
> about servername. Is the servername setup with the domain name of my system
> or by the one I have registered? Any clarifications would be
> appreciated.ThxAlexDazed and Confused
>


1. if you want your site accessible to the Internet you need a registered 
domain name

2. You'll need to manage your DNS, most domain name registrars offer this

3. hostname and servername are the name of the server, which can be anything

4. you need virtualhost only for running more than one website

This might help get you started: 
http://www.computerbits.com/archive/2002/0200/schroder0202.html

have fun!

From llywrch at agora.rdrop.com  Fri Sep  6 20:29:02 2002
From: llywrch at agora.rdrop.com (Geoff Burling)
Date: Fri, 6 Sep 2002 20:29:02 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] TeX Configuration Question
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0209062018420.26107-100000@joan.burling.com>

Has anyone here used the command ``texconfig" to make changes in
how dvi or LaTeX handles text?

The reason I ask is that I stumbled across this very useful menu-driven
command for the first time today & spent half an hour playing around
with it.  While I admit I am always learning something new with Linux,
UNIX or computers in general -- I try to learn at least one new thing
in one of these subjects every day -- I'm a little surprised that I
have been working with TeX & its friends for a couple of years now &
never knew this configuration tool existed before today.

I don't know if I missed reading a mention about it in one of the
standard references on TeX, or the documentation on this subject is
so poorly organized that it's easy to miss powerful tools like this
one. If it's the later case, I recommend anyone curious about TeX
& its friends to explore this menu-driven configuration tool. It
simplifies the matter of dealing with LaTeX & dvi settings immensely --
& comes with an embedded FAQ.

Geoff

    Richard> been inactive for some period of time?

Check your process table ("ps wwwauxf | less") and see if there's a
logoutd or something like that running.  Then, have a look at
"/etc/security/time.conf".  "logoutd" is part of the "login" package,
and is apparently no longer present in "unstable" for some reason.
I've never run it, by simply commenting out everything in time.conf.

Subject: [PLUG] Debian auto logout?

	<3D79355F.FBA6AEEC@attbi.com> <3D7938FD.6090403@sun.com>
	<3D794EA1.B121258F@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <87sn0maxip.fsf@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>

>>>>> "Richard" == Richard Steffens <rsteff at attbi.com> writes:

    Richard> Sep 6 16:26:28 Avatar gdm[2535]: gdm_slave_xioerr_handler: Fatal X error - Restarting :0
    Richard> Sep 6 16:26:31 Avatar modprobe: modprobe: Can't locate module char-major-13
    Richard> Sep 6 16:46:33 Avatar gdm[2717]: gdm_slave_xioerr_handler: Fatal X error - Restarting :0
    Richard> Sep 6 16:46:35 Avatar modprobe: modprobe: Can't locate module char-major-13

    Richard> So, it looks like X is restarting, and that's why I get
    Richard> the login screen.

    Richard> Looks like gnome, gdm and modprobe don't like something.

I've been seeing this also on one machine, an older Pentium 200 with
an S3 Trio card (my FreekBox 2.0 testbox).  What X Server is your
machine running?  (I wonder if the bug has been reported yet or not?
We can report it to Debian with the "reportbug" program if not, and
view the list of bug reports at <URL:http://bugs.debian.org/>.)

What device is char-major-13, I wonder?  Perhaps you can configure
"modutils" (/usr/share/doc/modutils) to load it or ignore it, using an
alias directive somewhere in "/etc/modutils/*" (then run
"update-modules" to have it rebuild modules.conf)?

Knowing what that device is may provide a clue as to why the X server
crashed, perhaps?  "gdm" is restarting the X Server and that takes a
few seconds... I suspect that the second log message is from then.  X
is trying to open a device that's not there, and the kernel is trying
to autoload that module.

Ok, I looked in the kernel source "Documentation/devices.txt" file,
and found that char-major-13 (M-x search-forward-regexp for "^ +13 ")
is "input core" -- USB keyboard and mouse.  If you are not using them,
you can say "alias char-major-13 off" someplace in /etc/modutils.  If
you create a separate file to put that in, you'll save a conffile
merge on upgrade.  Don't forget to run "update-modules" (rtfm please).
That will shut up that log message... I don't think it's why your X
Server is crashing though.

The message from "gdm_slave_xioerr_handler" (Can you find it in the
gdm source in less than 5 minutes?  I can.  Want to know how?) is just
telling you that the X Server has crashed and that GDM is restarting
it.  I believe that what is happening is that there is something wrong
with the DPMS codes in that X Server (how do I find this?), and so
every 20 minutes of idle time, it will crash.  Until it is fixed, you
can put:

 /usr/bin/X11/xset -dpms

... into your "/etc/gdm/Init/Default" script as a workaround.
Hopefully that will cause it to never run the code that is crashing.

[Back] [Search Definition]         [Matching words]        [Quit]
       [Select Dictionary]         [Select Match Strategy]

2 definitions found

>From The Free On-line Dictionary of Computing (09 FEB 02)[foldoc]:

BSOD

   Blue Screen of Death



>From Jargon File (4.3.1, 29 Jun 2001)[jargon]:

BSOD /B-S-O-D/ Very common abbreviation for Blue Screen of Death.
   Both spoken and written.



8<------------------------------------------------------------>8

dictd on localhost is most awesome.

On 6 Sep 2002, Chris Emery wrote:

> the simple answer is this, YES.  You can take out the last 3 lines and
> the splash image line with no problems.  The reason it broke when you
> only commented out the title is because the block that went under DOS
> then came under linux, and as you said made it horibly confused.

  Thank you, Chris, for confirming what I read -- and thought I understood.
 
> I've never understood lilo, but never had a problem with grub.  Odd how
> it seems opposit with so many people.  Anyways, have fun.

  When I first installed RH 4.1 I was triple-booting with LILO: linux,
PC-DOS/7 and win95. I had no problems understanding LILO, swapping mbrs
between drives as the Microsoft and IBM OSes needed to be loaded, and so on.
GRUB is functionally similar, but tries too hard -- in my case -- to help.
It assumed that I want to boot DOS because it found that /dev/hda10 was
formatted vfat on a mount point called "/dos7". If it had not made that
assumption I would have been happier.

  I just have problems with machines that think they are smarter than I am.
Sometimes the machine's correct, but when it tries to be as simple as a
light switch I have major issues with it.

  Long ago I learned to never assume -- anything about anyone. I wish that
linux installers followed the same philosophy.

Rich




From rsteff at attbi.com  Sat Sep  7 08:13:29 2002
From: rsteff at attbi.com (Richard Steffens)

"Karl M. Hegbloom" wrote:

> Check your process table ("ps wwwauxf | less") and see if there's a
> logoutd or something like that running. 

Avatar:/var/log# ps wwwauxf | grep logoutd
root      3970  0.0  0.7  1332  424 tty1     S    08:09     0:00 \_ grep
logoutd

I presume that means that the only occurrence of logoutd was in the

> to any CUPS conf files.

--- /etc/samba/smb.conf ---

[global]
--snip--
         printing = cups
         printcap name = /etc/printcap

[printers]
         path = /tmp
         guest ok = Yes
         printable = Yes
         browseable = no
         create mode = 0700

This is all that is printer-related in my smb.conf, though I believe the
printcap reference is superfluous w/ CUPS.

My cupsd.conf is near stock, as it should listen on localhost by default.

One thing that was faily maddening was that PCL Windows drivers for the
printers wouldn't work until the "application/octet-stream" lines were
uncommented in both /etc/cups/mime.convs and /etc/cups/mime.types.

References: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0209061323250.26123-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU> <200209061622.47178.aschlemm@attbi.com> <87ofbaaxf1.fsf@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>
Message-ID: <200209070928.32353.aschlemm@attbi.com>

I don't run X from the inittab either. I only have my inittab file 
tweaked so the default runlevel is 5 which starts "kdm" on my system 
when it boots up. I have S and K symbolic links in a 
"/etc/init.d/rc5.d" directory for an "xdm" init script. 

I guess I should have been more clear in that I don't think the X 
display manager goes away when X starts and that it is responsible for 
restarting X when X dies or is killed. It is my understanding that XDM 
is usually run at runlevel 5 although this could certainly be changed 
if an Snn symbolic links is placed in a different "rcN.d" directory 
besides rc5.d.

Tony 

On Saturday 07 September 2002 03:47 am, Karl M. Hegbloom wrote:
> >>>>> "Anthony" == Anthony Schlemmer <aschlemm at attbi.com> writes:
>
>     Anthony> If the default runlevel is set to 5 on a system, if X
>     Anthony> dies, XDM, KDM or whatever is being used for handling
>     Anthony> logins automatically restarts.
>
> Not on a Debian GNU system.  We don't run the X display manager via
> the inittab like that; it's started and stopped by a normal init.d
> script, at S99 and K01.

  As most of you know, I've been trying to move my two workstations from RH
6.2 to 7.3 for the past week+, and the process is far from done. Can't
print, haven't tried other apps for functionality, but the critical issue of
the moment is the network: RPC and nfs keep failing.

  I was trying to run a full backup of the current state of the network,
imperfect as it is, when BRU becaome comatose ("uniterruptable sleep" it's
called in ps) when it tried to access /mnt/usr2 which is nfs-exported from
machine 'caddis' and mounted on machine 'salmo'. So, I had to trace this
problem back to its source.

  Could not ping caddis: network unreachable. When I ssh'd to caddis (which
I could do), logged in and su'd to root, I discovered that bringing nfs down
failed because it was not up. Checking the monitor on that machine directly,
I saw that both RPC and nfs were returning errors. To remedy this, I
restarted portmap, network and nfs on both machines. We're up and running
again.

  The problem, and why I'm writing to all you gurus for help, is that this
is the third -- or fourth -- time this has happened in the past three days.
I had these problems when 'caddis' had RH 6.1 and 'salmo' had 5.2 installed.
Upgrading 'salmo' to 6.1 resolved that problem. But now, both boxes have 7.3
on them. I would _very_ much like to resolve this problem so I can focus on
the long list of remaining problems (such as printing).

  Both boxes have /usr/sbin/rpc.nfsd of 3804 bytes with a creation date of
April 9. One has a time stamp of 08:14, the other 11:14. I ascribe this to
time differences on these two machines. Yes, xntp is another thing to get
going.

  Thoughts, suggestions, and solutions solicited.

Thanks,

Rich

Carla,

I haven't shared one with samba, but I think it shouldn't be too hard. I 
would try just putting the db on the linux box and setting the samba 
share for the directory its in then see what happens. Or another way 
might be to set a small Fat32 partition on the linux box to hold the DB 
and sharing that. The biggest problem I could see would be if multiple 
people were accessing the db at one time. I have had problems wih 
that even on Windows platforms.


Good Luck and let us know what happens.

RAy

>From ps ax:

 PID TTY STAT	TIME COMMAND

3973 ?	 R<	1:08 /usr/bin/X11/X :0 -deferglyphs 16 -nolisten tcp vt7

> What device is char-major-13, I wonder?

> Ok, I looked in the kernel source "Documentation/devices.txt" file,

The source I downloaded is 2.4.18. I don't have any reference to USB in
the 13 char Input core section, just First and Second joystick, First
and Second mouse, Unified mouse, and First and Second event queue.

> The message from "gdm_slave_xioerr_handler" (Can you find it in the
> gdm source in less than 5 minutes?  I can.  Want to know how?)

(No, but I would like to know how.)

> is just
> telling you that the X Server has crashed and that GDM is restarting
> it.  I believe that what is happening is that there is something wrong
> with the DPMS codes in that X Server (how do I find this?), and so
> every 20 minutes of idle time, it will crash.  Until it is fixed, you
> can put:
> 
>  /usr/bin/X11/xset -dpms
> 
> ... into your "/etc/gdm/Init/Default" script as a workaround.
> Hopefully that will cause it to never run the code that is crashing.

Well, first I have to figure out what DPMS is. It's not something man or
info or apropos know anything about. Since google is my friend, I ran
the search, dpms site:debian.org, and found way too many hits. But I
scanned the first couple of pages and found:

Re: X crashes after 20 minutes inactivity
http://lists.debian.org/debian-laptop/2002/debian-laptop-200202/msg00309.html

which says:

---------------------------
> There's an Option "DPMS" line in the Monitor section of Xf86config-4, how
> can I turn it off? (Just uncommenting it didn't help.)

Use the following line:

Option	"DPMS" "off"
---------------------------

>From this, I conclude that DPMS has something to do with screen saving.

I also find that my Xf86config-4 file has an entry in the "Monitor"
section that says Option "DPMS".

I added "off" to that line, logged out, switched to a text console,
logged in as root, ran telinit 1, watched things stop, got the line to
enter maintenance mode or <ctrl>-D to start up normally, hit <ctrl>-D,
watched things start, found myself at the X login screen, and logged in
at 10:10 am. Now, I'll go away for 20 minutes and see what happens...

It's now 10:20, and the screen just went blank. I'm going to wait
another 10 minutes and see what else happens.

It's now 10:36. I slid the mouse and found that I was still logged in.
Maybe this fixed things. Only time will tell. I'll leave the system
logged in over lunch time and see what happens.

>>>>> "Rich" == Rich Shepard <rshepard at appl-ecosys.com> writes:

Rich>   When I first installed RH 4.1 I was triple-booting with LILO:
Rich> linux, PC-DOS/7 and win95. I had no problems understanding LILO,
Rich> swapping mbrs between drives as the Microsoft and IBM OSes
Rich> needed to be loaded, and so on.  GRUB is functionally similar,
Rich> but tries too hard -- in my case -- to help.  It assumed that I
Rich> want to boot DOS because it found that /dev/hda10 was formatted
Rich> vfat on a mount point called "/dos7". If it had not made that
Rich> assumption I would have been happier.

Just to clarify, I do not think GRUB made that assumption.  I think
RH's packaging of GRUB made that assumption.  When I installed GRUB
(both on Debian and from source) I didn't find it making any
assumptions.  I wrote the menu.lst file by hand, which wasn't too
difficult with 30 minutes of reading about how GRUB works and some
experimenting from the very handy interactive CLI that GRUB provides.
So please do _not_ fault GRUB for the sins of the packager.

Russell Evans said:
> Why did you choose to use windows shares instead of using IPP, technical
> issues, user issues, or political?

Mostly because it fit the paradigm we had been working from on our old
Netware setup.

I'd like to experiment more with the "CUPS as network Postscript RIP"
model (http://us4.samba.org/samba/ftp/docs/htmldocs/cups.html), so we
could use the generic Adobe Postscript drivers everywhere. Mix that with
the [print$] driver downloading, and Windows users can just
"point-'n-print".

From llywrch at agora.rdrop.com  Sat Sep  7 12:58:08 2002
From: llywrch at agora.rdrop.com (Geoff Burling)
Date: Sat, 7 Sep 2002 12:58:08 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] TeX special character
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0209071014480.30596-100000@linux.sourballs.org>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0209071253340.26107-100000@joan.burling.com>

On Sat, 7 Sep 2002, David Fleck wrote:

> Here's one that ought to be brain-dead simple - what's the special char in
> TeX/LaTeX for ? (the degree symbol)?  I can't find a way to do this in
> maths mode or standard mode, and I've already looked through Lamport and
> the ~ 100 pages of documentation I've printed off...
>
I agree, this ought to be brain-dead simple. Only because I found where
the documentation for the TeX/LaTeX packages are hiding last night (hint:
try the directory described in Karl's email on your own computer), was I
able to track down the answer. Use the SIunits package thus:

\usepackage SIunits
\degree

As a note, I'm surprised that this isn't included in the better known
AMS-TeX package. That package includes symbols, glyphs & fonts for an
unbelievable amount of stuff!

Geoff

I'm sorry you got tangled up in this.  The mail you're getting that looks 
like it's from SpamCop is a forgery.  The whole thing is a hoax.  We have a 
revenge seeking spammer who is trying his best to cause trouble for us by 
causing trouble for you.  This is the third attack on us recently.  For the 
current run, the originating IP appears to be 64.70.191.50  You may be able 
to block the traffic on that basis.

SpamCop is an anti-spam reporting service that sends something like 100,000 
complaints a day to spammer hosts worldwide, which has made this particular 
spammer very angry.  However, we only send complaints about specific 
messages, not general indictments of a system, or anything like that.

Actual SpamCop complaints would come from an address like 
12345678 at reports.spamcop.net.  Each complaint has a unique numbered 
address.  Addresses such as postmaster, webmaster, hostmaster, abuse, 
support, etc are not in use on our system.  Obviously we send bounce 
notices and stuff like that, but generally not anything else.

You can see a sample SpamCop complaint 
here:  http://spamcop.net/fom-serve/cache/338.html

You can read the latest about the forgery 
here:  http://www.julianhaight.com/forgery.shtml

From alan at clueserver.org  Sat Sep  7 09:54:13 2002
From: alan at clueserver.org (alan)
Date: Sat, 7 Sep 2002 09:54:13 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Access and Samba
In-Reply-To: <200209080019.g880Jfl24370@smtp.easystreet.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0209070945550.14553-100000@ebersisk.clueserver.org>

On Sat, 7 Sep 2002, Carla Schroder wrote:

> In theory it sounds reasonable- but this is Access we're dealing with. It's 
> their customer order database, so no funky solutions permitted! 
> 
> I found there are utilities to convert .mdb to PostgreSQL and mySQL, that 
> sounds way better to me. Use Access only as a front-end on the client PCs.

Access databases should never be shared for writing.  They do not have any 
file locking to speak of.  They were designed for single user access, not 
multi-user access. It will work, but you can lose records and have 
problems with database corruption.

Samba will handle filesharing as well or better than Windows will, as long 
as you can deal with the braindead way that the Win95/98 boxes handle 
passwords.  Also, do not expect any file security if you share it and 
*never* allow access outside the firewall.  (Win 95/98 uses incredibly bad 
passwords.  It also exposes all sorts of information about the system, 
including MAC address.)

> 
> Carla
> 
> 
> On Saturday 07 September 2002 09:51 am, you wrote:
> > Carla,
> >
> > I haven't shared one with samba, but I think it shouldn't be too hard. I
> > would try just putting the db on the linux box and setting the samba
> > share for the directory its in then see what happens. Or another way
> > might be to set a small Fat32 partition on the linux box to hold the DB
> > and sharing that. The biggest problem I could see would be if multiple
> > people were accessing the db at one time. I have had problems wih

From todd.sarratt at attbi.com  Sat Sep  7 18:56:18 2002
From: todd.sarratt at attbi.com (todd.sarratt)

Subject: [PLUG] Sparc 20 Console
Message-ID: <002801c256da$ec92d420$1600a8c0@vncvr1.wa.home.com>

Caveat : I am a computer idiot.  But I can troubleshoot the bejesus out of a T1.

Got me a Sparc 20 with no keyboard / monitor / etc.  It's got a CD-ROM.  I bought it out of the back of a van, or something.

Looking at the back on the CPU (from left to right) there's a power switch and some power connections.  A stamp of serial numbers .  

Then the top row has a blank space with a filler plate.  Next slot has what looks like a parallel port with a symbol over it that's a diamond with a line coming out of the east side (or 0 deg on a cartesian plane etc.)  Next to that is a RJ-45 plug labelled TP <...> with the dots being vertically centered.  Next slot is empty with a filler plate.

Middle row has three empty slots, one is covered with a plate and the other two are gaping dust sucking holes.

Bottom row has a funky port with pins and what look almost like small RCA connectors.  That's the video?  Labelled |O|
Next to that is a 25 pin female serial connector labelled A/B.  Next to that is a circular 8 pin female labelled | |  | |.  
2nd card slot has two female ports stacked atop each other, they're thin like USB ports but with 30 or so square holes each.  Labelled // / <...>  Next port is an RJ45 labelled <...>
Third slot looks like another parallel port and has that diamond with a line label.  Next to that are 4 headphone jack type connections.

(P.S.  Taking donations for a digital camera.)

So the real meat here : I want to console into the beast.

How do I console into it?  I got a Windows box which I figure I'll run Hyperterm or something off COM1 and hook a 9 pin female connector into the port labelled |O|O| A/1.  The other end of the cable goes into... the A/B slot on the Sparc?  Straight serial or null modem?  

I spent about an hour searching through Google newsgroups and finding conflicting or unhelpful info.

Thanks!
Todd

From alan at clueserver.org  Sat Sep  7 10:47:40 2002
From: alan at clueserver.org (alan)
Date: Sat, 7 Sep 2002 10:47:40 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Sparc 20 Console
In-Reply-To: <002801c256da$ec92d420$1600a8c0@vncvr1.wa.home.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0209071043230.15035-100000@ebersisk.clueserver.org>

You will need a couple of things to get that working.

A dumb terminal with keyboard should be enough to get it bootable.  The 
serial port is a db25.  You may need a null modem box to get the dumb 
terminal to talk to the Sparc. 

As for getting past the login prompt...  There are a couple of ways to 
hack a Sparc system. The easiest is to mount the drive under a properly 
configed Linux box and edit the /etc/passwd file.

From beattie at beattie-home.net  Sat Sep  7 19:16:55 2002
From: beattie at beattie-home.net (Brian Beattie)
Date: 07 Sep 2002 19:16:55 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Setting permissions for windows partition
In-Reply-To: <3D7A7A98.F655955F@attbi.com>
References: <3D7A7A98.F655955F@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <1031451416.3987.5.camel@coyote>

Well since fat filesystems (msdos and vfat) do not have a place in the
filesystem to store user name or id, you can't change it.  The is
however a mount option uid= and gid= which should do what you want.

Mount options for fat
       (Note: fat is not a separate filesystem, but a common part
       of the msdos, umsdos and vfat filesystems.)

...

       uid=value and gid=value
              Set the owner and group of all files. (Default: the
              uid and gid of the current process.)

Null modem cable.  Minicom does fine or any terminal emulator you like.  You 
may need to remove the video card as Solaris will set up the serial port 
automagically if there is not video card detected.  If it sees the video card 
it will use it.  With or without a monitor hooked up.

what you have before you:

they have left online -- including documentation on OpenProm.)

From heinlein at attbi.com  Sun Sep  8 07:15:20 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Sun, 8 Sep 2002 07:15:20 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Sparc 20 Console
In-Reply-To: <002801c256da$ec92d420$1600a8c0@vncvr1.wa.home.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0209080709050.8256-100000@pecos.madboa.com>

On Sat, 7 Sep 2002, todd.sarratt wrote:

> Got me a Sparc 20 with no keyboard / monitor / etc.  It's got a
> CD-ROM.  I bought it out of the back of a van, or something.

...

> So the real meat here : I want to console into the beast.
> 
> How do I console into it?  I got a Windows box which I figure I'll
> run Hyperterm or something off COM1 and hook a 9 pin female
> connector into the port labelled |O|O| A/1.  The other end of the
> cable goes into... the A/B slot on the Sparc?  Straight serial or
> null modem?

If a SPARC's prom doesn't find a local console (i.e., there's no 
keyboard and/or framebuffer), it'll default to sending console output 
to the first serial port.

Get yourself a crossover serial cable (aka null modem) and connect a 
serial port on your PC to the back of the 20.

You can use minicom for the console sessions, but IMO conserver 
(http://www.conserver.com/) is a far better option: it'll log your 
sessions and it handles "breaks" quite well. It's simple to compile on 
any Linux host; if you've got an RPM-based system, I've written a 
.spec file you can use to build your own package:

  http://www.madboa.com/geek/specs/conserver.spec.txt

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

Brian Beattie wrote:
 
> Well since fat filesystems (msdos and vfat) do not have a place in the
> filesystem to store user name or id, you can't change it.  The is
> however a mount option uid= and gid= which should do what you want.
> 
> Mount options for fat
>        (Note: fat is not a separate filesystem, but a common part
>        of the msdos, umsdos and vfat filesystems.)
> 
> ...
> 
>        uid=value and gid=value
>               Set the owner and group of all files. (Default: the
>               uid and gid of the current process.)

Thanks for the information.

First, I tried Keith's suggestion (modified with /mnt/windows, instead
of /mnt/hda):

> /dev/hda1   /mnt/windows   vfat  noauto,user 0 0

I umounted /mnt/windows while still su'd. Then I returned to being an
ordinary user, and successfully mounted /mnt/windows, and edited a file
in that system.

Next, after su'ing I tried changing the entry to:

/dev/hda1       /mnt/windows    vfat  
uid=rsteff,gid=rsteff                0	0

and umounted /mnt/windows.

But, when I returned to being rsteff instead of root, and tried to mount
/mnt/windows, I got the message:

mount: only root can mount dev/hda1 on /mnt/windows

So, did I misunderstandd your suggestion, or am I missing something
else?

  Ah, ha! We went through the same thing here. Two sets of downloaded ISOs,
and a last-minute dash to OfficeDepot to buy and "official boxed set" and
the same problem. We also had problems with the install hanging on another
workstation when it became time to install the chkconfig package.

  We resolved it by disconnecting the SCSI buses. Then the 7.3 installer saw
the ATAPI drive for all the cdroms it needed to read. There must be a bug
with the 7.3 installer.

From creswick at cs.orst.edu  Sun Sep  8 13:24:09 2002
From: creswick at cs.orst.edu (Rogan Creswick)
Date: Sun, 8 Sep 2002 13:24:09 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Setting permissions for windows partition
In-Reply-To: <3D7B7429.45748378@attbi.com>
References: <3D7A7A98.F655955F@attbi.com> <1031451416.3987.5.camel@coyote> <3D7B7429.45748378@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <20020908202409.GA26203@silver.CS.ORST.EDU>

> First, I tried Keith's suggestion (modified with /mnt/windows, instead
> of /mnt/hda):
> 
> > /dev/hda1   /mnt/windows   vfat  noauto,user 0 0
> 

The "user" param above means that any user can mount the filesystem, not
just root.

> I umounted /mnt/windows while still su'd. Then I returned to being an
> ordinary user, and successfully mounted /mnt/windows, and edited a file
> in that system.
> 
> Next, after su'ing I tried changing the entry to:
> 
> /dev/hda1       /mnt/windows    vfat  
> uid=rsteff,gid=rsteff                0	0
> 
> and umounted /mnt/windows.
> 
> But, when I returned to being rsteff instead of root, and tried to mount
> /mnt/windows, I got the message:
> 
> mount: only root can mount dev/hda1 on /mnt/windows
> 
> So, did I misunderstandd your suggestion, or am I missing something
> else?

Change the above to:
/dev/hda1   /mnt/windows  vfat  user,uid=rsteff,gid=rsteff  0 0

and it should work as you expect.

-Rogan

> 
> -- 
> Regards,

From deathfox at moochercrew.org  Sun Sep  8 13:49:15 2002
From: deathfox at moochercrew.org (Chris Emery)
Date: 08 Sep 2002 13:49:15 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Getting to runlevel 1 with GRUB
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0209081608140.1335-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0209081608140.1335-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <1031518155.4020.20.camel@moochercrew.org>

If you are unable to boot and edit the grub menu list, the easiest/best
way to do it is to type "e" on the line that you want to edit, and then
edit the kernel line so that it has single at the end of it.  Then you
just boot (by hitting b I think), and you should be set.

Hope this helps.
Chris

the kernel, including such things as hdd=ide-scsi (for atapi emulation)

From AthlonRob at data.lm.ro  Sun Sep  8 18:05:08 2002
From: AthlonRob at data.lm.ro (AthlonRob)
Date: 08 Sep 2002 18:05:08 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] USB
In-Reply-To: <3D7BEE99.1C4BA574@attbi.com>
References: <3D7BEE99.1C4BA574@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <1031533509.13640.13.camel@duron>

On Sun, 2002-09-08 at 17:43, Richard Steffens wrote:
> Is there a utility to test for the presence of USB adapters? I installed
> Debian with the motherboard USB ports enabled. They turn out to be less
> than reliable. I've had an IBM USB video camera work on one in Windows,
> but I didn't get my HP 656c working on it. I disabled the motherboard
> USB ports and installed a USB2 card. I successfully installed the HP
> 656c driver in Windows, so I know the hardware works.
<snip>
> I've tried reading the documentation in
> /usr/src/kernel-source-2.4.18/Documentation/usb. In the file
> proc_usb_info.txt, it talks about /proc/bus/usb. I have only a
> /proc/bus/pci.

You need the USB Proc Filesystem support compiled in to your kernel for
a /proc/bus/usb to appear.  I don't know if it appears there, however,
without a USB controller module loaded up.

Did you build the kernel yourself?  If so, did you include USB Proc
Filesystem support?  If not, I'm pretty sure that one requires a
recompile and reboot.

lspci should tell you what kind of USB controller you have (OHCI, UHCI,
or whatever the USB2.0 one is named) from which you should be able to
load the proper module... then look in /proc/bus/ and see if there's a
usb entry.  If not, you don't have USB Proc support and will either have
to guess (live without it) or rebuild your kernel.

Perhaps a debian guru will have better answers for you... but I'll bet
you missed USB Proc support (I know I did).  :-)

-- 
Rob

from."
 - Andrew S. Tanenbaum

From buchholz at easystreet.com  Sun Sep  8 19:53:01 2002
From: buchholz at easystreet.com (Don Buchholz)
Date: Sun, 08 Sep 2002 19:53:01 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Email forwarding
References: <LKELJJFGLNIKHFIAPIJGEEFOCEAA.bmdimaculangan@bhpi.com.ph>
Message-ID: <3D7C0D0D.1060506@easystreet.com>

Billy M Dimaculangan wrote:
> Anyone who could tell me how to automatically forward local users mail to an
> external mail, I think this has something to do with aliases...
> 
> Hope someone will help me with this...
> 
> ---
> bmd
> 

This can be done via /etc/aliases if you want the system admin
to handle the job.  Or it can be done in the $HOME/.forward file
for a particular user if the user is self-sufficient.

1) In your /etc/aliases file, create a new line with the
    username in the first column, and the address to forward
    in the second column (whitepace separates columns)

     username   new at address.out

    You might need to run (as 'root') the "newaliases" command to
    rebuild the aliases database.


2) In the $HOME/.forward file, just put the new address (and
    nothing else).

From bmdimaculangan at bhpi.com.ph  Sun Sep  8 20:26:12 2002

-----Original Message-----
From: plug-admin at lists.pdxlinux.org [mailto:plug-admin at lists.pdxlinux.org]On
Behalf Of Don Buchholz
Sent: Monday, September 09, 2002 10:53 AM
To: plug at lists.pdxlinux.org
Subject: Re: [PLUG] Email forwarding

Billy M Dimaculangan wrote:
> Anyone who could tell me how to automatically forward local users mail to
an
> external mail, I think this has something to do with aliases...
>
> Hope someone will help me with this...
>
> ---
> bmd
>

This can be done via /etc/aliases if you want the system admin
to handle the job.  Or it can be done in the $HOME/.forward file
for a particular user if the user is self-sufficient.

1) In your /etc/aliases file, create a new line with the
    username in the first column, and the address to forward
    in the second column (whitepace separates columns)

     username   new at address.out

    You might need to run (as 'root') the "newaliases" command to
    rebuild the aliases database.


2) In the $HOME/.forward file, just put the new address (and
    nothing else).

From griffint at pobox.com  Sun Sep  8 21:01:57 2002
From: griffint at pobox.com (Terry Griffin)
Date: Sun, 8 Sep 2002 21:01:57 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Email forwarding
In-Reply-To: <3D7C0D0D.1060506@easystreet.com>
References: <LKELJJFGLNIKHFIAPIJGEEFOCEAA.bmdimaculangan@bhpi.com.ph> <3D7C0D0D.1060506@easystreet.com>
Message-ID: <200209082101.57866.griffint@pobox.com>

On Sunday 08 September 2002 07:53 pm, Don Buchholz wrote:
> Billy M Dimaculangan wrote:
> > Anyone who could tell me how to automatically forward local users mail to
> > an external mail, I think this has something to do with aliases...
> >
> > Hope someone will help me with this...
> >
> > ---
> > bmd
>
> This can be done via /etc/aliases if you want the system admin
> to handle the job.  Or it can be done in the $HOME/.forward file
> for a particular user if the user is self-sufficient.
>
> 1) In your /etc/aliases file, create a new line with the
>     username in the first column, and the address to forward
>     in the second column (whitepace separates columns)
>
>      username   new at address.out
>
>     You might need to run (as 'root') the "newaliases" command to
>     rebuild the aliases database.
>
>
> 2) In the $HOME/.forward file, just put the new address (and
>     nothing else).
>

I've started using $HOME/.procmailrc instead when I set up
forwarding for a user. It has the benefit of doing the forwarding
*after* the incoming message has been processed by delivery agent
spam filter (procmail in my case). With /etc/aliases or $HOME/.forward,
the messages zips right back out again without ever being processed
by the local delivery agent. (DNS blacklists and other pre-delivery
filtering gets used either way.) A simple forwarding-only
$HOME/.procmailrc looks like this:

	:0
	! user at some-domain.com

Terry




From griffint at pobox.com  Sun Sep  8 21:11:35 2002
From: griffint at pobox.com (Terry Griffin)
Date: Sun, 8 Sep 2002 21:11:35 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Email forwarding

> I another thing, how can I leave a copy of the mail in our server before
> forwarding the mail to an external address. Any idea?
>
> Thanks again!
>

With /etc/aliases:

	username : user at some-domain.com, username

With $HOME/.forward:

	user at some-domain.com, \username

With $HOME/.procmailrc:

	:0 c
	user at some-domain.com

Terry

Bill> What kernel? Debian?

Compiled from source, 2.4.x, currently 2.4.18 at home.  You need to
compile in the USB_STORAGE stuff and SCSI disk support, because
you mount it as a scsi device.  E.g., I say:

  mount -t vfat /dev/sda1 /mnt

to get access to the image files on the SmartMedia.

Looking at my kernel configuration, I have: "Support for USB", "UHCI
(Intel PIIX4, VIA, ...) support", "Microtech CompactFlash/SmartMedia
support" and "SanDisk SDDR-09 (and other SmartMedia) support" turned
on.  The last two were just guesses, I am not sure which (if either!)
is used for my particular hardware... but it does work!  ;-)

From rasmussenm at columbiafunds.com  Mon Sep  9 08:12:11 2002
From: rasmussenm at columbiafunds.com (Michael Rasmussen)
Date: Mon, 9 Sep 2002 08:12:11 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] newbie question
Message-ID: <0E402AD0FEACD411B7C100508BCDF61106049A8A@cmc-exchange.columbiafunds.com>

For full control over those network issues you'll need to edit:

	/etc/hosts
	/etc/resolv.conf
	/etc/sysconfig/network

Or use a tool like linuxconf or webmin.  You can also browse the utilities
and system menus and look for something like network.  For instance in a KDE
system you could click on the K logo -> system -> network configuration.

Keep in mind that even after making those changes if DNS does not list
web.exsolv.com the world won't be able to find your webserver.

From rasmussenm at columbiafunds.com  Mon Sep  9 08:19:57 2002
From: rasmussenm at columbiafunds.com (Michael Rasmussen)
Date: Mon, 9 Sep 2002 08:19:57 -0700

Message-ID: <0E402AD0FEACD411B7C100508BCDF61106049A8C@cmc-exchange.columbiafunds.com>

> From: Rich Shepard [mailto:rshepard at appl-ecosys.com]
> > My /etc/crontab has the entry "MAILTO=root" by default.  Both on RH 
> > 7.2/7.3.
> 
>   Thanks, Keith. So does mine. I changed it to mail to me.

Rich,

An alternative solution would be to change /etc/aliases or
/etc/postfix/aliases (IIRC you're using postfix) and have mail for root sent
to you.  That way you won't need to change the config of every utility that
mails status reports/errors/whatever to root.  

FWIW, this approach is strongly suggested by postfix itself as shown through
these comments from the default postfix aliases file:


# Person who should get root's mail.  This alias
# must exist.
# CHANGE THIS LINE to an account of a HUMAN
root:           admin_group at localhost

> An alternative solution would be to change /etc/aliases or
> /etc/postfix/aliases (IIRC you're using postfix) and have mail for root sent

  Thanks, Michael. That's been the case here:

# Person who should get root's mail. This alias must exist. CHANGE THIS
# LINE to an account of a HUMAN
root:           rshepard

# Note to the user: You must create the alias above! The root alias *must*
# exist under postfix because postfix runs as a non-privileged user and
# cannot touch a spool file which is UID/GID root The mapping to the postfix
# user is to ensure that root's mail doesn't get lost on a system installed
# out of the box.

> From: Paul Heinlein [mailto:heinlein at attbi.com]
> 
> Has anyone discovered a way to get OpenOffice.org to deal with inches 
> instead of millimeters in, e.g., printer settings? It's so much 
> simpler to visual a margin of 1in rather than 2.54mm :-)

Perhaps if you convert 1 inch to 25.4mm it would work better? :)

But the solution you seem to be looking for is the menu chain of: 
  Tools -> Options -> Text Documents -> General -> Measurement Unit   
where you have a choice of centimeter, millimeter, inch, pica or point.

As soon as you click OK the change is applied.

From deanm at sharplabs.com  Mon Sep  9 09:19:48 2002
From: deanm at sharplabs.com (Dean S. Messing)
Date: Mon,  9 Sep 2002 09:19:48 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] TeX special character
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0209071014480.30596-100000@linux.sourballs.org>
	(message from David Fleck on Sat, 7 Sep 2002 10:18:37 -0700 (PDT))
References: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0209071014480.30596-100000@linux.sourballs.org>
Message-ID: <20020909161948.CB13317902@medulla>


 :: Here's one that ought to be brain-dead simple - what's the special char in
 :: TeX/LaTeX for ? (the degree symbol)?  I can't find a way to do this in
 :: maths mode or standard mode, and I've already looked through Lamport and
 :: the ~ 100 pages of documentation I've printed off...

It is simple (if you look in the right place).  Neither _The Joy of TeX_
(definitive book on AMS TeX) nor Lamport's LaTeX book (definitive book
on LaTaX) have it in the index, though  each defines the `\deg' operator,
which is something else.

However, Donald Knuth's _The TeX Book_, the definitive book for EVERYTHING
related to TeX, has it.  And it is easy.

Basic TeX defines the `\circ' symbol which is a little open circle typically
used in mathematics for the "composition" operator between functions.

To get the standard degree symbol, simply use \circ as an exponent:

37? C would be (in TeX) `$37^\circ$ C

No need for any special AMS TeX or LaTeX symbols.  It's been there since
TeX was first invented.

Dean  '

From don at truedisk.com  Mon Sep  9 14:44:22 2002
From: don at truedisk.com (Don Buchholz)
Date: Mon, 09 Sep 2002 14:44:22 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] RPM question
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0209091344010.20579-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <3D7D1636.3030909@truedisk.com>

Rich Shepard wrote:

>  Now for something completely different: an rpm question.
>
>  I have libraries installed, but they did not come from packages. When I
>try to run 'apt-get ...' it fails because it found unsatisfied dependencies
>for jpilot and xfce. The dependencies are there, of course, but the rpm
>database doesn't see them.
>
>  Is there a way to get the database to accept that these libraries exist
>and are valid?
>

Well the RPM-only world would have you add the "--nodeps" option to 
rpm(8) to
bypass the dependency check during installation.

Paul Heinlein recently posted this beauty of a work-around on the RPM 
list ...
  
https://listman.redhat.com/mailman/private/rpm-list/2002-September/016348.html

It outlines how to create a "virtual" RPM package, where the RPM doesn't 
contain
any actual files, but uses the SPEC file "%Provides" directive to load 
the RPM database
with entries which will satisfy those dependency checks.

- Don

/dev/hdb              /win98                   vfat    defaults        0 0

From aschlemm at attbi.com  Mon Sep  9 16:21:46 2002
From: aschlemm at attbi.com (Anthony Schlemmer)
Date: Mon, 9 Sep 2002 16:21:46 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Kernel size?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0209091610570.23999-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0209091610570.23999-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <200209091621.46525.aschlemm@attbi.com>

I think that would depend on how you compiled your kernel. If you 
compile your kernel so that many of the features are in modules you do 
tend to end up with a smaller kernel. 

Make sure you do a: "make modules modules_install" So your modules are 
compiled and in place for your new kernel.

Tony

On Mon, 9 Sep 2002, Rich Shepard wrote:

>   I just compiled 2.4.19 as a bzImage and it ended up with a size of 1167673
> bytes. The 2.4.18 kernels, as vmlinux, are:
> 
>       2046153 Aug  7 10:02 vmlinux-2.4.18-10BOOT*
>       2835238 Apr 18 07:45 vmlinux-2.4.18-3*
> 
>   Before trying to reboot, I want to make sure the size of the new kernel is
> correct. Also, should I rename it to vmlinux-2.4.19?


My understanding of kernel image naming it that it can be whatever you 
want just as long as everything that references it uses that same name.  
The grub entry, the link /boot/vmlinuz, and others.  I don't think the 
name is used for kernel version identification as that comes from the 
kernel itself.

Theoretically you could have "Richs-happy-linux-kernel" for a file name.






From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Mon Sep  9 13:39:39 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)

On Mon, 9 Sep 2002, Anthony Schlemmer wrote:

> I think that would depend on how you compiled your kernel. If you 
> compile your kernel so that many of the features are in modules you do 
> tend to end up with a smaller kernel. 

Tony,

  Is is modular. When I looked more closely I saw this:

-rw-r--r--    1 root     root       804587 Aug  7 10:02 vmlinuz-2.4.18-10BOOT
-rw-r--r--    1 root     root      1030147 Apr 18 07:45 vmlinuz-2.4.18-3
-rw-r--r--    1 root     root      1167673 Sep  9 16:01 vmlinuz-2.4.19

  Apparently, bzImage was copied to vmlinuz-2.4.19 for me.
 
> Make sure you do a: "make modules modules_install" So your modules are 
> compiled and in place for your new kernel.

  Yup. Did these, too. However, there's no module-info for the new kernel.
This is what I have in /boot:

boot.b                    kernel.h                  System.map-2.4.18-3
bzImage                   lost+found/               System.map-2.4.19
chain.b                   message                   vmlinux-2.4.18-10BOOT*
config-2.4.18-10BOOT      module-info@              vmlinux-2.4.18-3*
config-2.4.18-3           module-info-2.4.18-3      vmlinuz@
grub/                     os2_d.b                   vmlinuz-2.4.18-10BOOT
initrd-2.4.18-10BOOT.img  System.map@               vmlinuz-2.4.18-3
initrd-2.4.18-3.img       System.map-2.4.18-10BOOT  vmlinuz-2.4.19

  The module-info link points to the 2.4.18-3 file (there's no module-info
for the 2.4.18-10 kernel, either. System.map points to System.map-2.4.19.

  After what I've gone through the past couple of weeks, I want to be
certain of what I'm doing before I get into deep trouble. :-) Ergo, my
hesitation when I'd charge ahead in the past.

  Also, here's how I set up /boot/grub/grub.conf (a.k.a.
/boot/grub/menu.lst):

# grub.conf generated by anaconda
#
# Note that you do not have to rerun grub after making changes to this file
# NOTICE:  You have a /boot partition.  This means that
#          all kernel and initrd paths are relative to /boot/, eg.
#          root (hd0,1)
#          kernel /vmlinuz-version ro root=/dev/hda1
#          initrd /initrd-version.img
#boot=/dev/hda
default=2
timeout=10
fallback=1
title linux (2.4.19)
	root (hd0,1)
	kernel /vmlinuz-2.4.19 ro root=/dev/hda1
title linux-old (2.4.18-10BOOT)
	root (hd0,1)
	kernel /vmlinuz-2.4.18-10BOOT ro root=/dev/hda1
	initrd /initrd-2.4.18-10BOOT.img
title linux single (2.4.18-10BOOT)
	root (hd0,1)
	kernel /vmlinuz-2.4.18-10BOOT ro root=/dev/hda1 single
	initrd /initrd-2.4.18-10BOOT.img
title linux (2.4.18-3)
	root (hd0,1)
	kernel /vmlinuz-2.4.18-3 ro root=/dev/hda1
	initrd /initrd-2.4.18-3.img

  I _think_ the ''fallback'' phrase is in the right place. Once I know it's
working properly I'll change the linux single to the 2.4.19 kernel.

Thanks,

Rich

From rsteff at attbi.com  Mon Sep  9 17:07:03 2002
From: rsteff at attbi.com (Richard Steffens)
Date: Mon, 09 Sep 2002 17:07:03 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Building Kernel for Debian
Message-ID: <3D7D37A7.A682CF5E@attbi.com>

I guess I didn't have the right directions:

http://www.ibiblio.org/pub/Linux/docs/HOWTO/other-formats/html_single/Kernel-HOWTO.html#ss1.1

or didn't follow them. Here's what I did:

Unpacked the 2.4.18 kernel in /usr/src/
made a link to it called linux
Copied /boot/config-2.2.20 to /usr/src/linux/.config
cd linux
make menuconfig
	I looked at a number of things, but didn't change anything, and saved
before leaving.
make dep
make clean
nohup make bzImage &
tail -f nohup.out
	I watched this until it stopped
make modules
make modules_install

I copied bzImage to /boot/bzImage/myker.20020909.1600, and added this to
lilo.conf:

# kernel compiled on September 9, 2002
#
image=/boot/bzImage.myker.20020909.1600
	label=myker
	root=/dev/hda2
	read-only

Then, I ran lilo and lilo -q and re-booted. Now, when I select myker
from lilo's menu, the system starts to load, but evenutally bogs down
with a lot of this message:

modprobe: modprobe: Can't locate module net-pf-1

As promised, I can continue to boot to the old kernel, and things appear
to work fine. Is there another set of instructions I should have been
following? What did I miss?

Thanks in advance.

Dick Steffens
"Quando Omni Flunkus Moritati"
http://rsteff.home.attbi.com/

Date: Mon, 9 Sep 2002 17:28:41 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Access and Samba
Message-ID: <200209100028.g8A0Sfi02643@mail.theplatinumrule.com>

I'm sharing a 30 meg complex database and a few smaller, nearly flat ones on a RedHat server with samba. Multiple clients use the database at the same time. Been doing it for about two years. It works great, no losses no reboots like the (old) weekly Novell reboots. The customer was stunned when I told him it had been 500 days since he'd had a server re-boot. I've made sym links for the database and the system.mdw for each of the eight or so users.

I'll be glad to share the details with anyone interested. We haven't lost anything that wasn't related to a Win crash during data entry. That's happened a few times...

Mike De La Mater

alan <alan at clueserver.org> wrote ..
> On Sat, 7 Sep 2002, Carla Schroder wrote:
> 
> > In theory it sounds reasonable- but this is Access we're dealing with.
> It's 
> > their customer order database, so no funky solutions permitted! 
> > 
> > I found there are utilities to convert .mdb to PostgreSQL and mySQL,
> that 
> > sounds way better to me. Use Access only as a front-end on the client
> PCs.
> 
> Access databases should never be shared for writing.  They do not have
> any 
> file locking to speak of.  They were designed for single user access, not
> multi-user access. It will work, but you can lose records and have 
> problems with database corruption.
> 
> Samba will handle filesharing as well or better than Windows will, as long
> as you can deal with the braindead way that the Win95/98 boxes handle 
> passwords.  Also, do not expect any file security if you share it and 
> *never* allow access outside the firewall.  (Win 95/98 uses incredibly
> bad 
> passwords.  It also exposes all sorts of information about the system,
> including MAC address.)
> 
> > 
> > Carla
> > 
> > 
> > On Saturday 07 September 2002 09:51 am, you wrote:

> > >
> > > I haven't shared one with samba, but I think it shouldn't be too hard.

> > > would try just putting the db on the linux box and setting the samba
> > > share for the directory its in then see what happens. Or another way
> > > might be to set a small Fat32 partition on the linux box to hold the
> DB
> > > and sharing that. The biggest problem I could see would be if multiple
> > > people were accessing the db at one time. I have had problems wih
> > > that even on Windows platforms.
> > >

  New kernel (2.4.19) booted just fine. Then I tried rebuilding the VMware
modules for this kernel.

  Came up with warnings that malloc.h has been deprecated (!) and slab.h
should be used instead. That didn't seem to bother the script. But, in the
latest version of driver.c, the function 'LinuxDriver_Ioctl' has no member
named 'dumpable'. This caused a fatal error and the vmmon module could not
be built.

  Is anyone here running VMware-2.x on a recent 2.4 kernel? I may have to
buy an upgrade just to run with this kernel.

Rich

From derek at infotects.com  Mon Sep  9 18:01:08 2002
From: derek at infotects.com (Derek Loree)
Date: 09 Sep 2002 18:01:08 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Building Kernel for Debian
In-Reply-To: <3D7D37A7.A682CF5E@attbi.com>
References: <3D7D37A7.A682CF5E@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <1031619668.14021.26082.camel@dereklinux>

On Mon, 2002-09-09 at 17:07, Richard Steffens wrote:
> I guess I didn't have the right directions:
> 
> http://www.ibiblio.org/pub/Linux/docs/HOWTO/other-formats/html_single/Kernel-HOWTO.html#ss1.1
> 
> or didn't follow them. Here's what I did:
> 
> Unpacked the 2.4.18 kernel in /usr/src/
> made a link to it called linux
> Copied /boot/config-2.2.20 to /usr/src/linux/.config

I can't imagine this working with no changes, you are using an old
kernel configuration for a new kernel, there will be some significant
differences.

> cd linux
> make menuconfig
> 	I looked at a number of things, but didn't change anything, and saved
> before leaving.
> make dep
> make clean
> nohup make bzImage &
> tail -f nohup.out
> 	I watched this until it stopped
> make modules
> make modules_install
> 
> I copied bzImage to /boot/bzImage/myker.20020909.1600, and added this to
> lilo.conf:
> 
> # kernel compiled on September 9, 2002
> #
> image=/boot/bzImage.myker.20020909.1600
> 	label=myker
> 	root=/dev/hda2
> 	read-only
> 
> Then, I ran lilo and lilo -q and re-booted. Now, when I select myker
> from lilo's menu, the system starts to load, but evenutally bogs down
> with a lot of this message:
> 
> modprobe: modprobe: Can't locate module net-pf-1

Looks like the configuration didn't work, was the option for loadable
modules set?
> 
> As promised, I can continue to boot to the old kernel, and things appear
> to work fine. Is there another set of instructions I should have been
> following? What did I miss?

To really make a fresh kernel work well, I recommend looking very
closely at the boot message (using the working kernel), your motherboard
manual, and the output of:

# lsmod

Use this information to create your own configuration file from scratch
(delete the current one, and the make menuconfig should create a new one
for you).  To absolutely guarantee that you can still boot your system,
I also recommend that you make a boot floppy, I think the command it
mkboot (try man mkboot). 


HTH, let us know if you need more information.

Derek

References: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0209061323250.26123-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>

	<87sn0maxip.fsf@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net> 
	<3D7A3AA3.6A36E8FB@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <1031624435.9496.6.camel@bittersweet>

On Sat, 2002-09-07 at 10:42, Richard Steffens wrote:
> "Karl M. Hegbloom" wrote:
>
> > The message from "gdm_slave_xioerr_handler" (Can you find it in the
> > gdm source in less than 5 minutes?  I can.  Want to know how?)
> 
> (No, but I would like to know how.)

Use "apt-get source gdm" (as a non-root user) to get a copy of the GDM
source code.  As root, run "apt-get install cscope xemacs21", unless
those are already installed.  Now visit the GDM source directory by
using "C-x C-f" or the toolbar, and finding that directory.  Either use
the Cscope menu and pick "Create list and index", or use the "C-c s I"
command to do it.  Push enter when the dialog or minibuffer is pointing
at the toplevel directory of gdm's sources, and let it build an index.

Now either use the Cscope menu to choose "Find global definition" or use
the command key listed in the menu to do so, and search for
"gdm_slave_xioerr_handler".  I think that you'll have it in front of you
in less than five minutes, not counting the time to install XEmacs and
Cscope.

> stopped working.  Has anyone else had an success getting this feature to

Robbert,

  What I've done, with WP as well as OO is print the file to disk using a
PostScript printer driver. Then I run the .ps file through ps2pdf. As long
as you have ghostscript > 6.0 it'll work like a charm. One of the major
efforts of the Alladin development team in the production of the 6.0 version
was this module.

Rich

harddrives so win98 is on hda to save trouble ;)

would love to be proven wrong however.)

> I see the names of the M$ TTF fonts.  For example, there's Tahoma
> and "trebuchet ms" and "ms outhouse" (I mean "outlook").
> 
> But when I click on any of them (say Tahoma) I get
> 
> "The selected font is not available"
> 
> in the window where the font should display.

It sounds like you've tried everything I would, but just in case 
there's a detail missing, here's what has worked for me (Red 
Hat 7.x, XFree86 4.x):

* copy .ttf files into /usr/share/fonts/default/TrueType

* cd into that directory and do

  /usr/bin/ttmkfdir -o fonts.scale
  /bin/cp fonts.scale fonts.dir

* restart xfs

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

>>      2835238 Apr 18 07:45 vmlinux-2.4.18-3*

>>  Before trying to reboot, I want to make sure the size of the new kernel is
>>correct. Also, should I rename it to vmlinux-2.4.19?
>>    
>>
>
>
>My understanding of kernel image naming it that it can be whatever you 
>want just as long as everything that references it uses that same name.  
>The grub entry, the link /boot/vmlinuz, and others.  I don't think the 
>name is used for kernel version identification as that comes from the 
>kernel itself.
>
>Theoretically you could have "Richs-happy-linux-kernel" for a file name.
>
>
>
>
>_______________________________________________
>PLUG mailing list
>PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
>http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug
>  
>
The convention of Linux kernel images does nothing to the actual usage. 
However, in general it has the following convention. vmlinuz usually 
stands for compressed image and vmlinux is a normal uncompressed kernel 
image and you can notice the sizes. You can use "nm vmlinux" to view all 
the kernel symbols if you want to because it is a normal elf binary.

David

From davidchow at shaolinmicro.com  Tue Sep 10 08:39:38 2002
From: davidchow at shaolinmicro.com (David Chow)
Date: Tue, 10 Sep 2002 23:39:38 +0800
Subject: [PLUG] named base FTP virtual hosting
References: <13800.206.30.30.2.1031615198.squirrel@sautez.dhs.org>
Message-ID: <3D7E123A.2030707@shaolinmicro.com>

Josh Orchard wrote:

>All,
>
>I'm using proftpd and I'm trying to have multiple domains on the same IP
>and have proftpd handle the virtual hosting.  It appears that when I
>connect to the second domain name it resolves the IP and then when it goes
>back tries to log into the first domain.
>Is it possible to do name based FTP virtual hosting with proftpd?  Or with
>FTP in general?
>If not, do I have to run the second domain names on a different IP then
>route the request in iptables?
>Thanks.
>
>Josh
>
>
>
>_______________________________________________
>PLUG mailing list
>PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
>http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug
>  
>

Name based virtual hosting only exists in http 1.1 protocol where the 
client sends also the requesting server name to the server (for example 
Apache). Then Apache based on the client's request to resolve to the 
correct document. Ftp is a simple file transfer protocol and does not 
have this feature. This is due to a limitation of the ftp protocol. You 
should try to use Apache with http protocol with directory listing 
enabled to simlulate a virtual hosts ftp site for anonymous users. Don't 
try to rely on virtual hosts for access control since it doesn't really 
give any security between virtual hosts, and you are trusting the 
client's browser who sends a correct HTTP 1.1 request to your server.

David




From davidchow at shaolinmicro.com  Tue Sep 10 08:48:46 2002
From: davidchow at shaolinmicro.com (David Chow)
Date: Tue, 10 Sep 2002 23:48:46 +0800
Subject: [PLUG] RPM question
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0209091344010.20579-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <3D7E145E.7040006@shaolinmicro.com>

Rich Shepard wrote:

>  Now for something completely different: an rpm question.
>
>  I have libraries installed, but they did not come from packages. When I
>try to run 'apt-get ...' it fails because it found unsatisfied dependencies
>for jpilot and xfce. The dependencies are there, of course, but the rpm
>database doesn't see them.
>
>  Is there a way to get the database to accept that these libraries exist
>and are valid?
>
>Thanks,
>
>Rich
>
>
>_______________________________________________
>PLUG mailing list
>PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
>http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug
>  
>


It seems you are installing packages that is not for your distribution. 
When specifying dependency in rpm packages, you can specify the package 
name and version or just a file name. Packagers specifies filenames are 
tend to make the package work on different distributions because package 
names doesn't really tells you the actual files locate in your system, 
different distros tends to have different packaging conventions even the 
name is the same or even using a different package name for the same 
package. You can try to force the installation by specifying the 
"--nodeps" means no dependency to force installing a package ignoring 
dependency. But if you failed to provide the correct shared library, 
your app is likely to fail in run time. You can check the file list by 
"rpm -ql [packagename]" and check the required library by typing "ldd 
[executablefile]" to check the library existence. If libraries are 
missing you cannot run. try to make symlinks to the same existed library 
file with the latest version and after type "ldconfig" to regen the 
/etc/ld.so.cache file. My experience is it may work , but sometimes will 
fail with an incorrect version of library. You really need the correct 
library file if none of them exists or it fails.

David

From richard.langis at sun.com  Tue Sep 10 08:50:49 2002
From: richard.langis at sun.com (Richard Langis)
Date: Tue, 10 Sep 2002 08:50:49 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Building Kernel for Debian
References: <3D7D37A7.A682CF5E@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <3D7E14D9.70805@sun.com>


Richard Steffens wrote:
> I guess I didn't have the right directions:
> 
> http://www.ibiblio.org/pub/Linux/docs/HOWTO/other-formats/html_single/Kernel-HOWTO.html#ss1.1
> 
> or didn't follow them. Here's what I did:
> 
> Unpacked the 2.4.18 kernel in /usr/src/
> made a link to it called linux
> Copied /boot/config-2.2.20 to /usr/src/linux/.config
> cd linux
> make menuconfig
> 	I looked at a number of things, but didn't change anything, and saved
> before leaving.
> make dep
> make clean

I don't make clean between builds myself.

> nohup make bzImage &
> tail -f nohup.out
> 	I watched this until it stopped
> make modules
> make modules_install

Usually, I'll configure the kernel, then - all in ONE line:

make dep modules bzImage modules_install install

'install' copies the bzImage to /boot/vmlinuz, copies the old 
/boot/vmlinuz image to /boot/vmlinuz-old, updates lilo.conf to reflect 
these changes, and runs lilo.

> 
> I copied bzImage to /boot/bzImage/myker.20020909.1600, and added this to
> lilo.conf:
> 
> # kernel compiled on September 9, 2002
> #
> image=/boot/bzImage.myker.20020909.1600

You've got a . where a / should be in the above line.

 >> I copied bzImage to /boot/bzImage/myker.20020909.1600
                                     ^

> 	label=myker
> 	root=/dev/hda2
> 	read-only
> 
> Then, I ran lilo and lilo -q and re-booted. Now, when I select myker
> from lilo's menu, the system starts to load, but evenutally bogs down
> with a lot of this message:
> 
> modprobe: modprobe: Can't locate module net-pf-1
> 
> As promised, I can continue to boot to the old kernel, and things appear
> to work fine. Is there another set of instructions I should have been
> following? What did I miss?
> 
> Thanks in advance.
> 

Check your /etc/modules(.conf) for that line 'net-pf-1' and see what 
it's referencing.

Alternatively, since you are using debian, you CAN just grab a 
preconfigured kernel via apt-get that *should* work out of the box.  For 
example:

$ apt-cache search kernel | grep 2.4.19-686
kernel-headers-2.4.19-686 - Linux kernel headers 2.4.19 on 
PPro/Celeron/PII/PIII/PIV
kernel-image-2.4.19-686 - Linux kernel image 2.4.19 on 
PPro/Celeron/PII/PIII/PIV.
kernel-pcmcia-modules-2.4.19-686 - Mainstream PCMCIA modules 2.4.19 on 
PPro/Celeron/PII/PIII/PIV.
pcmcia-modules-2.4.19-686 - PCMCIA Modules for Linux (kernel 2.4.19-686).

Hope that helps.

-Richard

On Mon, 2002-09-09 at 22:57, Rogan Creswick wrote:
> Follow the thread started by Jason Dagit above ("Dual booting"), then swap
> harddrives so win98 is on hda to save trouble ;)
> 
> (to my knowledge you can not boot Win98 from any drive that is preceded by a
> non-fat filesystem. In most cases this means only hda1 will boot win98. I
> would love to be proven wrong however.)

Technically, the one partition (and only one) that has the "boot" flag
set is the only partition that will boot win98, it shouldn't matter
which IDE port the drive is plugged into.  However this seems to be
dependent on the BIOS's ability to recognize and properly initiate the
boot loader so, YMMV.  FYI, I have accidentally booted win98 from the
secondary-master IDE port because the drive I had setup (with a fresh
install of 98) on the primary didn't have the boot flag set.

Good Luck

Derek






From dagit at engr.orst.edu  Tue Sep 10 10:21:20 2002
From: dagit at engr.orst.edu (Jason Dagit)

Subject: [PLUG] kernel build errors during install
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0209100923010.6027-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0209101017320.17413-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>

Backup your .config.  make mrproper.  Copy your .config back.  make
menuconfig. save exit, then build as usual.  If you still have
problems then something else is wrong.  But you said it worked on the
other computer.

Of course this assumes that you used the same config, even if you
didn't it can make it easier to trouble shoot.

HTH,
Jason
