From cb at mail.onsitetech.com  Tue Sep 10 12:29:50 2002
From: cb at mail.onsitetech.com (Christian Brink)
Date: Tue, 10 Sep 2002 11:29:50 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] List of CVS projects
Message-ID: <2.1-9009149-404-A-OEWW@mail.onsitetech.com>

the easiest way is to look at your repository. This is visible in your 
dir string for cvs

  eg. cvs -d :pserver:user at host.name:/dir-name

you would look at host 'host.name' in directory '/dir-name' for the 
project names.

You might want to pick up the Fogel book IIRC 'Open Source Development 
with CVS' this should answer this question.

Christian Brink

From aschlemm at attbi.com  Tue Sep 10 12:10:57 2002
From: aschlemm at attbi.com (Anthony Schlemmer)
Date: Tue, 10 Sep 2002 12:10:57 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Tidying up
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0209100611100.5666-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0209100611100.5666-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <200209101210.57996.aschlemm@attbi.com>

The quick solution is if you're still in the same terminal you 
backgrounded "pine" in simply type: fg<RETURN>

If you're running through an xterm and have forgotten which session you 
backgrounded "pine" in you can do the following:

1) Run "ps" and under the TTY column note what "pts" "pine" is 
associated with.

2) For each xterm you have open, type "tty" at the shell prompt which 
displays the "pts" device your xterm is associated with. Once you get 
the same "pts" device that pine is associated with you can then type: 
"fg<RETURN>" to bring "pine" to the foreground.

Tony

You need to login (ssh, telnet) to the server that holds the repository then 
browse /scratch/cvs

If you're not adverse to gui tools, check out (accidental pun) TkCVS

http://sourceforge.net/projects/tkcvs

If you install tcl/tk on your windows box (not difficult), TkCVS makes a lot 
of CVS stuff less painful.

Cheers,
Kyle Accardi

That's a server mapped CVSROOT, instead of file mapped.  On the machine
pserver, in /scratch/cvs/info.outdoor-x should be all the modules by
directory.

As far as I can tell, there's no way to query CVS to ask it which
modules it has directly.

From deanm at sharplabs.com  Tue Sep 10 13:43:41 2002
From: deanm at sharplabs.com (Dean S. Messing)
Date: Tue, 10 Sep 2002 13:43:41 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] truetype font help
In-Reply-To: <200209100714.g8A7EBX02201@paper-wolf-solo.tigerfood.org>
	(message from Felix Lee on Tue, 10 Sep 2002 00:14:10 -0700)
References: <200209100714.g8A7EBX02201@paper-wolf-solo.tigerfood.org>
Message-ID: <20020910204341.D463417902@medulla>

On Mon, 9 Sep 2002, Dean S. Messing wrote:
< a sob story about not being able to get TTF fonts to work>

Keith Morse replied with a link to some helpful info.

Thanks Keith.

Paul Heinlein replied with a "magic incantation".

Thanks Paul.  I didn't try it but I now see that it
would probably have worked---depending on my root UMASK.

Finally, Felix Lee replied with:

 :: first guess: are the font files and the font dir readable by
 :: all?  xfs runs as an unprivileged user, not root.

Good guess.   The font dir and the font.{dir|scale} files were.
But the font files weren't.

That was it!  I suppose I should be embarassed, being
an old Linux hand hoodwinked by such a greenhorn trick.
But I'm not.  In fact I'm confused.
In my first attempt the .ttf font files were created with
root read permission for both owner and group:  -rw-r-----  root root

In another attempt it was -rw-r-----  deanm dvideo                      

Now I'm deanm.  And I'm in both group dvideo and group root.
Furthermore KDE was started by deanm (which is probably of no consequence).
Most important, `gfontsel' was started by both me and root in the many
times I tried to get the thing to work.  It was started on "The Command Line"
not by "binking" anything so in each case it should have been running
with the permissions of the executor---in which case it should have
been able to see the fonts.

Oh. Maybe I see.  I'm wonder ... (some seconds later)

xfs is running under UID "xfs".  That's it.  xfs couldn't get to the
fonts.  I can change their ownership, and then I can (if I like)
turn off world read bit.


 :: second guess: dunno.  everything you describe looks fine to
 :: me.  I just did the same thing a few months ago.  I got
 :: tired of the ugly imitation fonts that come with AbiWord.
 :: --

I like this guess.  It's usually the one I make.

Once again, eleven hours later, having pursued this to the bitter end,
I've picked up a few more crumbs of knowledge.  What a colossal
waste of time.

Dean

"The Average Linux Problem takes an averge of eleven hours to fix"

Message-ID: <3D7E6011.1020205@pacifier.com>

Curtis Poe wrote:
> Turns out to be a non-issue now.  I just kept guessing project names until I
> stumbled across the right one.  Of course, it would still be nice to know
> how to get a list of available projects.
> 
> --
> Cheers,
> Curtis Poe


If someone was nice enough to create module names (aliases to directories), 
you can checkout the CVSROOT directory itself

$ cvs co CVSROOT

and look at the modules dir

$ less CVSROOT/modules

This is a hand edited file and does not necessarily show all dirs in the cvs 
top-level dir.

--
Kyle Accardi

I know that the file transfer (at least the zmodem protocol) works in
mincom, I've used it to transfer boot images to Cisco routers.  The
tricky part seems to be getting the protocol parameters the same on both
ends of the connection (actually the Cisco routers didn't have any
adjustment, I had to tweak away at minicom until it worked).  My
experience has been that if minicom doesn't work, it is because I
haven't changed the right parameters.

I know this isn't the answer to your question, but I did try out other
terminal emulators, and I found that minicom worked the best.

Derek Loree

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Tue Sep 10 12:19:07 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Tue, 10 Sep 2002 15:19:07 -0400 (EDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Serial Port file transfers
In-Reply-To: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0209101433190.19032-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0209101513180.8944-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

On Tue, 10 Sep 2002, Jason Dagit wrote:

> How would I do this?  The little computer only has about 64megs total
> for storage, so hopefully I don't need to install anything new on it.

  According to the Preface to Frank da Cruz and Christine M. Gianone's
"Using C-Kermit, Second Edition", "C-Kermit software offers you terminal
connection, error-free file transfer and management, script programming and
comprehensive support for national and international character sets over a
wide variety of communications methods incuding direct and dialed serial
connections and (in most versions) TCP/IP, X.25 and or other netowrks."

  C-Kermit is still in active development at Columbia University and they
have a very helpful staff there. You can make a direct serial connection
between the two boxes and what you need on the little guy should fit
comfortably.

  I was going to write my bathymetry software in C-Kermit but decided on C
instead.

HTH,

Rich

For what it's worth, I have Windows ME on hda1 and I installed XP on hdb1. XP 
puts it's boot sector on the C: drive, no matter what. (XP - Windows 2K 
functionally the same for this purpose). I then installed Slackware on a 
partition on the hdb5, used lilo, which points to Slack and to Windows on 
hda1. If I choose Windows, it brings up the XP boot menu, where I can select 
either ME or XP.

If you have any questions, feel free to respond to me directly.

From derek at infotects.com  Tue Sep 10 17:00:47 2002

On Tue, 2002-09-10 at 16:21, Jason Dagit wrote:
> 
> 
> On 10 Sep 2002, Derek Loree wrote:
> 
> > I know that the file transfer (at least the zmodem protocol) works in
> > mincom, I've used it to transfer boot images to Cisco routers.  The
> > tricky part seems to be getting the protocol parameters the same on both
> > ends of the connection (actually the Cisco routers didn't have any
> > adjustment, I had to tweak away at minicom until it worked).  My
> > experience has been that if minicom doesn't work, it is because I
> > haven't changed the right parameters.
> 
> Could you give me an example of what to change?  I'm really new at this.

IIRC, the serial settings were the key, baud rate in particular (if this
isn't exactly right, the other end may respond, but in a way that
doesn't make sense), but the error protocol (or handshake protocol) had
to be correct as well.   As far as I can tell almost every device made
after 1990 uses 8 bit, no parity and one stop bit (abbreviated 8,N,1). 
Unfortunately, I can't begin to guess what settings you will need.

For the Cisco connection, I think I had to start with 2400 Bps, 8,N,1,
Hardware flow control on, and software flow control off. I seem to
remember reading somewhere that a typical null modem configuration uses
either hardware flow control or no flow control, while the software flow
control is used for dial-up modems, but I may be mistaken.

HTH

Derek

Wine has made leaps and bounds in the last year or two.  Mostly, I
think, due to the (now defunkt) Lindows deal.

Wine runs some of the stranger apps I've played with, including a couple
of SETI at Home team stat monitors without too much problems.  Anything
that interfaces with the web can cause problems if it uses Internet
Exploiter.

It's free... and a fairly easy (albeit long) compile.  I'd try it out
and see if your apps work.  Most of the apps I've tried do work, but
have either been a bit more unstable than they are in Windoze native or
are a little bit off... be it fonts or toolbars or whatnot.

From rsteff at attbi.com  Tue Sep 10 17:27:09 2002
From: rsteff at attbi.com (Richard Steffens)
Date: Tue, 10 Sep 2002 17:27:09 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Printer Installation - Success was Building Kernel for Debian
Message-ID: <3D7E8DDD.7E78D0AA@attbi.com>

This started out as the Building Kernel for Debian thread because I
didn't realize that the USB support I needed was already in the kernel I
had. I'll go back to building a kernel later on, but for now, I'm happy
to report that I discovered what I was missing, and I have my HP Deskjet
656c working from my newly installed USB 2 card.

I went to http://www.linuxnewbie.org/forum/search.php and searched on
"USB AND HowTo." One of the results, titled "USB problems" solved my
problem. The individual who asked for help was directed to see if his
USB modules were loaded. I looked and found that mine were not. I did
see some references to USB in the messages that scroll by during boot,
though. After reading man modprobe and looking at what was available, I
concluded that I needed to run

modprobe usb-ohci
modprobe usb-core
modprobe printer

I knew from yesterday's study that since I have a card with NEC chips, I
need ohci. I guessed that I needed usb-core from things mentioned in the
linuxnewbie thread, and I guessed that I needed printer since it exists
in /lib/modules/2.2.20/usb. After loading those modules, I ran the CUPS
web based admin tool again, installed the printer, and printed a test
page.

There may be some fine points that I've missed, such as, is what I did
permanent, or do I need to put something in a config file somewhere --
I've read the man page for modprobe, update-modules, and  modules.conf,
and didn't come away with a solid understanding that I did or did not
need to do anything further. But for now, I'm happy that I can finally
print. I'm very close to abandoning Windows as the environment in which
I live on a day-to-day basis. Just need to find a page layout tool to
print booklets, and to  figure out how to use e-mail with EMACS. I'm
really partial to the tree style of storing e-mails used in Netscape, so
I'm hoping there will be something that is functionally equivalent.

-- 
Regards,

Dick Steffens
"Quando Omni Flunkus Moritati"
http://rsteff.home.attbi.com/

It's been a very long time since I've had to think or deal with serial 
ports like this but I recall using Kermit in cases where (8,N,1) wasn't 
available. I recall using Kermit in places where we had 7 bit, even 
parity connections (7,E,1). IIRC Kermit did some special "quoting" of 
characters so it was possible to transfer binary data via Kermit even 
though the connection was 7 bit. 

Tony

From AthlonRob at data.lm.ro  Tue Sep 10 18:42:07 2002
From: AthlonRob at data.lm.ro (AthlonRob)
Date: 10 Sep 2002 18:42:07 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] dosemu & wine
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0209101826230.9879-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0209101826230.9879-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <1031708527.4459.12.camel@duron>

On Tue, 2002-09-10 at 15:31, Rich Shepard wrote:
>   I've tried to find mail lists for dosemu and wine, but without success. If
> someone knows of one, or knows what google search term will reveal them.

DOSEMU is kinda dead, or close to it, I think.  I don't know about Wine
mailing lists... the FreeDOS mailing lists, however, will often handle
DOSEMU questions (in my experience) ...

>   From my readings so far, it seems that I need to actually install DOS or
> Windows on the vfat partition. It's /dev/hd10 and mounted on /dos7. Before,
> I had PC-DOS7 installed in the mbr of /dev/hdb1 so dosemu worked just fine.
> Now it won't boot. I think that I could access my ol' DOS app via wine, so
> I'd rather focus on that.

Ok... DOSEMU and WinE are two totally different things.  DOSEMU boots up
DOS inside a sorta-virtualized machine.  You run DOS (MS-DOS, FreeDOS,
PC-DOS, whatever) inside a window.  It is *slower than hell* ...

WINE, on the other hand, runs more of a linux-way.  That is, the
programs have their windows rendered by your WM, etc.  Wine works well
completely standalone.  You do *not* install your OS into some sort of
virtualized disk or somethign as you might do with DOSEMU.

If you do have Windows installed somewhere accessable to your system,
you can tell Wine to work from there... this will allow any needed files
to be more easily found.

>   The winhq Web site didn't say how to install the OS, say win98, onto a
> linux partition that's been formatted with the vfat fs. Or, if it was there,
> I missed it.

That's because you don't do that.  DOSEMU boots, Wine doesn't.  Win98
sucks as far as Wine goes... if you want to have Wine work with a
pre-existing installation of whatever, I strongly suggest you go with
Windows 2000 ... if not Win2K, then NT 4.0 or XP.  How to get them
there?  You could use VMWare, I think....

>   Rob, have you done this before?

I've done similar things, but haven't ever installed Windows so that
Wine could use it.  If I had Windows there for whatever reason, I might
try getting Wine using it... but that was always with Win98SE, and it
totally sucked.

I hope that answered a few questions for ya.  :-)

-- 
Rob
 "The nice thing about standards is that you have so many to choose
from."
 - Andrew S. Tanenbaum

I had the same problem with my RedHat 7.2 system.  I had to set my DNS
configuration to use the DNS Search path to ATTBI.COM and set the DNS
servers statically.

From sean at fork.com  Tue Sep 10 22:08:11 2002
From: sean at fork.com (Sean Whitney)
Date: Tue, 10 Sep 2002 22:08:11 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Evolution and mail spools
Message-ID: <20020911050811.7E3082F68C@einstein.seansdomain.org>

I've been wanting to use Evolution for a mail client for a while.

I set it up for my wife and she loves it.  However I am using local mail 
spools that are NFS mounted and I could never get it to check mail without
a locking complaint.

Tonight I decided to check again and with googles help found.

http://mail.gnome.org/archives/gnome-redhat-list/2001-November/msg00020.html

The comments at the bottom

> 	# chown root.mail /usr/sbin/camel-lock-helper
> 	# chmod g+s /usr/sbin/camel-lock-helper

Did the trick!

So now I'm going to try and migrate from Kmail to evolution.


Sean

I switched from KMail to Sylpheed to Evolution.  Aside from its (IMHO)
broken PGP/GPG handling, I'm starting to like it.

One thing you might think about is compiling it from source.  It was
really an oinker here... taking a good 10-15 seconds to load up.

Now it takes closer to five or six seconds.

Here are the flags I used in its compile:
CFLAGS="-O3 -s -funroll-loops -ffast-math -mcpu=i686 -march=i386
-fno-exceptions -fschedule-insns2 -fexpensive-optimizations"
CXXFLAGS="-O3 -s -mcpu=i686 -march=i386"
LIBCFLAGS="-O3 -s -mcpu=i686 -march=i386"
BOOT_CFLAGS="-O3 -s -mcpu=i686 -march=i386"

...if you're interested.  :-)

/dev/hda8	/

/dev/hda13	/mnt/win_g
/dev/hda14	/tmp
/dev/hda11	/usr
/dev/hda12	/var

Now this tells me that my /home is not being mounted. Even stranger
still is I can login and access all my files in the /home directory.

I have made sure that it is a ext3 file system by

tune2fs -j /dev/hda10

I checked the fstab

/dev/hda8 / ext3 defaults 1 1
none /dev/pts devpts mode=0620 0 0
none /dev/shm tmpfs defaults 0 0

From buchholz at easystreet.com  Wed Sep 11 00:40:36 2002

The DHCP client might also have a tough time updating a mode 444
/etc/resolv.conf file.  Try setting it to: mode=644, owner=root,
group=root.

From cooper at linux-enterprise.net  Wed Sep 11 09:18:11 2002
From: cooper at linux-enterprise.net (D. Cooper Stevenson)
Date: Wed, 11 Sep 2002 09:18:11 -0700
Subject: Evolution + procmail? (Was: Re: [PLUG] Evolution and mail spools)
In-Reply-To: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0209110831270.20714-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>; from creelan@engr.orst.edu on Wed, Sep 11, 2002 at 08:43:17AM -0700
References: <1031722007.1367.17.camel@linux> <Pine.GSO.4.44.0209110831270.20714-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>
Message-ID: <20020911091811.A9834@cooper.kattare.com>

Tyler;

[snip]
> what if your mail is already sorted into files on a remote server by
> procmail, will evolution read these files in as folders? Or do I need to
> use an auxiliary program like fetchmail?
[unsnip]

Procmail uses the 'maildir' standard to separate it's messages into folders. It's a solid system that has been around for some time. See /usr/share/doc/courier-doc/README.sharedfolders.html (or find / -name README.sharedfolders.html) for more information on the Maildir and Maildir++ standard. 

Evolution supports this. Look for something to the effect of ``a standard UNIX directory'' for the source of the mail (instead of, for example, a POP3 server) and input the path to your sorted mail folder.

I will follow up this afternoon if you would like a quick step-by-step on it.

--

Cooper Stevenson        |cooper at metasource.us
UNIX/Linux Consultant   |PH: (541)791-1322
MetaSource Technologies |www.metasource.us

From cooper at linux-enterprise.net  Wed Sep 11 09:59:11 2002
From: cooper at linux-enterprise.net (D. Cooper Stevenson)
Date: Wed, 11 Sep 2002 09:59:11 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] OO running processes, no display
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0209111240010.1927-100000@appl-ecosys.com>; from rshepard@appl-ecosys.com on Wed, Sep 11, 2002 at 12:40:40PM -0400
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0209110926070.12236-100000@pecos.madboa.com> <Pine.LNX.4.44.0209111240010.1927-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <20020911095911.A9972@cooper.kattare.com>

Rich,

[snip]
>   Oh. Well, is there anything to be done short of rebooting the system?
[usnip]

I am assuming that the name of the hanging process is something like 'oofice.' Insert the process name that uniquely identifies the process as one that belongs to OpenOffice if that is not the case.

The following performed at the command line will remove any process with the name 'oofice...'

   ps -ef | grep oofice | awk '{ print $2 }' | while read i  [Press Enter]
   do  [Press Enter]
   kill -HUP $i  [Press Enter]
   done [Press Enter]

If they are stubborn, replace the `HUP' signal in the kill command with a '-9'.  Try to run the application again.

Of course, you could simlply kill the processes one at a time but this is handy to know if you run into a process that spawns several child processes. 

When running a large server, you want to do a manual 'ps -ef' and look before you kill.

--

From karlheg at pdxlinux.org  Wed Sep 11 10:24:55 2002
From: karlheg at pdxlinux.org (Karl M. Hegbloom)
Date: 11 Sep 2002 10:24:55 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] dircolors stored where?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0209111256160.2246-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0209111256160.2246-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <1031765095.32315.6.camel@bittersweet>

On Wed, 2002-09-11 at 09:58, Rich Shepard wrote:
>   Where is the text database shown when 'dircolors --print-database' is
> invoked? I need to change a color when directory listings are presented and
> I cannot seem to find the location of the database. It's not 'rgb' and the
> man page isn't helpful in this regard.
> 

8<----------------------------------------------------------------------->8
   If FILE is specified, `dircolors' reads it to determine which colors
to use for which file types and extensions.  Otherwise, a precompiled
database is used.  For details on the format of these files, run
`dircolors --print-database'.
8<----------------------------------------------------------------------->8

You did not read closely enough.  What you should do is run "dircolors
--print-database > /etc/dircolors", (assuming you want this change to be
system wide, for all users) then edit "/etc/dircolors" and use it as
input from your Bash or Zsh startup scripts.

The "dircolors -p" output is, by the way, a good way to get the
colorization escape codes, for reference.

Just a note - lsof is a great tool for situations like this. It also
doesn't seem to be trojaned by many rootkits when netstat and ps almost
always are. Just to be safe, it's good to keep a statically link known
good copy on read-only media.

# lsof -i | grep 31337
fakebo     9177 root    4u  IPv4 1888270       UDP *:31337 
# ps -p 9177
  PID TTY          TIME CMD
 9177 ?        00:00:00 fakebo

--Stafford

From derek at infotects.com  Wed Sep 11 10:49:29 2002
From: derek at infotects.com (Derek Loree)
Date: 11 Sep 2002 10:49:29 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Unmounted /dev
In-Reply-To: <1031717209.2677.44.camel@alexlinux.qwest.net>
References: <1031717209.2677.44.camel@alexlinux.qwest.net>
Message-ID: <1031766570.14021.27280.camel@dereklinux>

On Tue, 2002-09-10 at 21:06, alex wrote:
> I'm running MDL8.2 and had a breaker flip on me a couple of times in the
> past few days.(New breaker) Each time fsck was run successfully. Now
> here's the interesting part.
> /dev/hda10, which is my /home partition can not be mounted. I get
> 
> mount: wrong fs type, bad option, bad superblock on /dev/hda10,
> or too many mounted file systems
> 
> If I do a df I get
> /dev/hda8	/
> none		/dev/shm
> /dev/hda1	/mnt/win_c
> /dev/hda5	/mnt/win_d
> /dev/hda6	/mnt/win_e
> /dev/hda7	/mnt/win_f
> /dev/hda13	/mnt/win_g
> /dev/hda14	/tmp
> /dev/hda11	/usr
> /dev/hda12	/var
> 
> Now this tells me that my /home is not being mounted. Even stranger
> still is I can login and access all my files in the /home directory.

This is one of the really useful features of mounting partitions inside
file systems.  The mount point (/home in this case) isn't a mount point
until something is mounted to it, until then it is just another
directory that can have files and directories in it.  After you mount,
the original files and directories don't get erased, they are just no
longer accessible and the files and directories that are stored on the
mounted partition are now accessible.  I've done this many times with
the /home directory.  Install the OS with only one or two partitions,
set up user accounts and then realize that the / partition is too small
to contain /home.  I would then install a new harddrive, mount it to
/mnt, copy all files inside /home to /mnt (with no users logged in),
then mount the new drive on /home.  If something goes wrong (like
forgetting to use the -Rdp option with cp), just unmount the drive and
the original /home is still there.
> 
> I have made sure that it is a ext3 file system by
> 
> tune2fs -j /dev/hda10
> 
> I checked the fstab
> 
[snipped the biggest fstab I've ever seen]
> 
> and I think everything is ok there. Then I tried to use Linuxconf to get
> it mounted and it did! I thought "SUCCESS" until I opened Nautilus and
> all my files were in /home/lost+found in at least a thousand folders.
> <PANIC> So I took a chance and reran Linuxconf telling it to do nothing
> and everything was back to "normal".
> 
> So my question is....what the heck is going on here?

Looks like the power surge has caused a corruption of the partition.

> Why am I able to use /home even when /dev/hda10 is not mounted?
> Should I just count my lucky stars and live life to the fullest?

This depends on the free space of your / partition.  Since your
unmounted /home directory seems to be intact, you could re-initialize
the /dev/hda10 partition (all data will be lost on this partition),
mount it somewhere else (preferably an empty directory), copy all files
and directories from /home to the new mount, then remount to /home.

HTH a little anyway.

Derek Loree

From karlheg at pdxlinux.org  Wed Sep 11 11:53:18 2002
From: karlheg at pdxlinux.org (Karl M. Hegbloom)
Date: 11 Sep 2002 11:53:18 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] dev fs and permission problem
In-Reply-To: <20020910222012.GA679@jade.CS.ORST.EDU>
References: <20020910222012.GA679@jade.CS.ORST.EDU>
Message-ID: <1031770398.32315.31.camel@bittersweet>

On Tue, 2002-09-10 at 15:20, Rogan Creswick wrote:
>  Since flashing my BIOS last week (Tyan Tiger MPX mobo) I have had problems
>  with permissions on various devices. /dev/dsp, /dev/mixer, and /dev/ttyS1
>  at the least have had their permissions changed, such that a normal user
>  can no longer make use of them. (/dev/ttyS1 has all rx perms, but no one can
>  write to it, the others I would have to reboot to check).
> 
>  This is easily fixed with a chmod, however since I am using the
>  dev file system they revert to the undesired state when I reboot. Rather
>  than write a script to reset them at each boot I'd like to know how to
>  "correctly" fix the problem.
> 
>  fwiw, I'm running Debian Sid, on 2.4.17 for x86.

RTFM "devfsd" -- /usr/share/doc/devfsd, man update-devfs, and look at
the conffiles in /etc/devfs/.

You can create /dev-state/, and enable the rules in the devfsd.conf that
turn that feature on.  It seems to work fairly well, aside from some
warning messages each time I reboot re devcices for which no driver is
loaded yet.

On Wed, 2002-09-11 at 11:35, Karl M. Hegbloom wrote:
> On Wed, 2002-09-11 at 10:34, Matt Alexander wrote:
> > On Wed, 2002-09-11 at 09:58, Rich Shepard wrote:
> > >   Where is the text database shown when 'dircolors --print-database' is
> > > invoked? I need to change a color when directory listings are presented and
> > > I cannot seem to find the location of the database. It's not 'rgb' and the
> > > man page isn't helpful in this regard.
> > 
> > On RedHat, I believe it's in /etc/DIR_COLORS
> 
> Does the Red Hat version of "dircolors" read that automaticly, or is it
> pulled in by one of the shell startup files?

It is called by one of of the shell startup files.  In Slackware it is
/etc/profile:

# Set up the LS_COLORS and LS_OPTIONS environment variables for color
ls:
if [ "$SHELL" = "/bin/zsh" ]; then
 eval `dircolors -z`
elif [ "$SHELL" = "/bin/ash" ]; then
 eval `dircolors -s`
else
 eval `dircolors -b`
fi

You could put something similar in your ~/.bashrc file to be sure it is
called...

-- 
Rob

from."
 - Andrew S. Tanenbaum

/etc/profile.d/colorls.sh which runs dircolors on /etc/DIR_COLORS

From seniorr at aracnet.com  Wed Sep 11 14:10:56 2002
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)

Subject: [PLUG] Email signatures

>>>>> "Paul" == Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com> writes:

Jason> Does anyone know an easy way that doesn't require root to do
Jason> this with unix or linux?

Paul> Sure, create a named pipe. All the widely used scripting
Paul> languages will allow you to do this quite simply. See, e.g.,

Paul>   http://www.rocketaware.com/perl/perlipc/Named_Pipes.htm

Similar functionality, but not _quite_ the same thing, I think.  The
named pipe requires the perl FIFO-filler program to be running in a
"daemon mode".  If the perl script "goes away", reading from the named
pipe hangs.  The HURD functionality spawns the program more like an
inetd thing.  

Seems to me, it used to be possible, and even common, for people's
.signature's, .plan's, .project's and whatnot to be executable and
perform a similar function.  I never did that, so I don't know how
common it is anymore.

has an official slogan of "All mail clients suck. This one just sucks less."

From dan_young at parkrose.k12.or.us  Wed Sep 11 15:22:31 2002
From: dan_young at parkrose.k12.or.us (Dan Young)
Date: Wed, 11 Sep 2002 15:22:31 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] rpms
In-Reply-To: <3D7FBE47.90202@attbi.com>
References: <3D7FBE47.90202@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <1461.10.129.1.188.1031782951.squirrel@mail.parkrose.k12.or.us>

H Dirk Ouellette said:
> Would someone tell me again how to install all of the rpms I downloaded
> from RedHat's update site, at the same time ?

% rpm -Uvh foo.rpm bar.rpm  (where foo.rpm and bar.rpm are the rpms in
question)

If all of the RPMS in the current directory are ones you want to install,
you could do some file globbing:

% rpm -Uvh *.rpm

If they have dependencies, get ready to hunt them down (rpmfind.net is
useful for this) and undergo the heckling of the "apt-get install foo"
crowd.

-Dan Young
-Parkrose School District





From russj at dimstar.net  Wed Sep 11 15:25:57 2002
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: Wed, 11 Sep 2002 15:25:57 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] rpms
References: <3D7FBE47.90202@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <3D7FC2F5.1050403@dimstar.net>

H Dirk Ouellette wrote:

> Would someone tell me again how to install all of the rpms I 
> downloaded from RedHat's update site, at the same time ?
> BTW , my date and time should be correct now.
> Thanks,
> Dirk.
>
It depends on how you want to do it.

If you want to just install, regardless of what's already there, this 
command will do it:

rpm -i *

If you want to update those that already exist, and install those that 
don't:

rpm -U *

If you want to "freshen" (which means only update those that have a 
prior version installed):

rpm -F *

Your date/time looks correct.

One of the "media copy" ANSI sequences is probably what you want.  (i.e.
ESC [ i) Also look at the xterm attribute "printerCommand" to tell it what
command to run when this sequence is received.

  -- Steve

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Wed Sep 11 13:16:21 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Wed, 11 Sep 2002 16:16:21 -0400 (EDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Re: rpms
In-Reply-To: <3D7FC7F4.1010206@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0209111611230.8855-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

On Wed, 11 Sep 2002, Dirk Ouellette wrote:

> # rpm -F *
> ethereal-gnome-0.9.4-0.7.3.0.i386.rpm: read manifest failed: Success
> 
> That's my one answer to about 24 rpms I downloaded. Is this rpm blocking 
> all of the others? Should I remove the ethereal rpms and try again?

  What that's telling you is that you don't have ethereal-gnome installed so
it cannot freshen the installation. Do "rpm -q ethereal-gnome" and you
should get no response. That query tells you the verion of the installed
package. For example:

[root at salmo /home/rshepard]# rpm -q ethereal
ethereal-0.9.6-0.73.0

(I don't do Gnome or KDE here.)

  Move the ethereal-gnome rpm someplace else and re-run your Freshen
command. Then you can install ethereal-gnome.

  Two other hints:

  1)  Add the 'vh' switches to the rpm command line and you'll get progress
reports (as hashes) and more verbose output.

  B)  Since Karl hasn't offered the suggestion, I will. :-) Get yourself a
copy of apt-rpm and install it. It's easy, quick and wonderfully useful.
Then you can 'apt-get install ...', 'apt-get update ...' and so on. Very
handy during the 7.3 upgrade here.

Rich

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Wed Sep 11 13:34:47 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Wed, 11 Sep 2002 16:34:47 -0400 (EDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Re: results of running 1postfix
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0209110610410.17291-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0209111628150.9693-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

On Wed, 11 Sep 2002, Rich Shepard wrote:

>   I've just upgraded from RH 6.2 to 7.3 and I'm no longer receiving a dail
> mail message with the results of 1postfix running in /etc/cron.daily. The
> aliases file has 'root' set to my username.

  Found the culprit! I'll pass on the information in case others have the
same problem.

  The RH 7.3 installer installed sendmail as well as postfix. But, sendmail
was set as the default in /etc/rc.d/init.d/ and was hogging port 25. I found
and fixed that quickly enough. But, what I didn't track down until just now
is that the /etc/cron.daily/1postfix script calls /usr/sbin/sendmail.

  Turns out there are three files in /usr/sbin/ starting with sendmail:
sendmail, sendmail.postfix and sendmail.sendmail. The first is a soft link
to /etc/alternatives/mta, which is, itself, a softlink to
/usr/sbin/sendmail.sendmail! Wow! What a convoluted and cryptic mess.

  Anyway, I changed the link so that /etc/alternatives/mta now points to
/usr/sbin/sendmail.postfix and the script works.

  Can you believe this?

Rich

From creelan at engr.orst.edu  Wed Sep 11 18:09:48 2002
From: creelan at engr.orst.edu (Tyler F. Creelan)
Date: Wed, 11 Sep 2002 18:09:48 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Re: rpms
In-Reply-To: <20020911232324.GA27622@dalsemi.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0209111719260.23100-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>

> Wouldn't it be the easiest thing
> in the world to hack one of the repository machines, corrupt the
> RPMs with backdoors and automatic installation notifications and then
> alter the MD5 sum information so that it checks out?

FYI, this can also be done with source; last month
someone trojaned OpenSSH on the OpenBSD master ftp server, it even had time
to propagate to the mirrors:

http://www.linuxsecurity.com/advisories/other_advisory-2232.html

In the case of debian packages, if people used MD5sums from a different
source, your altered packages would not check out. You would have to crack
both the master MD5sum repository and, if they were distinct (not sure for
redhat) the master package repository, and replace only newly-updated
packages to avoid introducing inconsistencies with the other mirrors.
I think this would involve traversing fairly strong layers of security.

In terms of trusting the package authorship, in the Debian
system each package is signed with the GPG key of the package's
maintainer, or the maintainer's sponsor if the author has not
accumulated sufficient trust. I'm sure Karl has details/corrections...

http://www.debian.org/doc/developers-reference/

HTH,

Tyler

Redhat Software in its infinite wisdom stopped supporting.  Jacques 
Gelinas the author keeps enhancing and expanding it.  There have been 
some problems with versions and software that keeps changing (sendmail is 
one offender) and there is the time Redhat shipped a 'poorly' implemented

the best server configuration utiltity for the Redhat (RPM) derived 
distributions there is.  Text, GUI, or Web interfaces.  The GUI even works 
through a ssh tunnel.

> of RedHat 7.3 so I can ./configure? I got the ist 2 RH discs w/o the 3rd 
> and had trouble installing till I ignored the developement rpms. I've 
> now downloaded the 3rd disc .iso's and will install them, but I need 
> xcdroast and can't ./config it w/o the developement rpms.

Dirk,

  You have two options: mount the ISO image as a loopback device or burn it
on a cd-r first. You can use 'cdrecord' without xcdroast (man cdrecord) and
it works just as well.

  Xcdroast is a GUI front end to mkisofs and cdrecord. It's nice but not
necessary. I can pass you the command line I've been using and it works very
well.

Rich

From heinlein at attbi.com  Thu Sep 12 06:53:37 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Thu, 12 Sep 2002 06:53:37 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Developement rpms
In-Reply-To: <3D7FFB9C.4020500@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0209120640450.24569-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Wed, 11 Sep 2002, Dirk Ouellette wrote:

> And now once again. How do, get all of the developement rpms off
> disc 2 of RedHat 7.3 so I can ./configure? I got the ist 2 RH discs
> w/o the 3rd and had trouble installing till I ignored the
> developement rpms. I've now downloaded the 3rd disc .iso's and will
> install them, but I need xcdroast and can't ./config it w/o the
> developement rpms. Dirk

Dirk,

The answer to your question depends to a large extent on the list of 
packages you've already installed (or not installed) on your system.

Do you remember when you were installing Red Hat and you were given a 
list of package groups from which to choose: Base, Printing Support, X 
Window System, etc.?

A good way to get an idea of what packages you may or may not need is 
to look at the "Software Development" package listing. You can do this 
by poking around disk 1. Look for RedHat/base/comps. It's just a text 
file, and it's fairly easy to understand (I think). Search down until 
you see the "Software Development" listing. It'll look like this:

  0 Software Development {
    ? X Window System {
      Glide3-devel
      ...
    }
    ? Printing Support {
      VFlib2-devel
      ...
    }
    ...
    autoconf
    autoconf253
    automake
    automake15
    ...
    zlib-devel
  }

The "? X Window System" line means, "if we're installing the X Window 
System package group, then install these rpms; otherwise, skip them." 
There are quite a few of those conditional blocks before you get to 
the base list of development rpms (starting with 'autoconf').

Anyway, that list from autoconf to zlib-devel ought to be a good 
starting point. Install those packages and work from there.

Good luck.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>




From heinlein at attbi.com  Thu Sep 12 06:57:49 2002

I don't know much python, so I may be way off the mark -- but my hunch 
is that your script is a literal '\n\n' string, not two newlines, in 
your Content-Type description. Try this:

  print '''
  Content-Type: text/html

  <html>
  ...
  </html>
  '''

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

  This morning I learned that pointing "sendmail" to postfix rather than

Hat's "alternatives" system which is not too well documented, I've been

between KDE and Gnome, CUPS and LRPng, sendmail and postfix. Probably other
things, too.

From AthlonRob at data.lm.ro  Thu Sep 12 08:42:55 2002

On Thu, 2002-09-12 at 05:27, Rich Shepard wrote:
 
>   Does setting UTC=true set the time to that, but correct for the local time
> zone?

You set it to UTC=True if your hardware clock is set to UTC and you want
the operating system to account for that and subtract eight hours from
what the hardware clock reads to tell you what time it is.  How is that
for a long sentance?  :-)

From heinlein at attbi.com  Thu Sep 12 08:45:36 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Thu, 12 Sep 2002 08:45:36 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Setting the time properly
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0209120526090.20282-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0209120836100.24569-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Thu, 12 Sep 2002, Rich Shepard wrote:

> Does setting UTC=true set the time to that, but correct for the
> local time zone?

Honestly, I don't know. I've never played with that setting.

> Now that I've changed this, how do I implement the changes?

Take a look at /etc/rc.d/rc.sysinit. That's the boot script that, 
among other things, sets the time.

I think (but please verify this for yourself) that you'll want to

1. shut down ntpd

2. ensure that /etc/localtime == /usr/share/zoneinfo/US/Pacific; you 
   can copy the latter to the former if they differ

3. run "ntpdate" against a time server you trust

4. run "/sbin/hwclock --localtime --systohc" to get the hardware clock 
   in sync

5. restart ntpd

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

From fedorp at wv.mentorg.com  Thu Sep 12 09:11:54 2002
From: fedorp at wv.mentorg.com (Fedor G. Pikus)
Date: Thu, 12 Sep 2002 09:11:54 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] amd: needed or not?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0209120721050.19740-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.31.0209120907181.3251-100000@lorien.wv.mentorg.com>

1) amd is only needed if you want to mount nfs filesystems by hostname
(i.e. if you want to mount /net/scratchy and it automatically mounts
scratchy:/, or /net/itchy and then it's itchy:/). Otherwise use autofs
2) amd is crap even for /net filesystems, if you need them, use autofs4
3) if you have everything mounted statically, you can uninstall all
automounters, both amd and autofs. Everything here includes floppy and
cdrom. If you want to be able to do ls /mnt/cdrom and it gets mounted, you
need an automounter, but that automounter should be autofs. Sounds
convenient, but it's a pain in the ass to get that CD ejected because you
need to convince the automounter to let you unmount it.
Fedor

From heinlein at attbi.com  Thu Sep 12 09:31:45 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Thu, 12 Sep 2002 09:31:45 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Setting the time properly
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0209120620340.20744-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0209120926480.24569-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Thu, 12 Sep 2002, Rich Shepard wrote:

> On Thu, 12 Sep 2002, Paul Heinlein wrote:
> 
> > 2. ensure that /etc/localtime == /usr/share/zoneinfo/US/Pacific; you 
> >    can copy the latter to the former if they differ
> 
>   /etc/localtime is a binary here. Could that be the problem?

No: timezone files are binary. You ought to be able to use diff to 
tell if the files are the same, e.g.,

  diff /etc/localtime /usr/share/zoneinfo/US/Pacific

If they are different, it'd be worth trying 

  diff /etc/localtime /usr/share/zoneinfo/US/Eastern

just to make sure that your current EDT timestamp is the result of an 
understandable error.

If you want to be in the Pacific timezone (not necessarily a given: I
know you folks out in Gresham have weather patterns the differ
somewhat significantly from those in the rest of the Willamette and
Columbia valleys, so maybe a new timezone is appropriate too :-), then
just

  cp /usr/share/zoneinfo/US/Pacific /etc/localtime

and go ahead with the process I outlined in an earlier message.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

> I think apt is a bit better because you can use the official debian site
> to get all your .debs.

I'm questioning the combination of the two (apt-rpm), but in general
the use of automated downloads and installs.

Tyler's answer pointed out the use of MD5 sums, but for apt-rpm I think
there's only 1 repository (freshrpms.net) so it's a single point of
potential attack.

Colin



From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Thu Sep 12 09:28:57 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Thu, 12 Sep 2002 09:28:57 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Setting the time properly
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0209120836100.24569-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0209120925370.20744-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

On Thu, 12 Sep 2002, Paul Heinlein wrote:

> 1. shut down ntpd
> 
> 2. ensure that /etc/localtime == /usr/share/zoneinfo/US/Pacific; you 
>    can copy the latter to the former if they differ
> 
> 3. run "ntpdate" against a time server you trust
> 
> 4. run "/sbin/hwclock --localtime --systohc" to get the hardware clock 
>    in sync
> 
> 5. restart ntpd

  Wow! That's magnificent, Paul! It worked like a charm.

  I copied the binary /etc/localtime to a backup form, put the string
'/usr/share/timezoneinfo/US/Pacific' in it and followed the rest of the
instructions. The only part that was slightly disconcering was running
'/usr/sbin/npdate npt.nasa.gov' and having the entire screen instantly go
black -- no cursor or anything. Then, of course, it came back up and all's
right again with the world.

  Wadda' hassle! I've no idea how it got clobbered the way it did.

Many thanks,

Rich

From russj at dimstar.net  Thu Sep 12 09:48:31 2002
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: Thu, 12 Sep 2002 09:48:31 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Setting the time properly
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0209120439030.20282-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <3D80C55F.6050505@dimstar.net>

Rich Shepard wrote:

>  I found the 'tzset' command and used that to specify Pacific Time Zone.
>Then I put the TZ set string in ~/.bash_profile as well as for root and the
>other user on the system here. That's all well and good.
>
>  However, when I logged out and back in (so the new setting would take
>effect from the re-reading of .bash_profile) and typed 'date' on the command
>line, I saw that it was three hours behind the real time (I've ntpd running;
>it's exactly 3 hours behind). But, when I start X and ask for the date in a
>virtual terminal, it displays:
>
>[rshepard at salmo ~]$ date
>Thu Sep 12 04:38:34 PDT 2002
>
>  Correct time zone, wrong time. When I su I see this:
>
>[root at salmo /home/rshepard]# /usr/sbin/hwclock -r 
>Thu 12 Sep 2002 07:37:56 AM EDT  0.536746 seconds
>[root at salmo /home/rshepard]# date
>Thu Sep 12 07:38:06 EDT 2002
>
>  Correct time, wrong time zone.
>
>  What might be going on here?
>
In /etc/sysconfig, there's a file called 'clock'. In that file, is the 
following:

$ cat clock
ZONE="America/Los_Angeles"
UTC=false
ARC=false

I believe this is were the clock gets set during boot, in relation to 
the hardware clock. If you have the hardware clock set to UTC, make sure 
that's "true" instead of "false".

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Thu Sep 12 09:47:46 2002

Subject: [PLUG] amd: needed or not?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.31.0209120907181.3251-100000@lorien.wv.mentorg.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0209120946520.20744-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

On Thu, 12 Sep 2002, Fedor G. Pikus wrote:

> 1) amd is only needed if you want to mount nfs filesystems by hostname
> (i.e. if you want to mount /net/scratchy and it automatically mounts
> scratchy:/, or /net/itchy and then it's itchy:/). Otherwise use autofs
> 2) amd is crap even for /net filesystems, if you need them, use autofs4
> 3) if you have everything mounted statically, you can uninstall all
> automounters, both amd and autofs. Everything here includes floppy and
> cdrom. If you want to be able to do ls /mnt/cdrom and it gets mounted, you
> need an automounter, but that automounter should be autofs. Sounds
> convenient, but it's a pain in the ass to get that CD ejected because you
> need to convince the automounter to let you unmount it.

Fedor,

  Thanks very much. I suppose that I slightly understood what they did, but
now I understand much more. They're now shut off.

Not suprising. The web site has been pretty broken for a long time.  Many 
people have stopped looking there at all because of the delays.

> Is there a way I should have known about this prior to asking on the list?

Asking is about the only way you will find out.

Now since I am only going from the title, I am assuming you were wanting 
information on DVD players for Linux.

The best so far is Xine.  It is kind of a pain to set up.  There are RPMs 
available, but they require the aalib RPMs, which are not standard on most 
distributions.  (Which is a shame because they are kind of cool.)

You need the decss libraries and the dvdread libraries. Those can be 
found with the RPMs for Xine.  (Look around at 
http://xine.sourceforge.com/ for external links. One of them will send you 
to the site with the proper RPMs.

If you have a problem, drop me an e-mail.




From russj at dimstar.net  Thu Sep 12 09:57:25 2002
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: Thu, 12 Sep 2002 09:57:25 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Re: rpms
References: <20020911232324.GA27622@dalsemi.com> <Pine.GSO.4.44.0209111632040.22814-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU> <20020912163107.GC28430@dalsemi.com>
Message-ID: <3D80C775.90700@dimstar.net>

Colin Kuskie wrote:

>I'm questioning the combination of the two (apt-rpm), but in general
>the use of automated downloads and install
>

Well, when using pgp, you're using a public/private keypair. What this 
means is that (in theory) the only way to trojan the files would be to 
get the key Redhat uses to sign the RPMs they release. The key we have 
to verify the signature can only verify, it can't create.

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Thu Sep 12 10:01:31 2002

On Thu, 12 Sep 2002, Dirk Ouellette wrote:

> Does the loopback device allow me to install the 3rd.iso directly from the hdd onto the same hdd, negating the need to burn a 3rd CD?

Dirk,

  Yup.

  Here's an example line to get you started:

mount -o loop,ro image_name /mnt

  Now you can copy from your read-only image on /mnt to whereever you want.

From derek at infotects.com  Thu Sep 12 11:00:58 2002
From: derek at infotects.com (Derek Loree)
Date: 12 Sep 2002 11:00:58 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Mouse problems w/  XFree on Debian Laptop
In-Reply-To: <3D80BDF4.3000901@logiccloud.com>
References: <3D80BDF4.3000901@logiccloud.com>
Message-ID: <1031853659.14011.27518.camel@dereklinux>

On Thu, 2002-09-12 at 09:16, Ben Prew wrote:
> So I recently installed Debian 3.0r0 on my Toshiba Satellite 315CDS and 
> I was having some problems getting the mouse pointer to cooperate in 
> XFree86 4.1.0.1.  Specifically, the mouse pointer will "freeze up" after 
> about 15 seconds and will then move erraticaly and is generally 
> unresponsive.  I have tried several different drivers in my XF86Config 
> (mouseman, MSMouse and PS/2).  PS/2 is the only one that works properly, 
> so I don't think its a driver problem.  Also, I have gpm setup and using 
> the mouse in the console works fine.  And, it doesn't matter what window 
> manager I use, Gnome, ICW-WM, XTerm (for testing), the mouse displays 
> the same behavior.  I've looked at the output from XFree, and there are 
> no warnings (WW) or errors (EE).  Now, I know this mouse works, because 
> I had Redhat 7.2 installed on this laptop previously and it worked fine 
> in X (using Windowmaker as my WM).  
> 
> So, my questions are:
> 
> 1.  Is there some setting I am missing?  Maybe something Redhat 
> installed by default that debian didn't?

Sounds like it is the other way around, Debian installed gpm, RH didn't.
> 
> 2.  Is X4.1.0.1 the latest debian package?  I noticed x4.2.1 was out on 
> www.xfree86.org.  I did an apt-get update XFree86.  How can I tell what 
> version of X has been .deb'ed?
> 
> 3.  I am assuming that X is turning off GPM... could this be a possible 
> problem or conflict?

Incorrect assumption, in this case, both gpm and the X-server are trying
to read from the same device at the same time.  The fix is easy, you
just need to set up the X-server to read from /dev/gpmdata instead of
/dev/psaux.  If you allowed debconf to handle your X-server
configuration, then I think the command to reconfigure the X-server is:

dpkg-reconfigure xserver-xfree86

which must be run as root.

Good Luck

Derek Loree

> Well, when using pgp, you're using a public/private keypair. What this
> means is that (in theory) the only way to trojan the files would be to
> get the key Redhat uses to sign the RPMs they release.

In theory you could also introduce your trojan in such
a way that the modified rpm hashes to the same value. While not yet
practical for MD5, such techniques for eliciting collisions and
pseudo-collisions have been shown:

Dobbertin, H. (1996). "The Status of Md5 After a Recent
Attack," RSA Laboratories' CryptoBytes, Volume 2, Number 2.
ftp://ftp.rsasecurity.com/pub/cryptobytes/crypto2n2.pdf

Tyler

Tyler F. Creelan

From galens at seitzassoc.com  Thu Sep 12 13:51:53 2002
From: galens at seitzassoc.com (Galen Seitz)
Date: Thu, 12 Sep 2002 13:51:53 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Setting the time properly 
In-Reply-To: Your message of "Thu, 12 Sep 2002 09:28:57 PDT."
             <Pine.LNX.4.44.0209120925370.20744-100000@appl-ecosys.com> 
Message-ID: <200209122051.g8CKpr216545@tinman.seitzassoc.com>

rshepard at appl-ecosys.com said:
>   Wow! That's magnificent, Paul! It worked like a charm.
>   I copied the binary /etc/localtime to a backup form, put the string
> '/usr/share/timezoneinfo/US/Pacific' in it and followed the rest of
> the instructions. The only part that was slightly disconcering was
> running '/usr/sbin/npdate npt.nasa.gov' and having the entire screen
> instantly go black -- no cursor or anything. Then, of course, it came
> back up and all's right again with the world. 

Be sure to remove those TZ=... entries from your profile.  It's very
unusual to be messing with TZ in any of the shell startup files.

BTW, the screen went black because the screensaver kicked in due to a 
big time step.  Whenever you adjust the system time, beware
of cron funnies.  In past it could get confused when the time was stepped.
Current versions may not have this problem.  I usually stop and restart
cron after any system time adjustment.

galen

ps  I was on vacation.  That's why you didn't see the standard kermit
    response to the serial question.

> uses /boot/vmlinuz if that helps.

It's for a book I'm writing. In a lab exercise, the reader must
know the name and location of the kernel file. The reviewers
think that it's not enough to tell the reader that it's most
often in the /boot directory and frequently has a name that
starts with "vmlinuz". They'd like a list of the names for
various distributions. 

This is the kind of book where you must tell the reader to press
Enter after every command. I'm beginning to think the book should
come with crayons and coupons for a Happy Meal.

Ed

From don at truedisk.com  Thu Sep 12 15:07:04 2002
From: don at truedisk.com (Don Buchholz)
Date: Thu, 12 Sep 2002 15:07:04 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] kernel file names and locations
References: <1031847412.22414.113.camel@red> 	<1031854522.2207.24.camel@duron> <1031866111.24049.44.camel@red>
Message-ID: <3D811008.1060809@truedisk.com>

For RH 7.1 and 7.3, RedHat has been creating the symlink:
    vmlinuz -> vmlinuz-2.4.yy-zz  
inside of /boot.

It makes their 'up2date' process simpler, I think.  Since they
don't have to modify /etc/lilo.conf (7.1) or /etc/grub.conf (7.3)
since the config files use "/boot/vmlinuz" to refer to the kernel.

From dealy at deatech.com  Thu Sep 12 18:51:17 2002

On Thu, 12 Sep 2002, Rich Shepard wrote:

[snip]
> Apparently, trying to get WP/8 working -- even with glibc-5 installed -- is
> a lost cause.
[snip]

I have WP/8 working on one of my systems running the current Debian stable
(Woody).  The only problem I had with it was that it would seg-fault
everytime I tried to fire it up after the initial upgrade to Woody.  After
much hair pulling and assorted incantations of a four letter variety :-)
I realized that it was failing because it couldn't find some font or fonts
it apparently requires.  Eventually, I discovered and tried the
"-useISOFonts" command line option, for starting the program and it has
worked fine ever since.  Interestingly, it only seems to require the
"-useISOFonts" option some of the time, the rest of the time it fires up
without the option.  ldd command shows the following library dependencies
for the main program (xwp):

	libXt.so.6 => /usr/i486-linuxlibc1/lib/libXt.so.6 (0x40015000)
	libX11.so.6 => /usr/i486-linuxlibc1/lib/libX11.so.6 (0x40058000)
	libXpm.so.4 => /usr/lib/libc5-compat/libXpm.so.4 (0x400f9000)
	libm.so.5 => /lib/libm.so.5 (0x40107000)
	libc.so.5 => /lib/libc.so.5 (0x40110000)
	libSM.so.6 => /usr/i486-linuxlibc1/lib/libSM.so.6 (0x401ce000)
	libICE.so.6 => /usr/i486-linuxlibc1/lib/libICE.so.6 (0x401d7000)

FWIW

  Thank you, my friend. That's worth a _lot_! For some reason, I don't think

[rshepard at salmo ~]$ ldd /usr1/wp8/wpbin/xwp
        /lib/libNoVersion.so.1 => /lib/libNoVersion.so.1 (0x40014000)
        libXt.so.6 => /usr/X11R6/lib/libXt.so.6 (0x4002a000)
        libX11.so.6 => /usr/X11R6/lib/libX11.so.6 (0x40076000)
        libXpm.so.4 => /usr/X11R6/lib/libXpm.so.4 (0x4014b000)
        libm.so.5 => /usr/lib/libm.so.5 (0x4015a000)
        libc.so.5 => /usr/lib/libc.so.5 (0x40162000)
        libc.so.6 => /lib/i686/libc.so.6 (0x42000000)
        libSM.so.6 => /usr/X11R6/lib/libSM.so.6 (0x4022c000)
        libICE.so.6 => /usr/X11R6/lib/libICE.so.6 (0x40234000)
        libdl.so.2 => /lib/libdl.so.2 (0x4024b000)
        /lib/ld-linux.so.1 => /lib/ld-linux.so.1 (0x40000000)

  So, I'll make sure all the libs are where the program is looking for them,
and I'll try your command line switch, too.

  Another valuable lesson reinforced.

From dealy at deatech.com  Thu Sep 12 22:14:53 2002
From: dealy at deatech.com (Shannon C. Dealy)
Date: Thu, 12 Sep 2002 22:14:53 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] help with pppd (wvdial)
In-Reply-To: <20020912024534.A1894@defiant.ncplus.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0209122146410.29842-100000@critter.deatech.com>

On Thu, 12 Sep 2002, Bruce Kingsland wrote:

[snip]
> wvdial successfully negotiates the login, and then:
>
> login:
> --> Looks like a login prompt.
> --> Sending: asavage
> asavage
> password:
> --> Looks like a password prompt.
> --> Sending: (password)
> --> Don't know what to do!  Starting pppd and hoping for the best.
> --> Starting pppd at Thu Sep 12 02:32:37 2002
> --> PPP daemon has died! (exit code = 16)
> --> Disconnecting at Thu Sep 12 02:32:39 2002
> --> Auto Reconnect will be attempted in 10 seconds
> --> pppd error!  Look at files in /var/log for an explanation.
> --> Initializing modem.
[snip]
> Any ideas?

[snip]
> supports windoze and OS/2 just fine, and I have shell access to a
> linux system thru ssh (when I connect thru an ethernet port). They
> don't know why it doesn't work for me, as others connect just fine;
[snip]

I know zip about wvdial, but entirely to much about pppd.  What you really
need here is the raw character output of this session so you can see what
wvdial actually sees.  You might check if there is an option to wvdial
which will output all of the character I/O which it was involved in.  This
will tell you if wvdial is responding correctly to the prompts that it
sees and is behaving correctly up to the point where it starts pppd.
If this doesn't solve the problem, next you will want to look at what
happens during the ppp session, you can capture this using the "record"
option for pppd (see pppd manpage).  How you set this depends on how
wvdial operates, but normally it would be placed in the configuration file
for your ISP in the directory (possibly distribution specific)
/etc/ppp/peers  Once you have run with the record option, you could
examine the file specified by the record option using the pppdump command
(usually with the -p option), though if I remember right, I think ethereal
understands this format and may give an even more readable rendition of
the data in the capture file.

My guesses as to what might be happening are:

1-Your initial login is failing, so you are effectively dead when wvdial
  drops you into ppp.  This would imply that wvdial is not responding to
  the correct prompts, or that your username/password are configured
  incorrectly.  I was not entirely clear from what you said whether or not
  you were trying to log in to your old pacifier account through a third
  party pop, or if you just switched ISP's, if it's the former, then your
  problem may be that you aren't using the right login id, since third
  party pop login's generally require the name of the ISP you are
  connecting to and are likely to want a login name of

       asavage at pacifier.com

  or something similar.


2-The ISP wants to authenticate within the ppp session using PAP and you
  are not correctly configured for PAP authentication, however, the
  information you gave above seems to indicate that a text mode login was
  performed prior to starting pppd, and (so far) I've never seen an ISP
  require performing the same authentication twice, once before the
  session and once from within it.

Hope this helps.

Phone: (800) 467-5820 | Networking, Scientific & Engineering Applications
   or: (541) 451-5177 |                  www.deatech.com

From griffint at aracnet.com  Fri Sep 13 09:34:19 2002
From: griffint at aracnet.com (Terry Griffin)
Date: Fri, 13 Sep 2002 09:34:19 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Forcing numbering of ethernet interfaces?
Message-ID: <200209131634.g8DGYJu29863@shell1.aracnet.com>

I think I know the answer to this which is "You can't do it" but
I'll ask anyway.

Got a machine running Red Hat 7.3 with three ethernet interfaces,
two on the PCI bus and one on the USB bus. The USB NIC is coming
up as eth0 and the PCI NIC's are coming up and eth1 and eth2.
We'd really rather have the PCI NIC's as eth0 and eth1 with the
USB NIC as eth2. This would make it consistent with the numbering
you get if you plug in the USB NIC after system boot. Is there a way
to force this?

Two ideas have come up so far. One was to try and force it via
alias settings in /etc/modules.conf and then disabling kudzu to
make sure it doesn't get modified during boot. This didn't do it.

The second idea which we've not tried yet is to build a kernel
with the PCI NIC drivers built in, but leave the USB NIC driver
built as a module. The non-module drivers ought to initialize
first thus giving them first shot at the interface numbers.

Any other ideas?

Terry

Terry Griffin <griffint at pobox.com>
http://www.blindchicken.com/~terryg/

From srau at rauhaus.org  Fri Sep 13 09:47:27 2002
From: srau at rauhaus.org (Stafford A. Rau)
Date: Fri, 13 Sep 2002 09:47:27 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] .bugtrac: what is that?
In-Reply-To: <1031933991.32737.1199.camel@lana.manymoons.net>
References: <1031933174.1413.1190.camel@lana.manymoons.net> <20020913161037.GB27111@rauhaus.org> <1031933991.32737.1199.camel@lana.manymoons.net>
Message-ID: <20020913164727.GC27111@rauhaus.org>

* Jon Jacob <jon at manymoons.net> [020913 09:20]:
> No, I don't.  The logs don't immediately show anything, but I am not
> sure what to look for.
> 
> I have an IPChains firewall up, but of course port 80 is open for the
> web server.

Some of the things you might want to do:

Do an "lsof -i" as root, and save the output. This will tell you what
processes are bound to which tcp & udp ports. See if those bugtrac
processes are actually listening to any ports.

Do a "find /dev -type f -print" to see if there are any regular files
(with the possible exception of a MAKEDEV script) that shouldn't be
under /dev.

If you have something like a distribution install cd, put it in and mount it,
and use the executables from it rather than ones that might have been
trojaned on your machine.

Do a "ps aux" with your possibly suspect installed version of ps, and
then do an "ls /proc". Compare the pids from your ps with the ones in
/proc. There will be a couple different ones, as the pid of your ps and
of your ls will be different, but any others that are missing from the
"ps" but are in /proc will tell you that your ps command is trojaned.

Run nmap from a different machine, or have someone do it for you, and
do a full port scan of your machine.

I'm not saying that you've definitely been rooted, as it may be that
those bugtrac processes are just a red herring and belong to a
legitimate package. I wish I hadn't deleted the mailing list post that
I'm recalling, but it would probably have been from one of the
securityfocus.com mailing lists.

--Stafford

Subject: bugtraq.c httpd apache ssl attack



I am using RedHat 7.3 with Apache 1.3.23. Someone used the 
program "bugtraq.c" to explore an modSSL buffer overflow to get access to 
a shell. The attack creates a file named "/tmp/.bugtraq.c" and compiles it 
using gcc. The program is started with another computer ip address as 
argument. All computer files that the user "apache" can read are exposed.
The program attacks the following Linux distributions:

Red-Hat: Apache 1.3.6,1.3.9,1.3.12,1.3.19,1.3.20,1.3.22,1.3.23,1.3.26
SuSe: Apache 1.3.12,1.3.17,1.3.19,1.3.20,1.3.23
Mandrake: 1.3.14,1.3.19
Slakware: Apache 1.3.26

Regards
Fernando Nunes
Portugal

From deanm at sharplabs.com  Fri Sep 13 11:54:42 2002
From: deanm at sharplabs.com (Dean S. Messing)
Date: Fri, 13 Sep 2002 11:54:42 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] bash / find question
Message-ID: <20020913185442.A94D717902@medulla>

I can't seem to find the right permuation  to get
the `find ... -exec ... \;' to work in general.

If I do something like:

  find $DIR -type f -exec $COMMAND $ARGS {} \;

it works just fine.


But I can't figure out how to do  a shell operation like,
say, output redirection _within the -exec command block_.
N.B.: I'm not interested in re-directing the output of `find'
to a file.  That's easy.

To be specific suppose I want, on each instance of the command w/in
the -exec block,  to output something to a file named {}.foo.

How do I do this?  I've tried the obvious (but wrong)

  find $DIR -type f -exec $COMMAND $ARGS {} > {}.foo \;

I've tried escaping the redirection thus:

  find $DIR -type f -exec $COMMAND $ARGS {} \> {}.foo \;

I've tried also (and only) escaping the  {}  (which
I normally never escape).

And I've tried double quoting  various substrings of

         $COMMAND $ARGS {} > {}.foo

Now I'm going to try asking you.

What is the general form of the stuff following -exec
when you have pipes, multiple cammands &c.

Thanks.
Dean

Stafford;

I just performed research on this. Here's your answer:

This attack is a variation of the GOBBLES exploit and affects Apache servers thro ugh v. 1.3.26 according to this sight:

  http://packetstorm.decepticons.org/filedesc/apache-worm.c.html
  
As this is a variation of a known exploit, it was effectively fixed by the Apache team before it was created; the exploit was closed on 21 June 2002 with Apache v . 1.3.26.

From srau at rauhaus.org  Fri Sep 13 12:45:38 2002

Here's more on the ssl worm, and a request from a guy at
securityfocus.com for info from people with compromised hosts.

--Stafford

----- Forwarded message from Dave Ahmad <da at securityfocus.com> -----

Date: Fri, 13 Sep 2002 11:28:51 -0600 (MDT)
From: Dave Ahmad <da at securityfocus.com>
To: Ben Laurie <ben at algroup.co.uk>
Subject: Re: OpenSSL worm in the wild
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.43.0209131118440.7298-100000 at mail.securityfocus.com>

Ok,

The incident analysis team over here is examining this thing.  At first
glance it looks reasonably sophisticated.  Looks to me like it exploits
the issue described as BID 5363, http://online.securityfocus.com/bid/5363.
It seems to pick targets based on the "Server:" HTTP response field.
Mario Van Velzen proposed a quick workaround of disabling ServerTokens or
setting it to ProductOnly to turn away at least this version of the exploit
until fixes can be applied.  Another thing to note is that it communicates
with its friends over UDP / port 2002.

I'd like to request IP addresses of hosts that have been compromised or
that are currently attacking systems from anyone who is comfortable
sharing this information.  We wish to run it through TMS (formerly
known as ARIS) to see how quickly it is propagating.

David Ahmad
Symantec
http://www.symantec.com/

From dealy at deatech.com  Fri Sep 13 13:55:17 2002
From: dealy at deatech.com (Shannon C. Dealy)
Date: Fri, 13 Sep 2002 13:55:17 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Forcing numbering of ethernet interfaces?
In-Reply-To: <200209131958.g8DJwW512851@shell1.aracnet.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0209131347280.32585-100000@critter.deatech.com>

On Fri, 13 Sep 2002, Terry Griffin wrote:

[snip]
> > > Got a machine running Red Hat 7.3 with three ethernet interfaces,
> > > two on the PCI bus and one on the USB bus. The USB NIC is coming
> > > up as eth0 and the PCI NIC's are coming up and eth1 and eth2.
> > > We'd really rather have the PCI NIC's as eth0 and eth1 with the
> > > USB NIC as eth2. This would make it consistent with the numbering
> > > you get if you plug in the USB NIC after system boot. Is there a way
> > > to force this?
>
> Booting without initrd is not an option. This is SCSI-based system.
> But you give me an idea. Can I make a custom initrd that makes things
> come out in the right order?
[snip]

Yes you could make a custom initrd which would allow you to preload
modules in the desired order before the system boots.  I don't know how
Red Hat handles this, but on Debian all that is necessary is to modify the
file /etc/mkinitrd/modules to specify the modules you want to load, then
reconfigure or reinstall the initrd kernel image and run lilo (or whatever
your preferred boot loader is).  It might also be necessary to modify
/etc/mkinitrd/mkinitrd.conf to ensure that the module you need is included
in the initrd image before reconfiguring the kernel installation.

FWIW

Phone: (800) 467-5820 | Networking, Scientific & Engineering Applications
   or: (541) 451-5177 |                  www.deatech.com

From 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com  Fri Sep 13 14:41:50 2002
From: 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com (Steve Bonds)
Date: Fri, 13 Sep 2002 14:41:50 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] http://safari.oreilly.com/
Message-ID: <1540683726.1031953314157.JavaMail.root@monkey>

On Fri, 13 Sep 2002, Jason Dagit dagit at engr.orst.edu XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX wrote:

> Has anyone used O'Reilly's safari system?  Is it economical?  Is it
> nice? What do you people think of it?

I use it.  It's very nice if you have lots of time to kill and want to
learn something.  (Unfortunately, I fear that there are lots of folks out
there right now with too much time to kill.)

The $10/month subscription is a great way to try it out.  Even if you only
read one book that month, you'll come out ahead.  For $40/month you could
get a decent online reference library going-- but the economics of that
get a bit rough.  It seems to be more economical if you "churn" the books
more by removing access from old books and adding in new ones.

One hint: always keep one slot free for that book you simply MUST add on
short notice.  With their bookshelf system you can always add a book, but
can only remove books every 30 days.  I clear it out monthly and often end
up adding in the same books-- but not always.

Their anti-spidering code is pretty sensitive.  Don't try any direct URL
mods or you'll probably trigger it.  Some caching proxies will trigger it
as well.  They've been pretty understanding with me since I respond to
each E-mail I get on it with an "oops!, sorry", but they ARE watching, and
I suspect if these E-mails are ignored they'll close the account.

It also seems to be quite alternative-browser friendly.  (Works with
Konqueror 3.0)

The cons:
  + Online only, if your net is down, so is your book access
  + HTML format has its limits

And a BIG BIG warning:

YOU WILL GET SPAM as a result of signing up with Safari.  I'm still
tracking down how this happens, but in the meantime I highly suggest that
you use http://www.sneakemail.com to generate a unique E-mail only for
Safari.

All in all, a GREAT service, and one well worth checking out.

  -- Steve

From creswick at cs.orst.edu  Fri Sep 13 15:04:32 2002
From: creswick at cs.orst.edu (Rogan Creswick)
Date: Fri, 13 Sep 2002 15:04:32 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] bash / find question
In-Reply-To: <20020913185442.A94D717902@medulla>
References: <20020913185442.A94D717902@medulla>
Message-ID: <20020913220432.GE1311@jade.CS.ORST.EDU>

> To be specific suppose I want, on each instance of the command w/in
> the -exec block,  to output something to a file named {}.foo.
> 

find will only replace the first occurrence of {} with the "found" file, so
you have to write a script of sorts:


$ find $DIR -type f | \
	while read file \
		do $COMMAND $ARGS "$file" > "$file".foo \
	done

(that is all one command)

I just pulled the above out of "Unix Power Tools" and haven't tested it, so
you should :)

I imagine something like this would work also:

$ find $DIR -type f -exec FILE={} && $COMMAND $ARGS $FILE > $FILE.foo \;

-Rogan

> How do I do this?  I've tried the obvious (but wrong)
> 
>   find $DIR -type f -exec $COMMAND $ARGS {} > {}.foo \;
> 
> I've tried escaping the redirection thus:
> 
>   find $DIR -type f -exec $COMMAND $ARGS {} \> {}.foo \;
> 
> I've tried also (and only) escaping the  {}  (which
> I normally never escape).
> 
> And I've tried double quoting  various substrings of
> 
>          $COMMAND $ARGS {} > {}.foo
> 
> Now I'm going to try asking you.
> 
> What is the general form of the stuff following -exec
> when you have pipes, multiple cammands &c.
> 
> Thanks.
> Dean
>

From m at netpro.to  Fri Sep 13 15:12:50 2002

On 13 Sep 2002, Jon Jacob wrote:

> Okay, I need to upgrade OpenSSL but it also sounded like it would best
> to upgrade Apache as well or is the OpenSSL upgrade part of that.

You'll want to upgrade Apache as well because every version that's shipped
with RedHat (even up to 7.3) is vulnerable to the chunk encoding stack
overflow vulnerability.

> If the thing is running as Apache, then it shouldn't have access to a
> whole lot, right?  Or am I being naive?

Correct.  The worm wouldn't have root access, but it can still infect
other computers and be used in DDoS attacks, for example.




From derek at infotects.com  Fri Sep 13 15:20:49 2002
From: derek at infotects.com (Derek Loree)
Date: 13 Sep 2002 15:20:49 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Galeon - the experience
In-Reply-To: <3D7FE183.A69F827A@attbi.com>
References: <3D7FE183.A69F827A@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <1031955649.2524.27644.camel@dereklinux>

On Wed, 2002-09-11 at 17:36, Richard Steffens wrote:
> Are there configuration issues that would markedly affect the apparent
> speediness of Galeon, or Mozilla? When I run my machine under Windows,
> using either IE or Netscape 4.7, download times are very quick (I'm on
> cable). But, when I run either Galeon or Mozilla, under Linux, they
> really crawl. Is there anything I can do to speed things up?

This would have to be characterized much better in order to start
troubleshooting it.  Do other apps download slow as well (like ftp or
sftp)?  What does ifconfig show for the ethernet device?  What is the
ethernet device?

In general, the default settings for Winblows is designed for dial-up
connection speeds, and you're lucky if it responds well to cable speeds,
linux defaults are usually geared to ethernet communication, and almost
always respond well to cable speeds.

Give us more to go on.

Derek Loree

From derek at infotects.com  Fri Sep 13 16:27:36 2002
From: derek at infotects.com (Derek Loree)
Date: 13 Sep 2002 16:27:36 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] FW: Nessus
In-Reply-To: <006501c25b7b$fae4d140$02a8a8c0@Jim>
References: <006501c25b7b$fae4d140$02a8a8c0@Jim>
Message-ID: <1031959656.14011.27648.camel@dereklinux>

On Fri, 2002-09-13 at 16:19, Jim Webb wrote:
> 
> I'm trying to get Nessus to run.  I installed the nessus vulnerability
> scanner, but I'm unable to start the nessus daemon. I found it in
> /usr/local/sbin where it has 755 for permissions.  I'm logged in as su root.
> bash told me that "bash: nessusd: command not found".  And I can start the
> nessus client.

You don't have the root environment, you need to put a - between the su
and the root (like: su - root) to inherit the root environment.

OTOH, if you specify full path name, it will work
(like:/usr/local/sbin/nessusd).

HTH

Derek Loree

From deathfox at moochercrew.org  Fri Sep 13 22:12:39 2002

file it lists an address that does not allow binding.  Sometimes the

My sugestion would be to double check your IP addy and put that into
your conf file.

Chris

Thanks to all those who helped me figure out what was up with that
annoying bugtraq thing.

I have upgraded my Apache, and since the new version does not load the
module for openssl, I think I am okay.  (Makes me wonder why I needed to
upgrade that and not just diable openssl, but I am here now so what can
i do?)

I was not able, yet, to find an rpm that will upgrade my OpenSSL without
getting rid of libcrypto.so.2 which Evolution requires.  So, I am
staying with the same version of OpenSSL with the dummy of bugtraq in my
/tmp file (setting it to mode 000, so the intruder cannot place another
one or use it in any way).  I will continue to try and upgrade OpenSSL,
but right now I feel reasonably secure.

Anyway, just wanted to update you all and say thanks.

From revans at e-z.net  Sat Sep 14 03:45:05 2002
From: revans at e-z.net (Russell Evans)
Date: Sat, 14 Sep 2002 03:45:05 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Desktop Calendar
In-Reply-To: <20020914053140.65258.qmail@web14406.mail.yahoo.com>
References: <20020914053140.65258.qmail@web14406.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <20020914104436.YKDB23613.sccrmhc02.attbi.com@dhcp-320-212>

I have half an answer. netpbm-9.24, pscal-1.15, xsetbg from xli-1.16, and I
think montage from ImageMagick-5.4.2


#!/bin/sh
pscal `date +%m" "%Y` |  pstopnm  |  pnmflip -r270  |  pnmtojpeg > cal.jpg
montage ( some magic here ) cal.jpg back.jpg dayback.jpg
xsetbg /pathto/dayback.jpg

The half I don't have is how to combine the background image I have on my
desktop ( back.jpg ) and the cal.jpg. I thought montage would work to combine
them. It would need to allow me to set the cal.jpg to some small size, say
100x100+0+0  ( top left corner of the root window ) on top of the 1024x768,
back.jpg. Anyone know if montage will do this and the command syntax needed? I
tried what I thought the man page specified without success.


A really simple way to do this would be to use cal from util-linux-2.11, date
from sh-utils-2.0 and root-tail. 

#!/bin/sh
cal > month.cal 
echo "" >> month.cal
echo"	    "`date +%D`  >> month.cal	 # need the spaces to alaign the date
in the middle  
root-tail -i 86400 -font -adobe-courier-medium-r-*-*-18-*-*-*-*-*-*-* -g
60x10+100+100  -color blue month.cal


You also could use xfclock with the noborder, staysonbottom, sticky,
windowlistskip options in xfce.

Thank you
Russell

On 13 Sep 2002, Jon Jacob wrote:

> What does the upgrade get me?

  Packages built with the latest version of rpm won't install with an older
version. You lose nothing and gain more ability with newer packages.

From heinlein at attbi.com  Sat Sep 14 10:07:18 2002

On Sat, 14 Sep 2002, Dan Young wrote:

> So I'm a  little late to the party again, but it looks like Redhat
> backported the bugfix to 1.3.22, FWIW:
> 
> https://rhn.redhat.com/network/errata/errata_details.pxt?eid=1100
> 
> "We have backported the security fix from the official Apache 1.3.26
> release. This should help minimize the impact of upgrading to our
> errata packages."

This is Red Hat's m.o. The rule seems to be that Red Hat will try to 
keep a package at a stable version number whenever possible. That 
means that if a security fix can be back-ported, it will be.

This is really nice for us who don't want to worry about whether our 
current config files will work with the next package that comes down 
the pike. Or whether other dependencies will be broken.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

works with KDE3, YMMV.	I didn't test the year end month rolls, i.e. current
