For the extremely security conscious and the overly curious, I note the
following limitations:

	1) there's no attempt (yet) to verify the signature on the
	pubkey before verifying the package signature.

	2) there's no attempt (yet) to implement any trust model using
	OpenPGP packets. All imported keys in the rpm database are considered
	trusted.

	3) only V3 signatures are implemented ATM.

If that's not to your taste, then you can export the signature from a
package and verify using gpg outside of rpm. For example, here's a
short script that verifies the traditional header+payload signatures of
a package using gpg:

==========================================================================
#!/bin/sh

for pkg in $*
do
    if [ "$pkg" = "" -o ! -e "$pkg" ]; then
	echo "no package supplied" 1>&2
	exit 1
    fi

    plaintext=`mktemp $0-$$.XXXXXX`
    detached=`mktemp $0-$$.XXXXXX`

# --- Extract detached signature
    rpm -qp -vv --qf '%{siggpg:armor}' $pkg > $detached

# --- Figger the offset of header+payload in the package
    leadsize=96
    o=`expr $leadsize + 8`

    set `od -j $o -N 8 -t u1 $pkg`
    il=`expr 256 \* \( 256 \* \( 256 \* $2 + $3 \) + $4 \) + $5`
    dl=`expr 256 \* \( 256 \* \( 256 \* $6 + $7 \) + $8 \) + $9`

    sigsize=`expr 8 + 16 \* $il + $dl`
    o=`expr $o + $sigsize + \( 8 - \( $sigsize \% 8 \) \) \% 8`

# --- Extract header+payload
    dd if=$pkg ibs=$o skip=1 2>/dev/null > $plaintext

# --- Verify DSA signature using gpg
    gpg --batch -vv --verify $detached $plaintext

# --- Clean up
    rm -f $detached $plaintext
done
==========================================================================

Enjoy

73 de Jeff

Jeff Johnson	ARS N3NPQ

[heinlein at pecos heinlein]$ rpm -qi popt
Name        : popt
Summary     : A C library for parsing command line parameters.
Description :
Popt is a C library for parsing command line parameters. Popt was
heavily influenced by the getopt() and getopt_long() functions, but it
improves on them by allowing more powerful argument expansion. Popt
can parse arbitrary argv[] style arrays and automatically set
variables based on command line arguments. Popt allows command line
arguments to be aliased via configuration files and includes utility
functions for parsing arbitrary strings into argv[] arrays using
shell-like rules.


Without libpopt.so, some compiled programs are unable to process 
command-line arguments. I've never had a problem with that library, 
however, so I'm unsure at what point it'd mess up the boot process.

>---------- Forwarded message ----------
>Date: Wed, 18 Sep 2002 11:48:52 -0400
>From: Jeff Johnson <jbj at redhat.com>
>Reply-To: rpm-list at redhat.com
>To: rpm-list at redhat.com
>Subject: rpm-4.1 released
>
>
>Rpm 4.1 is now available at
>
>        ftp://ftp.rpm.org/pub/rpm/dist/rpm-4.1.x
>
>The final part of the release (6x, 7x, etc) indicates the version
>of Red Hat Linux for which the package has been built. For example,
>the i386 packages for Red Hat 6.2 are
>        rpm-4.1-6x.i386.rpm
>        rpm-devel-4.1-6x.i386.rpm
>        rpm-build-4.1-6x.i386.rpm
>        rpm-python-4.1-6x.i386.rpm
>        popt-1.7-6x.i386.rpm
>
>This version is also available through anonymous cvs:
>        cvs -d :pserver:anonymous at cvs.rpm.org:/cvs/devel login
>        (no password, just carriage return)
>        cvs -d :pserver:anonymous at cvs.rpm.org:/cvs/devel get rpm
>        cd rpm
>        cvs up -r rpm-4_1-release
>You will need the versions of libtool, autoconf, and automake identified
>in autogen.sh if you wish to build from CVS.
>
>Please report any difficulties, problems, issues, feature requests, whatever at
>        http://bugzilla.redhat.com
>
>Here's a brief summary of features that have been added. See the
>CHANGES file in the src rpm for the gory details.
>
>1) Header signatures and digests, if available, are verified when (first)
>   retrieved from the rpm database.
>
>2) The rpm database permits concurrent access. That means that it is now
>   possible to run rpm in %post scriptlets.
>
>   Note: What still remains is to find out whether there are deadlocks
>   (there are), and whether the deadlocks can be avoided or otherwise
>   handled gracefully. I'd really like to support (at least read)
>   concurrent access to the rpm database, but it's gonna take a lot
>   of careful (i.e. reproducible) testing to achieve that goal. Any
>   and all help is appreciated. What's very promising is that the
>   problems are deadlocks, not segfaults, but reproducing deadlocks
>   is gonna be quite challenging.
>
>3) The rpmdb-redhat package (which contains an "everything" rpm database),
>   if installed, will be used to provide suggested solutions for unresolved
>   dependencies. Try installing the rpmdb-redhat package from Raw Hide if
>   interested.
>
>DSA/RSA signature verification using RFC-2440 OpenPGP V3
>packets is now implemented directly in rpm. The signature,
>if available, is always verified when reading a package, and failures
>are always reported.
>
>Signing is done with gpg/pgp helpers as always, and both a new,
>header-only, as well as the Good Old header+payload signature
>are generated. In fact, all of Red Hat 7.3 was signed with rpm-4.1,
>so both signatures should be present in 7.3 packages.
>
>What's also new is pubkey management using --import. Basically
>	rpm --import RPM-GPG-KEY
>(or any ascii armored OpenPGP pubkey) will wrap the binary OpenPGP
>packet in a header, and install just like any other package.
>
>Here's what you see if you have not yet imported the correct pubkey(s):
>
>bash$ sudo rpm -Uvh popt-1.7-7x.i386.rpm
>warning: popt-1.7-7x.i386.rpm: Header V3 DSA signature: NOKEY, key ID db42a60e
>...
>
>Here's what the Red Hat pubkeys look like when imported:
>==========================================================================
>bash$ rpm -qa | grep pubkey
>gpg-pubkey-0352860f-3c3cb5e4
>gpg-pubkey-db42a60e-37ea5438
>
>bash$ rpm -qi gpg-pubkey-db42a60e
>Name        : gpg-pubkey                   Relocations: (not relocateable)
>Version     : db42a60e                          Vendor: (none)
>Release     : 37ea5438                      Build Date: Sat 16 Mar 2002 10:47:53 AM EST
>Install date: Sat 16 Mar 2002 10:47:53 AM EST      Build Host: localhost
>Group       : Public Keys                   Source RPM: (none)
>Size        : 0                                License: pubkey
>Summary     : gpg(Red Hat, Inc <security at redhat.com>)
>Description :

check to see if all zones were loaded properly (particularly the hints
or root zone).

This sounds like it could be trying to do a reverse lookup (and waiting
for a time-out), or your forwarders are not responding appropriately (Do
you have forwarders set up?).

From aschlemm at attbi.com  Wed Sep 18 13:06:09 2002

By chance do you have a TZ environment variable set in the runtime 
environment that majordomo is running in? I know "date" will use the TZ 
variable if it is defined and you can have a different time displayed

e.g.:

tony at tigger:~> export TZ=EST5EDT
tony at tigger:~> date
Wed Sep 18 16:04:32 EDT 2002
tony at tigger:~> export -n TZ
tony at tigger:~> date
Wed Sep 18 13:04:47 PDT 2002

Tony

I am not sure this is related, but when I upgraded to RH7.3 something
about the timezone broke.

I get this message upon boot:

timezone: /etc/rc3.d/S10timezone: nls: command not found
timezone: /etc/rc3.d/S10timezone: run_cmd: command not found

I used timeconfig to set the time zone which appeared to correct it but
my cron jobs still ran like they were on GMT.

Last night, I used timetool to correct the problem after another reboot
and synch up the time server with ntpd. 

I didn't see the usual cron job from early this morning, so I suspect
the cron will run at 9:30 instead of 3:30 (for example).

Not sure if all that helps, but I think if one of us solves our problem
it will at least hint at the others solution.

From deathfox at moochercrew.org  Wed Sep 18 13:48:29 2002
From: deathfox at moochercrew.org (Chris Emery)
Date: 18 Sep 2002 13:48:29 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] 2 NICs
Message-ID: <1032382109.14090.15.camel@moochercrew.org>

So, I have a compaq pressario 7234, which has 2 PCI slots in it, one is
shared with an ISA slot, the other is all by itself.  I got 2 D-Link
NICs, which use the ne2k_pci driver.  The botom most controler is the
one that is shared with an ISA slot, the top controler is not.  If both
NICs are in the machine, the bottom controller works and the top
controller does not work, A single NIC in either of the controllers
works perfectly.

Anybody have any ideas?
Places to search
Terms to search
sugesstions



From richard.langis at sun.com  Wed Sep 18 14:00:45 2002
From: richard.langis at sun.com (Richard Langis)
Date: Wed, 18 Sep 2002 14:00:45 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] 2 NICs
References: <1032382109.14090.15.camel@moochercrew.org>
Message-ID: <3D88E97D.3060101@sun.com>

My suggestion would be to find the driver disk for the nic(s), and see 
if there's a configuration utility.  Install both nics, boot the driver 
disk (or other dos disk, then insert the driver disk), run the config 
utility and let it configure the nics for you.  THEN write down this 
information in case you need to pass kernel options or module options, 
and try to boot into linux.

I had two 3c509's that were set at the same IRQ/port/DMA and would panic 
the kernel every time until I reconfigured them using the above method.

Hope that helps, YMMV.  :)

-R

From richard.langis at sun.com  Wed Sep 18 14:12:12 2002

I kept this around since I liked the picture Todd sent...but I just had 
another idea.

I've been looking for a keyboard for my Toshiba Protege 660CDT (kids 
spilled something into it, I think), and I noticed a LOT of laptops on 
ebay going with broken screens, no keyboard, no cdrom, no HD, no ram, 
etc etc.  In other words, people were selling every single removable 
part off of the laptop in order to maximize the selling price.

So you can look at it two ways - 1) get a good laptop screen/broken body 
and somehow frankenstein 'em together, or 2) sell your laptop peicemeal 
to try and pick up enough cash to buy a new one (or put a good amount 
down on one).

So there it is.  Hope that helps.  :)

-R

> installed.

You don't have to have KDE running to run Quanta+, it runs within
Blackbox for me.  Since I don't like KDE, I only installed Quanta+ and
its dependencies.  The only really annoying thing about Quanta is that
every once in a while text on the right side of the window will not be
displayed correctly (sometimes it won't be displayed at all).  It also
has some problems with color coding the HTML keywords if PHP scripts are
used within the HTML.  OTOH, I really like the preview.  The type of
stuff I'm doing could easily be done with a plain text editor (mostly
copy and paste then preview), so I can't comment on its usefulness as a
real development tool.

I think I'll try Bluefish now.

Derek Loree

On Tue, 2002-09-17 at 21:54, Stephen Liu wrote:

> One thing I could not understand.  According to my recollection, Debian 
> distro has 3 CDs.  Why this distro has only one of capacity 94.4MB

Because that is a "netinst" image.  It contains only the installer, not
the software packages.  Those will be downloaded from the net by the
installer.

If you are installing several computers, you should investigate
"apt-proxy".  (Consulting services are available; phone me or email
offlist.)

Date: Wed, 18 Sep 2002 14:39:27 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] How to pull out a particular line from a textfile
In-Reply-To: <Pine.GSO.4.33.0209181431170.14106-100000@lukem.com>
References: <Pine.GSO.4.33.0209181431170.14106-100000@lukem.com>

On Wed, Sep 18, 2002 at 02:36:01PM -0700, Matt Alexander wrote:
> I've got a file and I want to write a script to pull out particular lines
> and save them in variables.  Line 1 is always the email address and Line 2
> is always the subject, for example.
> 
> #!/bin/bash
> 
> EMAIL=`some magical way to pull out line 1 from a textfile`
> SUBJECT=`some magical way to pull out line 2 from a textfile`
> 
> 
> I assume there's a simple command to pull out a particular line from a
> textfile, but I can't think of anything right now.

I usually use perl:

perl -ne 'print if $. == 1' textfile

where $. is the current line number.

You can also use combinations of head and tail:

First line:

  head -1

Second line:

  head -2 | tail -1

Colin

Real quick and dirty:

For line 1: "head -n 1"

For line 2: "head -n 2 | tail -n 1"

Tony

From don at truedisk.com  Wed Sep 18 14:51:02 2002
From: don at truedisk.com (Don Buchholz)
Date: Wed, 18 Sep 2002 14:51:02 -0700

here are 2 ways to do it ...

--------------------------------
#!/bin/bash
EMAIL=`head -1 $file`
SUBJECT=`head -2 $file | tail -1`
--------------------------------
#!/bin/bash
EMAIL=`awk 'NR==1 {print;}`
SUBJECT=`awk 'NR==2 {print;}`
--------------------------------

couldn't find its fonts. In my case, it was something else -- I wasn't
allowing xfs to read /usr/share/AbiSuite/fonts/. As such, I believe the
warning about not running the wrapper is a red herring.

settings, kind of forcing the issue.  I've also seen it where identical

the one module to a file with a different name, then had the kernel load
both modules.

From dagit at engr.orst.edu  Wed Sep 18 15:09:08 2002
From: dagit at engr.orst.edu (Jason Dagit)
Date: Wed, 18 Sep 2002 15:09:08 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] How to pull out a particular line from a textfile
In-Reply-To: <Pine.GSO.4.33.0209181456180.14106-100000@lukem.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0209181507360.27602-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>

Hey and according to the Advanced Bash scripting howto you can do in
directly from bash:

http://www.tldp.org/LDP/abs/html/internal.html#READREDIR

And straight from the howto:
#!/bin/bash

read var1 <data-file
echo "var1 = $var1"
# var1 set to the entire first line of the input file "data-file"

read var2 var3 <data-file
echo "var2 = $var2   var3 = $var3"
# Note non-intuitive behavior of "read" here.
# 1) Rewinds back to the beginning of input file.
# 2) Each variable is now set to a corresponding string,
#    separated by whitespace, rather than to an entire line of text.
# 3) The final variable gets the remainder of the line.
# 4) If there are more variables to be set than whitespace-terminated
strings
#    on the first line of the file, then the excess variables remain
empty.

Good luck,
Jason

> Does the setup program have the ability to hard-set the IRQ and I/O?
> These values could then be used to load the modules with the
> appropriate settings, kind of forcing the issue.  I've also seen it
> where identical cards needed two separate modules to load, in that
> case, I just copied the one module to a file with a different name,
> then had the kernel load both modules. 

I believe the devices in question are pci.  pci configuration is soft, and
typically done by the bios.  I wonder if a bios upgrade would solve the
problem.  Does lspci or cat /proc/pci show both cards, despite only one
being functional?  What does the scanpci command return?

galen

From 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com  Wed Sep 18 16:13:18 2002
From: 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com (Steve Bonds)
Date: Wed, 18 Sep 2002 16:13:18 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] OpenBSD (was: 2 NICs)
Message-ID: <591661475.1032390800849.JavaMail.root@monkey>

On Wed, 18 Sep 2002, Rich Shepard rshepard at appl-ecosys.com wrote:

>   I recall reading here a few years ago, that either Open or NetBSD
> was slightly better than linux for a firewall application. I don't
> recall exactly why, but it was security related.

OpenBSD is often chosen over say, RedHat, since OpenBSD is designed to be
secure "out of the box", whereas RedHat is designed to be working "out of
the box".

There are lots of choices which would make a good firewall os-- OpenBSD
being one.  Another one which looks interesting (and requires more
work) is LIDS (http://www.lids.org/).  This provides excellent protection
against hacks since even root canot modify protected files (which you need
to define) without a system reboot.

  -- Steve





From 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com  Wed Sep 18 16:25:10 2002
From: 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com (Steve Bonds)
Date: Wed, 18 Sep 2002 16:25:10 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] 2 NICs
Message-ID: <1528465827.1032391516402.JavaMail.root@monkey>

On 18 Sep 2002, Chris Emery deathfox at moochercrew.org wrote:

> So, I have a compaq pressario 7234, which has 2 PCI slots in it, one
> is shared with an ISA slot, the other is all by itself.  I got 2
> D-Link NICs, which use the ne2k_pci driver.  The botom most controler
> is the one that is shared with an ISA slot, the top controler is not.  
> If both NICs are in the machine, the bottom controller works and the
> top controller does not work, A single NIC in either of the
> controllers works perfectly.
> 
> Anybody have any ideas?
> Places to search
> Terms to search
> sugesstions

I would suggest:

1) Check your /etc/modules.conf to ensure that you have aliases for both
eth0 and eth1 listed.  For example:

alias eth0 ne2k-pci
alias eth1 ne2k-pci

The easiest way to get this change to take effect is to reboot.

If that doesn't help:

2) Grab "mii-diag" and "libmnii.c" from http://www.scyld.com/diag/ and
compile with "gcc -Wall -Wstrict-prototypes -O mii-diag.c -DLIBMII
libmii.c -o mii-diag".  Try running ./mii-diag eth0 and ./mii-diag
eth1.  This is a pretty low-level diagnostic, so the information is rather
obscure.

Unless you get the error "SIOCGMIIPHY on eth1 failed: No such device",
then you have an eth1 present.  If you get that error, then there is
something wrong with the module load.

3) Try loading the module manually with "insmod ne2k-pci debug=2" to
enable some rather pathetic debugging.  Use "dmesg" to view the output
after loading.  (This should also be in /var/log/messages.)

  -- Steve





From derek at infotects.com  Wed Sep 18 16:25:26 2002

> http://www.scyld.com/expert/irq-conflict.html

This was a good read, very informative.  I think the lesson here is (for
pci devices): if you can't assign an IRQ to a slot in your BIOS, the
only other way to change the IRQ assignment is to put the card in a
different slot.  BTW, an easy way to free up IRQ's (15 just isn't enough
to go around) is to disable (in the BIOS) any unneeded serial and
parallel ports.

Thanks,

Derek





From aschlemm at attbi.com  Wed Sep 18 16:38:01 2002
From: aschlemm at attbi.com (Anthony Schlemmer)
Date: Wed, 18 Sep 2002 16:38:01 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] OpenBSD (was: 2 NICs)
In-Reply-To: <591661475.1032390800849.JavaMail.root@monkey>
References: <591661475.1032390800849.JavaMail.root@monkey>
Message-ID: <200209181638.01663.aschlemm@attbi.com>

With a properly setup syste with firewalling enabled I think either 
Linux or OpenBSD make a pretty good firewall. I ran with a firewall 
using ipchains under various versions of 2.2.x for more than 4 years 
and I'm now trying the other "BSD" side of things. Within the last week 
I have setup a OpenBSD 3.1 system using "pf" and am using that as my 
network's gateway/firewall system. The stateful firewalling is very 
nice and has significantly reduced the complexity of my firewall rules 
I had with ipchains. I could do the same thing with Linux using 
"iptables" which are also stateful.

I know I could enable enough services on my OpenBSD system to make it 
insecure too. But by default I was impressed that OpenBSD only had 
"ssh" service running by default and nothing else. No telnet or login 
service or anything else that uses clear text passwords. I thought I 
was going to miss FTP since I use it to transfer files around but I've 
found "scp" to an adequate replacement and use it to transfer files 
between my BSD and other Linux systems.

Probably the most difficult part of OpenBSD is that when a security fix 
comes out it is in source form and so I have to patch code and compile 
things. If the patch affects a library that may be statically linked 
with other programs I end up first compiling a new kernel and then I 
compile the entire basic OpenBSD system. 

I "nice" the build process and just let it go off and do its thing and 
check on it the next day since it takes 8-9 hours to build everything. 
My system is a typical underpowered firewall box with a lowly AMD K6 
CPU hence the long build times. 

With Linux I just download a new RPM from my distro provider. Again I 
made this my choice and I'm willing to live with a little bit extra 
work doing full system builds to keep my OpenBSD system patched and 
up-to-date.

Tony

From galens at seitzassoc.com  Wed Sep 18 16:38:04 2002
From: galens at seitzassoc.com (Galen Seitz)
Date: Wed, 18 Sep 2002 16:38:04 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] 2 NICs 
In-Reply-To: Your message of "18 Sep 2002 16:25:26 PDT."
             <1032391526.14011.27842.camel@dereklinux> 
Message-ID: <200209182338.g8INc4229161@tinman.seitzassoc.com>

> This was a good read, very informative.  I think the lesson here is
> (for pci devices): if you can't assign an IRQ to a slot in your BIOS,
> the only other way to change the IRQ assignment is to put the card in
> a different slot.  BTW, an easy way to free up IRQ's (15 just isn't
> enough to go around) is to disable (in the BIOS) any unneeded serial
> and parallel ports. 

Sharing IRQs isn't necessarily bad.  The PCI bus was design
with this in mind.  It is only due to the brain damaged ISA bus that
people have come to expect each device to have its own interrupt.  With
ISA, if two devices were both in use, no sharing was possible.  With PCI,
sharing is not a problem.

galen




From randal.t.pluimer at intel.com  Wed Sep 18 16:41:51 2002

Also the memory space used by the cards could be the same.

Or. see if there is a utility available that lets you set these through
software.

From ali at axian.com  Wed Sep 18 17:58:53 2002
From: ali at axian.com (Alice Corbin)
Date: Wed, 18 Sep 2002 17:58:53 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] C++ style comments in C under emacs
In-Reply-To: <200209182304.g8IN4H228960@tinman.seitzassoc.com>; from galens@seitzassoc.com on Wed, Sep 18, 2002 at 04:04:17PM -0700
References: <200209182304.g8IN4H228960@tinman.seitzassoc.com>
Message-ID: <20020918175853.A7784@zaphod.axian.com>

You could try:

(setq auto-mode-alist
  (append '(("\\.c$"  . c++-mode)
            ("\\.h$"  . c++-mode)
           ) auto-mode-alist))

in your .emacs file.

From revans at e-z.net  Wed Sep 18 21:01:55 2002
From: revans at e-z.net (Russell Evans)
Date: Wed, 18 Sep 2002 21:01:55 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] How to pull out a particular line from a textfile
In-Reply-To: <Pine.GSO.4.33.0209181456180.14106-100000@lukem.com>
References: <Pine.GSO.4.33.0209181456180.14106-100000@lukem.com>
Message-ID: <20020919040156.JYBB21527.sccrmhc02.attbi.com@linux>

I find myself using recycling so I try for easy to change, easy to copy into a
function in another script. I also tend to need to capture when thing don't
happen correctly. YMMV

#!/bin/sh

FILE=somefile
LINELIST="1 2"
MIN=2 

declare -a WHATIWANT

DoWhatEver () {
	echo
}	


if [ -f $FILE ] ; then
	WHATIWANT=( `cat $FILE` )
else
	echo "$FILE does not exist"
	exit 1
fi

if [ ${#WHATIWANT[@]} -ge $MIN ] ; then
	for i in $LINELIST ; do
		if [ ${#WHATIWANT[4i]} != 0 ] ; then
			DoWhatEver ${WHATIWANT[$i]}
		else
			echo "Line $i is blank"
			exit 2
		fi
	done
else 
	echo "Content not found in $FILE" 
	exit 3
fi
exit 0

Thank you
Russell

I couldn't figure out what was going on on my laptop with my time, but I
found a helpful page :

http://www.linuxsa.org.au/tips/time.html

Being new to Linux, I didn't realize that there is a local time, a system
time, AND a hardware time.

There's also this :

The time in some applications is wrong

If some applications (such as date) display the correct time, but others
don't, and you are running Red Hat Linux 5.0 or 5.1, you most likely have
run into a bug caused by a move of the timezone information from
/usr/lib/zoneinfo to /usr/share/zoneinfo. The fix is to create a symbolic
link from /usr/lib/zoneinfo to /usr/share/ zoneinfo: ``ln -s
../share/zoneinfo /usr/lib/zoneinfo''.

From 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com  Thu Sep 19 01:07:57 2002
From: 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com (Steve Bonds)
Date: Thu, 19 Sep 2002 01:07:57 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] OT: Databases
Message-ID: <1434949608.1032422880931.JavaMail.root@monkey>

On Wed, 18 Sep 2002, Jeremy Bowen ocarules at webnationinc.com wrote:

> This is probably more of a datatbase question than a Linux question.
> 
> I need someone who can show me how to do the following (consultant or just
> someone good with databases and programs):
> 
> List A (45,000 records) has: Name, Address, City, State, Zip
> 
> List B (100,000) has: Name, Address, City, State, Zip, Additional Data,
> Additional Data.......
> 
> I need to compare the two lists and MARK the records in List A that exist in
> list B (They need to be marked in List A). Using Linux would be great but I
> don't have a functioning Linux box right now and I need the data on the
> Windows box because the software the will ultimately use the list has not
> Linux alternative.
> 
> Has anyone done anything like this before? I would be more than happy to pay
> someone to teach me how to accomplish this task.

This would be a trivial perl script.  The only hard part would be for you
to define how closely the records need to match.  For example:
  + Exact name match, but address differs
  + Exact name match, address match, ZIP differs
  + is name match case-sensitive or not?
  + Name doesn't match, but address does
  + Other combinations

Suggested program structure: (optimized for speed and simplicity at the
expense of using more memory than it might otherwise.  With as few
records as you have, this shouldn't be a problem on any modern PC.)

  + pull list A into a hash, index by the item(s) you want to match
exactly
  + pull list B into a hash, index it the same way
  + for each hash index in B, pull the matching record from A

  -- Steve

From heinlein at attbi.com  Thu Sep 19 06:42:39 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Thu, 19 Sep 2002 06:42:39 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] OT: Databases
In-Reply-To: <008601c25f9a$ba378c00$6501a8c0@jeremyb>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0209190635340.2944-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Wed, 18 Sep 2002, Jeremy Bowen wrote:

> This is probably more of a datatbase question than a Linux question.

Is it? Do you lists reside in a database, or are they in text files?

> I need someone who can show me how to do the following (consultant
> or just someone good with databases and programs):
> 
> List A (45,000 records) has: Name, Address, City, State, Zip
> 
> List B (100,000) has: Name, Address, City, State, Zip, Additional
> Data, Additional Data.......

If they're in an SQL-addressable database, and you're sure that List B 
records are identical to List A records except for the additional 
data, then

  select
    a.name, a.address, a.city, a.state, a.zip
  from
    a,b
  where
    a. name   = b.name    and
    a.address = b.address and
    a.city    = b.city    and
    a.state   = b.state   and
    a.zip     = b.zip

If the data in the fields that exist in A and B aren't *identical*,
however, then you'll have some trouble...

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>




From derek at infotects.com  Thu Sep 19 08:55:33 2002
From: derek at infotects.com (Derek Loree)

Message-ID: <1032450934.2524.28805.camel@dereklinux>

On Wed, 2002-09-18 at 16:38, Galen Seitz wrote:
> 
> > This was a good read, very informative.  I think the lesson here is
> > (for pci devices): if you can't assign an IRQ to a slot in your BIOS,
> > the only other way to change the IRQ assignment is to put the card in
> > a different slot.  BTW, an easy way to free up IRQ's (15 just isn't
> > enough to go around) is to disable (in the BIOS) any unneeded serial
> > and parallel ports. 
> 
> Sharing IRQs isn't necessarily bad.

This is only theoretical, in practice, I've seen many pci devices that
would exhibit odd behavior, or just wouldn't work because of an IRQ
conflict.  The 3Dfx Voodoo cards are the worst offenders, they MUST have
an IRQ, and it MUST be the only device using it.  Sound cards and NIC's
are next on the list.  The best running systems have one device per IRQ,
this became my system builders mantra.


Derek

From russj at dimstar.net  Thu Sep 19 09:49:49 2002
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: Thu, 19 Sep 2002 09:49:49 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] 2 NICs
References: <200209190547.g8J5lc230079@tinman.seitzassoc.com>
Message-ID: <3D8A002D.5090901@dimstar.net>

Galen Seitz wrote:

>The main point I was trying to make was that PCI hardware supports IRQ
>sharing.  It is certainly possible that the driver doesn't support it,
>though it seems from a quick google search that there are people using
>2 ne2k-pci cards
>
As have I. However, on occasion, I've run into the motherboard that 
shares IRQs between PCI slots that are next to each other. The solution 
(and this never fails, when it's available) is to put the NICs in the 
machine with a slot seperating them. Or even just move one card to the 
slot on the other side of the other NIC. Either action would cause the 
card to now be in a slot that is not sharing an IRQ.

In this case, that's not an option, as there are only two PCI slots. I 
suspect the driver needs different IRQs, or it wouldn't know where to 
talk when that interupt signals. I suspect that's the root reason for 
the problem we're trying to troubleshoot here.

From galens at seitzassoc.com  Thu Sep 19 10:39:21 2002

> >The main point I was trying to make was that PCI hardware supports IRQ

> >though it seems from a quick google search that there are people using
> >2 ne2k-pci cards

> As have I. However, on occasion, I've run into the motherboard that 
> shares IRQs between PCI slots that are next to each other. The solution 
> (and this never fails, when it's available) is to put the NICs in the 
> machine with a slot seperating them. Or even just move one card to the 
> slot on the other side of the other NIC. Either action would cause the 
> card to now be in a slot that is not sharing an IRQ.
> 
> In this case, that's not an option, as there are only two PCI slots. I 
> suspect the driver needs different IRQs, or it wouldn't know where to 
> talk when that interupt signals. I suspect that's the root reason for 
> the problem we're trying to troubleshoot here.

I just looked at the ne2k-pci driver source.  It certainly looks like it
supports shared irqs.

static int ne2k_pci_open(struct net_device *dev)
{
        int ret = request_irq(dev->irq, ei_interrupt, SA_SHIRQ, dev->name, dev);
                                                      ^^^^^^^^
This flag tells the kernel that the driver supports shared interrupts.  That
doesn't necessarily mean it works, but at least the author was thinking
about the issue.

If you have access to "Linux Device Drivers, 2nd Ed.", you can read about
interrupt sharing starting on page 274.

galen

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Thu Sep 19 11:07:30 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Thu, 19 Sep 2002 11:07:30 -0700 (PDT)

                                   SuitWatch

  Views on Linux in Business

  --by Doc Searls, Senior Editor of Linux Journal
     _________________________________________________________________

                               Deskward bound

   As I write this, on Wednesday morning, all eyes and ears are trained
   in the direction of Sun Microsystems, which is announcing new Linux
   desktop hardware (among other Linux-related items) at the company's
   Sun Network:
   http://sunnetwork.sun.com/ show in San Francisco:

   <http://sunnetwork.sun.com/>

   The Big Picture stories have already appeared in the Wall Street
   Journal and the New York Times:
   :

   <http://www.nytimes.com/2002/09/18/technology/18SUN.html>

   Both position the new boxes as threats to Microsoft. Given Sun's
   severe antipathy toward Microsoft, that's an easy story to tell. In
   fact, this morning the Times is running an editorial endorsing Linux,
   presumably on the occasion of the Sun announcement. "The New Challenge
   to Microsoft":
   , opens with this:

   As the government's antitrust lawsuit winds down, Microsoft's next
   battle may be a knock-down, drag-out fight against Linux. Like
   Microsoft's Windows, Linux is a computer operating system, but written
   and updated by volunteer programmers in a communitarian spirit, and
   available for free. If Linux spreads, Microsoft could see the first
   real challenge to its dominance of the operating-system software
   market. For consumers, that would be good news.

   And it closes with this:

   Government units abroad and in the United States and individual
   computer users should look for ways to support Linux and Linux-based
   products. The competition it offers helps everyone.

   <http://www.nytimes.com/2002/09/18/opinion/18WED2.html>

   That's a nice endorsement, but it doesn't touch the real fight that's
   going on, which is for shelf space among each big vendor's UNIX
   offerings, which was the topic of the last SuitWatch:
   :

   <http://www.ssc.com/pipermail/suitwatch/2002q3/000029.html>

   News came yesterday that IBM plans add:
   its pSeries of servers to the growing list of Big Blue hardware lines
   running Linux. Those already include the xSeries of Intel-based
   servers, the iSeries midrange servers and zSeries mainframes:

   <http://news.com.com/2100-1001-958354.html>.

   IBM is also working on "improving" Linux in ways the help it run on
   the company's Power4-based systems, including the pSeries.

   In a related announcement:
   http://news.com.com/2100-1001-958002.html, IBM and Red Hat say Red Hat
   will be supplying Advanced Server software for IBM's heavier iron: the
   p, i and zSeries. Red Hat already supports the xSeries.

   In one announcement after another, IBM makes clear its intention to
   make Linux work every possible place it makes sense. The company
   appears to be making no attempt to protect AIX, or any of its other
   operating systems, from Linux. From the Linux perspective, IBM has a
   shelf that includes all kinds of hardware.

   Not so with Sun. A Reuters story says "Sun argues Linux is a low-end
   complement to Solaris and keeps customers out of the Microsoft camp."
   In other words, Linux is Sun's low-end OS. That's where it sits on
   Sun's OS shelf. Which is fine: different company, different strategy.
   We'll see how it goes.

   There is good reason for Sun to concentrate right now on corporate
   PCs. Reports on a survey:
   by SG Cowen say IT spending growth will rise 1.8% in 2002 and 3.4% in
   2003, with anticipated spending closest to flat among the largest
   firms. But while PC spending is "entrenched" in a 4-year cycle,
   corporate PC upgrade budgets are due to increase 17% in 2002 and 20%
   in 2003. The primary suppliers are still IBM and Dell, with HP/Compaq
   having a "reduced role" in future spending plans. Meanwhile, all of
   those companies are pushing their Linux server offerings. Not Linux
   desktops.

   <http://www.sgcowen.com/rs/rs3.html>
   <http://www.theregister.co.uk/content/7/27010.html>

   In fact, finding desktop hardware is easier at Wal-Mart than at any of
   the Big Three corporate desktop suppliers, as I reported in a Linux
   Journal Web piece about Sun's latest anticipated offerings:

   <http://www.linuxjournal.com/article.php?sid=6327>

   That leaves a significant hole. Sun doesn't have a Microsoft
   relationship to protect. It can much more easily imagine PC business
   that doesn't swap Linux into boxes originally meant to run Windows. It
   can zero-base its PC strategy in a Windows-free way. That's a huge
   advantage.

   Even if all Sun sells is droneware for corporate cubicle hives (what I
   suspect at this point, still in the absence of input), at least it's
   offering something that the Big Three are not.

   Yet.

   Until the Big Three get on the stick, the primary competition for Sun
   will be commodity white boxes. Are companies already buying white
   boxes by the trainload likely to go for the Sun brand? Not clear. It
   would help if they were already Sun customers, and taking advantage of
   the application environments Sun talks about on its Linux page:

   <http://wwws.sun.com/software/linux/>

   The question then for Sun is whether or not its successes with Linux
   will be at the expense of PC vendors and Microsoft, or of itself.
   After all, that same SG Cowen survey showed both Linux and Windows
   gaining momentum, with Linux growth coming at the expense of other
   UNIX variants.

   It also said Linux was already running at 44% of the companies
   surveyed, with 45% planning to emphasize Linux more in the future.

   This invites a new concept: the Linux hardware replacement cycle. At
   some point all these competitors will have to count on it. And that
   will be a huge sign of Linux' success.

   Other items:

   Earthlink to bundle with LIndows PCs (ComputerWire, via The Register)
   <http://www.theregister.co.uk/content/6/27167.html>

   Red Hat broadens desktop push (News.com)
   <http://news.com.com/2100-1001-958342.html>

   Sun to shed light on desktop Linux plans (ITworld.com)
   <http://www.itworld.com/Comp/2362/020917sunlinux/>

   Security: Linux Virus Exploits Buffer Overflow Vulnerability
   (Net4Nowt) <http://www.net4nowt.com/comments/1032345778,7666,.shtml>

   LinOra Corporation Switches from Microsoft Windows to Linux Desktops
   Using Ximian Evolution
   <http://ximian.com/about_us/press_center/press_releases/linora.html?>

:
: This is probably more of a datatbase question than a Linux question.
:
: I need someone who can show me how to do the following (consultant or just
: someone good with databases and programs):
:
: List A (45,000 records) has: Name, Address, City, State, Zip
:
: List B (100,000) has: Name, Address, City, State, Zip, Additional Data,
: Additional Data.......
:
: I need to compare the two lists and MARK the records in List A that exist in
: list B (They need to be marked in List A). Using Linux would be great but I
: don't have a functioning Linux box right now and I need the data on the
: Windows box because the software the will ultimately use the list has not
: Linux alternative.
:

As somebody already pointed out, the success of any method is largely
dependent on the consistency of data in the two lists.  While it is
really a database task, you might be able to get some results sooner
by considering the `comm' command (man comm to learn more).  With a
little awk, tr, and other shell magic, one could get some reliable
output without going through the effort of installing a database
server and learning SQL.

This is admittedly a quick and dirty solution.  If this data will be
used for other things in the future, then the investment of time in the
database solution would probably be worth making sooner or later.

Good luck -

Wally

From cp at onsitetech.com  Thu Sep 19 15:04:30 2002
From: cp at onsitetech.com (Curtis Poe)
Date: Thu, 19 Sep 2002 15:04:30 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] OT: Databases
References: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0209191244300.16942-100000@dhcp-73-190.attbi.com>
Message-ID: <006b01c26028$87e95790$1a01a8c0@ot.onsitetech.com>

> On Wed, 18 Sep 2002, Jeremy Bowen wrote:
> This is probably more of a datatbase question than a Linux question.
>
> I need someone who can show me how to do the following (consultant or just
> someone good with databases and programs):
>
> List A (45,000 records) has: Name, Address, City, State, Zip
>
> List B (100,000) has: Name, Address, City, State, Zip, Additional Data,
> Additional Data.......
>
> I need to compare the two lists and MARK the records in List A that exist
in
> list B (They need to be marked in List A). Using Linux would be great but
I
> don't have a functioning Linux box right now and I need the data on the
> Windows box because the software the will ultimately use the list has not
> Linux alternative.

I think a database is likely overkill for this.  Let's assume for a moment
the following facts:

1.  The lists are in CSV (comma separated value) flat files.
2.  The data is rather dirty (arbitrary    spacing and caPitaliZation), but
none is missing.

The strategy I would try is:

1.  Remove all non-word characters, leaving only letters, numbers, and
underscores.
2.  Lower case all letters.
3.  Join the fields in List A into one field and make them hash keys.
4.  Iterate over List B and check for existence in List A.  If it exists,
stuff into an array.

The following quick, dirty, and untested code (in Perl) should give you an
idea of what I mean:

#!/usr/bin/perl -w
use strict;
use Text::CSV_XS;
my $csv = Text::CVS_XS->new;

my ( $list_a, $list_b ) = ('list_a.txt','list_b.txt');
my %list_a;
open LIST_A, "< $list_a" or die $!;
while (<LIST_A>) {
    next if ! $_; # skip empty lines
    if ( $csv->parse($_) ) {
        my $data = join '', $csv->fields;
        $data =~ s/\W//g; # that's a capital W
        $data = lc $data;
        $list_a{ $data } = 1;
    }
    else {
      warn "List_a: could not parse " . $csv->error_input;
    }
}
close LIST_A;

my @match;

open LIST_B, "< $list_b" or die $!;
while( <LIST_B> ) {
    next if ! $_;
    if ( $csv->parse($_) ) {
        my $data = join '', $csv->fields;
        $data =~ s/\W//g;
        $data = lc $data;
        push @match => [$csv->fields] if exists $list_a{ $data };
    }
    else {
        warn "List_b: could not parse " . $csv->error_input;
    }
}
close LIST_B;
# @match now has a list of matching records (an array of arrayrefs)

Let me know if you have any questions.

--
Cheers,
Curtis Poe
Senior Programmer
ONSITE! Technology, Inc.
www.onsitetech.com

<snip>

Oops!  There was a bug in my code.  Creating the $data key in the second
while loop should only use the fields defined in List A.  The second while
loop should define data as follows:

    my $data = join '', @{$csv->fields}[0..4];

Also, my heuristic was a general case that should catch *most* of that
matches, but that greatly depends on the data.

Curtis

From karlheg at pdxlinux.org  Thu Sep 19 16:39:23 2002
From: karlheg at pdxlinux.org (Karl M. Hegbloom)
Date: 19 Sep 2002 16:39:23 -0700
Subject: Of course, silly. (Re: [PLUG] c++ stl docs in Debian?)
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0209191216240.30637-100000@tpol.peak.org>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0209191216240.30637-100000@tpol.peak.org>
Message-ID: <1032478763.7814.151.camel@bittersweet>

On Thu, 2002-09-19 at 12:18, Eric House wrote:
> I'm trying to find my way around some STL (standard template library)
> C++ code for the first time.  When I encounter unfamiliar stdlib
> functions (printf, select, etc.) a simple 'man printf' gives me info
> about them.  Does anybody know if there's a Debian package that will
> do the same for STL, and if so what it is?

Visit:

http://www.pdxlinux.org/dc/

And enter "template" in the search box at the bottom of the left panel.

The "/dc/" URL is provided by the "doc-central" package and "doc-base". 
The STL documentation you'll find there is provided by the (drum roll
please) "stl-manual" package.  You don't need to use a web server and
doc-central to access that STL manual on localhost; you can always get
to it directly via a file:// URL.

You will also find that the "devhelp" books and/or the *-doc packages (
in particular, the libc-doc) contain usefully available documentation. 
Try "devhelp" and see if you like it, and also try "info libc" once as
well.

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Thu Sep 19 16:55:48 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Thu, 19 Sep 2002 16:55:48 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] WINE Question

On Thu, 19 Sep 2002, David Mandel wrote:

>     Is there a good way for a Windows program to check to see if it
> is running in Wine instead of running on native Windows?

David,

  I think this would be inimical to the whole idea of wine. The point is to
have Microsoft-written programs run in linux and not know the difference.
Wine replaces the winderz API with the equivalent calls for linux. There are
also dummy .dlls that make the application feel comfortable while the linux
.so does the actual work.
 
>     I know this seems like a silly question, but I need to know.

  That's why you asked. It's OK.
 
>     I was thinking that since Wine runs in the Linux file system
> it could look for linux files in root, but it doesn't this doesn't
> look promising.  Wine lets you map these files out.

  Wine runs on a linux fs, but I believe that the application and data need
to be on a vfat (type 6) fs. I haven't tried copying an application to ext3,
but I'm making progress installing an application off the cdrom and putting
it on a vfat partition.

  I wouldn't let wine, or an application running over it, anywhere near
/root or /.

Rich

From don at truedisk.com  Thu Sep 19 18:18:02 2002
From: don at truedisk.com (Don Buchholz)
Date: Thu, 19 Sep 2002 18:18:02 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Socket Question
References: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0209191630470.3499-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>
Message-ID: <3D8A774A.2040305@truedisk.com>


Jason Dagit wrote:
>
> I was just curious if anyone knows why tcp/ip sockets below 1024 need
> root permission, but sockets above 1024 do not?
>

In "The Good Old Days"(r), you didn't connect a system to the network
unless you had a lot of resources ($$$).  It was a gentlemen's agreement
to limit TCP ports <1024 to 'system-only' privileges.  After all, the
system wouldn't be in existence if there wasn't a professional staff to
support it.

Therefore, if I contacted a system at port 79 (finger), I could be fairly
certain that I was getting an answer from a system admin program.  If the
admin wasn't running fingerd, then a random user could hang a daemon on
that port and send any old bogus answer.  This gets even more interesting
when you peruse the low-numbered port names ... ftp, ssh, telnet, smtp,
time, nameserver, tacacs, domain, bootps & bootpc, tftp, finger, ntp,
auth, sunrpc, ....

 > Is this some sort of attempt to prevent users from preempting programs
 > Like sshd from using it's usuall port?
Yes ... or worse, spoofing the daemon.

I think, that at some level, even, there was a facility which could be
used to propogate authentication from one system to another.  Basically,
if a program on Host A connected to Host B from a low numbered port, and
Host A's protocal said "this is user 'X'", then Host B would accept that.

... then personal computers got cheap to network, and easy to connect, and
no one could ever trust a low-numbered port again ...

From beattie at beattie-home.net  Thu Sep 19 19:03:08 2002
From: beattie at beattie-home.net (Brian Beattie)
Date: 19 Sep 2002 19:03:08 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Socket Question
In-Reply-To: <3D8A774A.2040305@truedisk.com>
References: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0209191630470.3499-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU> 
	<3D8A774A.2040305@truedisk.com>
Message-ID: <1032487388.5443.7.camel@coyote>

On Thu, 2002-09-19 at 18:18, Don Buchholz wrote:
> 
> 
> Jason Dagit wrote:
> >
> > I was just curious if anyone knows why tcp/ip sockets below 1024 need
> > root permission, but sockets above 1024 do not?
> >
> 
> In "The Good Old Days"(r), you didn't connect a system to the network
> unless you had a lot of resources ($$$).  It was a gentlemen's agreement
> to limit TCP ports <1024 to 'system-only' privileges.  After all, the
> system wouldn't be in existence if there wasn't a professional staff to
> support it.
> 
> Therefore, if I contacted a system at port 79 (finger), I could be fairly
> certain that I was getting an answer from a system admin program.  If the
> admin wasn't running fingerd, then a random user could hang a daemon on
> that port and send any old bogus answer.  This gets even more interesting
> when you peruse the low-numbered port names ... ftp, ssh, telnet, smtp,
> time, nameserver, tacacs, domain, bootps & bootpc, tftp, finger, ntp,
> auth, sunrpc, ....

Close, the ports < 1024 being "special" was introduced by the boys from
Berkeley for the rsh commands (rsh, rcp, rlogin).  The rsh commands were
the predecessors of the ssh commands (ssh, scp, slogin).  Since rsh and
rcp did not have a way to prompt for a password, they had to be
"trusted" to work.  The security scheme that they came up with was that
if the connection "came" from a port < 1024 it had to be a root process
and therefore trusted.  Not very secure, but it worked in the
environment for which it was designed.

> ability to modify the program, you can check the value of those keys.
>
> Perhaps I'm missing the point.  Do you want to be able to detect this if
> someone installs the software on a computer you have no control over (ie.
> end user systems)?
>

Yes, this is a strange request; but for some reason I'm interested
in writing a Windows program that suppose to perform slightly differently
depending on if it is being ran:

        (1) On native Windows
        (2) On Windows under VM-Ware
        (3) On Windows under wine
        (4) and so on.

Thus, my Windows program needs to know if it has been started from
wine.

    * 7:35-7:50 Video over IP demo. Multicast two streams of
    * live video. One camera on the room and one camera on
    * outside. Show multicast ability by playing stream on
    * PC as well as monitors.

"marvin at marvin.ordb.org@XXX.ISPREVERSEDNS.com"@MAIL.MYDOMAIN.com

From dmandel at pdxLinux.org  Fri Sep 20 14:23:30 2002
From: dmandel at pdxLinux.org (David Mandel)
Date: Fri, 20 Sep 2002 14:23:30 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] WINE Question
In-Reply-To: <86k7lglayg.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0209201407500.4291-100000@sco302.DavidMandel.com>

On 20 Sep 2002, Russell Senior wrote:

...
>
> David> MS Fortran!!  This was Micro Soft's somewhat successful attempt
> David> to kill a great language....
>
> Heh, yeah.  Not my choice...

Fortran is a fine language.  My compliant is MS Fortran.  Actually,
back when I was doing lots of Fortran I never found a good Fortran
for small computers.  MS Fortran was buggy.  However, all the
Fortrans I used on small computers (those running DOS, Windows, or
Apple OS) were slow, slow, slow; and Fortran isn't very useful unless
it executes numerical code fast.

I used g77 on my last Fortran project (That was 4 or 5 years ago).
This was a port of 300+ programs from Primos to AIX and Linux.
I didn't have time to do much bench marking, but the resulting
code seemed ok.  It felt more like a mainframe or workstation Fortran
than one of those baby Fortrans they built for small computers.

Of course, g77 follows the 1977 Fortran standard instead of the
1990 or one of the enhanced 1990 standards.  I sort of feel
bad that I've never had a chance to use a more modern Fortran.
Instead, mostly I've used C for that type of work.

>> -----Original Message-----
>> From: CERT Advisory [mailto:cert-advisory at cert.org]
>> Sent: Saturday, September 14, 2002 3:26 PM
>> To: cert-advisory at cert.org
>> Subject: CERT Advisory CA-2002-27 Apache/mod_ssl Worm
>>
>>
>>
>>
>> -----BEGIN PGP SIGNED MESSAGE-----
>>
>> CERT Advisory CA-2002-27 Apache/mod_ssl Worm
>>
>>    Original release date: September 14, 2002
>>    Last revised: --
>>    Source: CERT/CC
>>
>>    A complete revision history can be found at the end of this file.
>>
>> Systems Affected
>>
>>      * Linux  systems running Apache with mod_ssl accessing
>> SSLv2-enabled
>>        OpenSSL 0.9.6d or earlier on Intel x86 architectures
>>
>> Overview
>>
>>    The  CERT/CC  has  received reports of self-propagating malicious
>> code which  exploits a vulnerability (VU#102795) in OpenSSL. This
>> malicious code  has  been referred to as Apache/mod_ssl worm,
>> linux.slapper.worm and bugtraq.c worm.
>>
>> I. Description
>>
>>    The  Apache/mod_ssl  worm  is  self-propagating  malicious  code
>> that exploits  the  OpenSSL  vulnerability  described  in
>> VU#102795.
>>
>>      http://www.kb.cert.org/vuls/id/102795
>>
>>    This vulnerability was the among the topics discussed in CA-2002-23
>> "Multiple Vulnerabilities In OpenSSL".
>>
>>      http://www.cert.org/advisories/CA-2002-23.html
>>
>>    While this OpenSSL server vulnerability exists on a wide variety of
>> platforms, the Apache/mod_ssl worm appears to work only on Linux
>> systems running Apache with the OpenSSL module (mod_ssl) on Intel
>> architectures.
>>
>>    The  Apache/mod_ssl  worm  scans for potentially vulnerable systems
>> on 80/tcp using an invalid HTTP GET request.
>>
>>           GET /mod_ssl:error:HTTP-request HTTP/1.0
>>

From seniorr at aracnet.com  Fri Sep 20 15:57:32 2002
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)

>>>>> "David" == David Mandel <dmandel at pdxLinux.org> writes:

David> MS Fortran!!  This was Micro Soft's somewhat successful attempt
David> to kill a great language....

Russell> Heh, yeah.  Not my choice...

David> Fortran is a fine language.  My compliant is MS Fortran.

Yeah, I understood that.  The primary reason for wanting to rewrite it
in C was to more easily support distributed computations in a
master/slave kind of architecture, which was going to require some
integrated networking code.  My intuition was that would make Fortran
too painful.

The problem factors nicely, essentially a bunch of independent random
walks, which made the distributed architecture particularly
attractive.  All the master needs to send the slave is the geometry (a
set of surfaces and a starting point), and all the slave needs to send
the master is the number of times the random walks terminated on each
surface.

I did 1 million random walks for each of 21 different starting points
on a 500 MHz P3 box using the MS Fortran compiled binary under WINE
and it took about, oh, 18 hours or so.  Just think how many more
random walks per hour I could do with 20 CPU's running at the same
time!

Back in middle-history, I learned Fortran while I was at Oregon State
University in the engineering program.  I took a course from a guy
named Dave Caufield (sp?) in the mid-1980's.  Interesting fellow.  Red
haired, bearded, hacker-type, with yellow tobacco stains on his
fingers.  He also pulled consulting duty in the basement of the Milne
Computer Center.  I occasionally wonder where he disappeared to.  I
once complained to him about how, on a different problem, I was being
compelled to hack Fortran instead of C (which, given the tools
available to me at the time, a Compaq 8088 and MS Fortran v2 or
something with no manual, was quite painful) because I was working
with a bunch of electrical power engineers.  He replied wryly, "When
one is in Italy, one speaks Italian!" ;-)

From ckuskie at dalsemi.com  Fri Sep 20 16:02:11 2002
From: ckuskie at dalsemi.com (Colin Kuskie)
Date: Fri, 20 Sep 2002 16:02:11 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] FW: CERT Advisory CA-2002-27 Apache/mod_ssl Worm
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0209200737520.30127-100000@ebersisk.clueserver.org>
References: <20020920224742.GA8150@dalsemi.com> <Pine.LNX.4.44.0209200737520.30127-100000@ebersisk.clueserver.org>
Message-ID: <20020920230211.GB8150@dalsemi.com>

On Fri, Sep 20, 2002 at 07:38:55AM -0700, alan wrote:
> On Fri, 20 Sep 2002, Colin Kuskie wrote:
> 
> > http://rhn.redhat.com/errata/RHSA-2002-155.html
> > 
> > This was released July 9, 2002.  Odds are that if you've been running
> > up2date like you say, it's already on your system.
> 
> I wish Redhat had been a bit more clear in their announcement.  I know 
> what is fixed in that version and i was not clear about it until looking 
> at the SRPM.

What's not clear about this:

A security audit of the OpenSSL code sponsored by
DARPA found several buffer overflows in OpenSSL which affect versions 0.9.7
and 0.9.6d and earlier:

1. The master key supplied by a client to an SSL version 2 server could be
oversized, causing a stack-based buffer overflow. This issue is remotely
exploitable. Services that have SSLv2 disabled would not be vulnerable to
this issue. (CAN-2002-0656)

2. The SSLv3 session ID supplied to a client from a malicious server could
be oversized and overrun a buffer. This issue looks to be remotely
exploitable. (CAN-2002-0656)

3. Various buffers used for storing ASCII representations of integers were
too small on 64 bit platforms. This issue may be exploitable. (CAN-2002-0655)

Y'all have to remember that the CERT advisory came out AFTER the
fixes from the vendors.

Colin

From aschlemm at attbi.com  Fri Sep 20 16:31:39 2002
From: aschlemm at attbi.com (Anthony Schlemmer)
Date: Fri, 20 Sep 2002 16:31:39 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Tuning the time
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0209201503120.27068-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0209201503120.27068-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <200209201631.39394.aschlemm@attbi.com>

I went through this a week or so ago and while searching for public 
stratum 1 and 2 time servers I found this information about NTP at this 
site:

http://www.ultimeth.net/ntp/

They do offer, by permission, public access to their stratum 2 time 
server but they are pretty restrictive since it looks like they've had 
a lot of bozos with misconfigured NTP servers accessing their site at 
one time. 

I'm not using them since I want hassle free NTP server access but their 
website has alot of good information about configuring an NTP server 
and also how to verify its proper operation. I used their config file 
as the basis for mine and went through the NTP documentation to find 
some public NTP servers. I am also able to verify propery operation as 
well now.

I now synchronize all of my internal systems (Windows, Linux, and 
OpenBSD) against the time server on my gateway system.

Tony

From mike at computer-arts.net  Fri Sep 20 17:00:55 2002
From: mike at computer-arts.net (Mike Witt)
Date: Fri, 20 Sep 2002 17:00:55 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Tuning the time
References: <mailman.1032560001.20052.plug@lists.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <3D8BB6B7.D5CF414B@computer-arts.net>

Here's a copy of my /etc/ntp.conf, for what it's worth. As far as
I can tell, I'm keeping correct time. Of couse, the way I CHECKED
this was by calling the NIST phone line (303-499-7111) so I guess
it's no surprise that it agrees with the NIST severs :-)

-Mike

#
# ntp.conf for Perelandra
#
# The plan is for Perelandra to be the time server on our network, and
# have everyone else feed off it.
#

# NIST Info from:
# http://www.boulder.nist.gov/timefreq/service/time-servers.html
#
# stratum 1 server      IP Address      Location
# ----------------      ----------      --------
# time.nist.gov         192.43.244.18   NCAR, Boulder, Colorado
# time-nw.nist.gov      131.107.1.10    Microsoft, Redmond, Washington

server 192.43.244.18
server 131.107.1.10
driftfile /etc/ntp/drift
authenticate no

From dmandel at pdxLinux.org  Fri Sep 20 18:10:55 2002

On 20 Sep 2002, Russell Senior wrote:

...
> Yeah, I understood that.  The primary reason for wanting to rewrite it
> in C was to more easily support distributed computations in a
> master/slave kind of architecture, which was going to require some
> integrated networking code.  My intuition was that would make Fortran
> too painful.

Yes, Fortran is no longer sufficient - but it does work well with C.
In my late Fortran years, I did the numerical stuff in Fortran and
write the graphical stuff in C.  I suppose this approach would also
work for distributed computations.  In many cases, I was reluctant to
rewrite the numerical stuff in C because it was very complex and worked
so well as it was.  It would have been an enormous waste of time to
convert it to C.

By the way the last Fortran package I worked on was converted to C
at some east coast university which will remain nameless.  I was
then asked to port the original Fortran code to new platforms.
Why, you ask?  Well, the rewritten code didn't get the algorithms
right, so it gave wrong answers.  However, it did have a nice
user interface.
...
>
> Back in middle-history, I learned Fortran while I was at Oregon State
> University in the engineering program.  I took a course from a guy
> named Dave Caufield (sp?) in the mid-1980's....

I can't place Dave Caufield, but I bet I knew him a bit.
That was the era when Tom Yates, Dave Fuhrer, Mike Drost, and
JoAnn Baumman were at the OSU Computer Center.

> He replied wryly, "When one is in Italy, one speaks Italian!" ;-)
>
Yes, I speak "Italian" as my native tongue, but had to learn
"English" to communicate in the new world (of the 1980s).

                                          Dave

It's been a long time since I've tinkered with this kind of stuff, but
there is a book that may be of some help to you:

   Numerical Computation of Electric and Magnetic Fields
   by Charles W. Steele

My copy has a 1987 copyright, so better methods may have been developed
in the last 15 years, but there may be an updated version of the book, or
it may be that not much has changed.

From heinlein at attbi.com  Fri Sep 20 20:37:32 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Fri, 20 Sep 2002 20:37:32 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] FW: CERT Advisory CA-2002-27 Apache/mod_ssl Worm
In-Reply-To: <41611.207.173.0.68.1032561669.squirrel@webmail.woo-hoo.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0209202027550.24603-100000@pecos.madboa.com>

On Fri, 20 Sep 2002, Steven Raymond wrote:

> I have checked up2date every day for a new rpm for this
> vulnerabiliy- but it seems that so far Redhat has not addressed the
> issue.  What have you RH'ers done to protect yourselves?

There are a few things worth noting here.

1. If you do nothing else, subscribe to the redhat-watch mailing list. 
   Although it's sometimes a few days behind the release date of 
   updated RPMs, it's the official mass-distribution forum for Red 
   Hat's security/enhancement/bugfix notices.

   https://listman.redhat.com/mailman/listinfo/redhat-watch-list

2. The changelogs for RPMs are available from the command line, e.g.,

   rpm -q --changelog openssl

   In the case of the openssl package, you're told that the patch to 
   fix the recently announced ASN.1 vulnerabilities was added on July 
   29, and the backport of Ben Laurie's patches for OpenSSL 0.9.6d 
   were added on July 25.

   Granted, the changelog-query facility is only as informational as 
   the changelogs themselves, but it's the best place to start.

3. The Linux Weekly News security page is a well reported 
   clearinghouse of security information. You can do worse than 
   checking it every Thursday.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

From seniorr at aracnet.com  Fri Sep 20 23:36:54 2002
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: 20 Sep 2002 23:36:54 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] WINE Question
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0209201755240.6468-100000@sco302.DavidMandel.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0209201755240.6468-100000@sco302.DavidMandel.com>
Message-ID: <86bs6rlugp.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

>>>>> "David" == David Mandel <dmandel at pdxLinux.org> writes:

David> [...] In many cases, I was reluctant to rewrite the numerical
David> stuff in C because it was very complex and worked so well as it
David> was.  It would have been an enormous waste of time to convert
David> it to C.

In my case, the Fortran was written by Electrical Engineers, who
weren't really programmers at all.  Let's just say I think this
particular code benefitted by being rewritten.  ;-)

The other thing that rewriting in C did was make it more flexible.
All the old Fortran had static limits on the size of arrays.  One of
the first things I did was take advantage of malloc() and friends to
make that all dynamically allocated.

I was careful to test the rewrite to yield exactly the same output as
the old Fortran program.  If I got the algorithms wrong, they were
wrong in exactly the same way as the original, except maybe I computed
them wrong faster.

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Sat Sep 21 08:06:40 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Sat, 21 Sep 2002 08:06:40 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] WINE Question
In-Reply-To: <86bs6rlugp.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0209210801540.31840-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

On 20 Sep 2002, Russell Senior wrote:

> In my case, the Fortran was written by Electrical Engineers, who
> weren't really programmers at all.  Let's just say I think this
> particular code benefitted by being rewritten.  ;-)

  Most folks who wrote in fortran also did not put comments in the code.
Look at a lot of source available from the USGS and similar sites and there
will be thousands of lines of code -- all in uppercase, of course -- and not
a single comment to explain the variables or what is supposed to be done.

  When I was writing in fortran -- about 1972-1976 -- code was punched on
Hollerith cards. I had to develop the idea of punching a card with a 'C' in
column 1 to separate code; occasionally I'd actually write a comment. It was
just not standard practice. The only code organizational I was taught was to
use a felt-tip marking pen to make diagonal lines across the top edges of
the card deck. This made it easier to get the back in order when you dropped
them; especially with an ecosystem model I developed that consisted of two
boxes of cards.

  I like C and I like full-screen editors.

Rich

  By "folder" I presume you mean a directory and its subdirectories. There
are several compression utilities, but the only one that works cross-OS so
Microsoft users can decompress files is called "zip". 'man zip' will give
you directions.

http://support.3com.com/infodeli/tools/nic/linuxdownloads.htm
has what you want.  You need to create a floppy with this driver on it.

The driver floppy is a like a kernel module load with a module.cgz file.  Took 
me a while to find out that .cgz is a cpio file gzipped.  But this file would 
contain the driver for you NIC.  I am surprized that the PCIMIA boot disk 
does not have the driver on it.

From mike at computer-arts.net  Sun Sep 22 07:18:55 2002
From: mike at computer-arts.net (Mike Witt)
Date: Sun, 22 Sep 2002 07:18:55 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Syntax to compress a folder with tar
References: <mailman.1032668361.11759.plug@lists.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <3D8DD14F.7D8553F6@computer-arts.net>

Stephen Liu wrote:
> 
> Hi All People,
> 
> Kindly advise what is the correct syntax to tar (compress) a fold (directory)
> which contains sub-folders (sub-directories) and files.
> 
> Thanks in advance.
> 
> Stephen Liu

If the directory name is "my_dir" I would suggest the following
commands:

  cd my_dir
  tar cvzf /tmp/my_dir.tgz .

This will leave a compressed version of the files in /tmp. If you
do it this way, the path names of the files in the directory will
be "relative" so that a sequence of commands like:

  mkdir foo
  cd foo
  tar xvzf /tmp/my_dir.tgz

Will restore all the files into the directory "foo"

Use the command "man tar" to get more information on the tar command.

-Mike

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Sun Sep 22 13:03:37 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Sun, 22 Sep 2002 13:03:37 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Allowing user shutdowns
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0209221259450.14780-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

  I know that only root can issue the 'shutdown' command, but what is the
accepted procedure when the installation is on a laptop and you don't want
to give the user root priviledges? I can think of only two scenarios:

  1) Make a different root password for that box and hope that accidents are
few and far between; or,

  2) Write a script, called perhaps 'done', that su's to root, uses expect
to supply the root password, then issues the 'shutdown -h now' command.

  The second is cleaner and safer, but I've never done any expect
programming and I don't know if it can be used to supply the root password
in a situation as I've described.

Thoughts?

Rich




From aschlemm at attbi.com  Sun Sep 22 14:02:04 2002
From: aschlemm at attbi.com (Anthony Schlemmer)
Date: Sun, 22 Sep 2002 14:02:04 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Allowing user shutdowns
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0209221259450.14780-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0209221259450.14780-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <200209221402.04059.aschlemm@attbi.com>

Do you have "sudo" installed? You can grant specific users access to the 
shutdown command and you don't have to give them root access. The user 
would then run something like:

sudo shutdown -h now

You can probably setup Linux to perform a reboot with a 
"three-fingered-salute" as well. I things that can be setup in the 
/etc/inittab file. I know my SuSE system supports this because while 
attempting to go to a virtual console I presses CTL-ALT-DEL rathar than 
CTL-ALT-2...DOH!

Tony

From mikeraz at patch.com  Sun Sep 22 15:00:42 2002
From: mikeraz at patch.com (mikeraz at patch.com)
Date: Sun, 22 Sep 2002 15:00:42 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] shutdown for normal users
Message-ID: <20020922150042.A2587@patch.com>

Rich,

Why not just create /etc/shutdown.allow with the names of the users
you want to allow to use shutdown?

>From the Fine man page:

       If shutdown  is  called with the -a argument (add this to the
       invocation of shutdown in /etc/inittab), it checks to  see
       if  the file /etc/shutdown.allow is present.  It then com?
       pares the login names in that file with the list of people
       that   are   logged   in   on   a  virtual  console ...

then alias shutdown to "shutdown -a" in the global bashrc file.

darn fine man page, if I do say so myself.

-- 
      Michael Rasmussen  aka  mikeraz
    Be appropriate && Follow your curiosity
 http://www.patch.com/ http://wiki.patch.com/
       http://blog.patch.com/sandbox/

Real computer scientists only write specs for languages that might run
on future hardware.  Nobody trusts them to write specs for anything homo
sapiens will ever be able to fit on a single planet.

From aschlemm at attbi.com  Sun Sep 22 15:34:42 2002
From: aschlemm at attbi.com (Anthony Schlemmer)
Date: Sun, 22 Sep 2002 15:34:42 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] shutdown for normal users
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0209221516150.15105-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0209221516150.15105-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <200209221534.42529.aschlemm@attbi.com>

That certainly is an easier way to grant shutdown access. I always get a 
bit nervious of giving Joe or Jane average access to "shutdown" that is 
"too easy" to get at. I've always preferred to use "sudo" to grant 
shutdown access to non-root users since they have to have a 
command-line available and run "sudo shutdown...." explicity. It's a 
bit harder to get at than an aliased "shutdown" command IMHO. 

I guess if you're going to script the shutdown you could go either way. 
With it scripted you can force the user to answer "YES" before 
proceeding with running the "shutdown" command just in case they get 
there by mistake.

Tony

From miken at europa.com  Mon Sep 23 07:02:35 2002
From: miken at europa.com (Mike Neal)
Date: Mon, 23 Sep 2002 07:02:35 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] pcmcia install of RH 7.3
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0209221251130.14780-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <3.0.5.32.20020923070235.00f7d008@pop.europa.com>

Similar problem solved by changing the CMOS setting for:
PC Card Controller Mode
from the default to:
CardBus/16 bit
Got the tip from the PCMCIA mail list.

Cheers,
Mike

information about Debian and Mandrake (others too?) on our
website?  I mean I'm sure that there are similar mailing lists
for each of the distributions and ways of checking each package
format.

Not only could we be heading off a lot of similar email, but
then we'd have a single point of reference for information.

We could even invent a new acronym, RTFW.

Colin



From galens at seitzassoc.com  Mon Sep 23 09:46:31 2002
From: galens at seitzassoc.com (Galen Seitz)
Date: Mon, 23 Sep 2002 09:46:31 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Info on format for /dev/dsp or /dev/audio 
In-Reply-To: Your message of "Sun, 22 Sep 2002 19:23:16 PDT."
             <3D8E7B14.3A8C55BB@computer-arts.net> 
Message-ID: <200209231646.g8NGkV200495@tinman.seitzassoc.com>

> Can anyone tell me the exact format of a .wav file that can be
> cat'ed to /dev/dsp or /dev/audio?  What I'm trying to do is to
> create small sound sample that I can write out to the sound card
> in a C program.
> 

The sound howto should help with some of your questions.
http://www.tldp.org/HOWTO/Sound-HOWTO/

I believe /dev/audio expects mono 8 bit u-law data.  I think this is
the sound format used by the first Sun sound hardware.

Here's a quote from the sound howto:
Sun workstation (.au) sound files can be played by sending them to the 
/dev/audio device. Raw samples can be sent to /dev/dsp. This will generally 
give poor results though, and using a program such as play is preferable, as 
it will recognize most file types and set the sound card to the correct 
sampling rate, etc.

Another area for problems is the mixer.  If the levels are set too low,
the sound could be playing, but just too soft to be heard.

> The .wav files I've created so far have this format:
>  $ file short.wav 
>  short.wav: RIFF (little-endian) data, WAVE audio, Microsoft PCM, 16 bit, stereo 44100 Hz
> 
> While these files can be played by xmms or whatever, they can't
> be written directly to /dev/dsp or /dev/audio.
> 
> I'm obviously a little confused about this, so I might not be asking
> exactly the right question. Any pointers to info on how to write
> sound directly to these devices would be appreciated.
> 

Wav files have a header, so even if you play them by cat'ing them to
/dev/dsp, you may get a burst of noise at the beginning.

As the howto says, you are best off using a program to play sound files.
I suggest beginning with the source code of the 'play' program, and
hacking as needed.

galen





From zot at whiteknighthackers.com  Mon Sep 23 10:09:40 2002
From: zot at whiteknighthackers.com (Zot O'Connor)
Date: 23 Sep 2002 10:09:40 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Fighting ORDB, solved....
Message-ID: <1032800979.7313.355.camel@kat.zotnet.com>

So basically I am an idiot.  In my networks I had a class C with a typo
192.XXX.XXX.0/2  not /24.

This would declare all networks 192.0.0.0 and higher to be in my local
networks (192 is binary 1100|0000).

so 212.X.X.X would work, but not 62.X.X.X.

So when people test from a lower network it failed.  ORDB is coming in
at different numbers, so when it hit from 212.242.88.3 it worked, but
when it hit from 62.79.90.71 it did not.

This is why it would pass some days, or for some tests and not others. 

A really big thanks to the folks who helped me, especially Wietse who
put in a lot of time for my screwup.  I apologize for wasting people's
time (especially since the private class C did not make the original
posting due to line wrap).

It might would be mighty nice if there was a debug mode where postfix
would post what rule accepted each mail (or I could find that option). 
Overload for a normal site, but the only way I found this was setting up
a similar site.  Reproducing the results, and then I went to a default
main.cf.

I checked each line in my original main.cf (grep -v '^#' main.cf | grep
-v '^$').  I searched for each variable set in the original main.cf, and
then added it when it did not match.  When it allowed the tests, it was
on mynetworks, I reduced the line down, and found it.

files in the hierarchy.

through ALL files in a hierarchy?

From heinlein at attbi.com  Mon Sep 23 13:16:31 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Mon, 23 Sep 2002 13:16:31 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Recursive grep
In-Reply-To: <3D8F674A.34C6DF58@computer-arts.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0209231312450.20042-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Mon, 23 Sep 2002, Mike Witt wrote:

> When I want to grep through (for example) all the .c files in
> a hierarchy I've been using find, for example:
> 
>   find . -name \*.c -exec fgrep -H "find.this.string" {} \;
> 
> It SEEMS like I ought to be able to accomplish the same thing using
> grep recursively, something like: 
> 
>   grep -r "find.this.string" *.c

No, because -r == -d recurse, so grep reads all files under each 
directory that matches the '*.c' expansion.

find's -exec option is expensive, however, so you can do a hacky sort 
of combination to speed things up a bit:

  grep 'find.this.string' $(find . -name \*.c)

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>




From lemming at attbi.com  Mon Sep 23 13:24:33 2002
From: lemming at attbi.com (lemming at attbi.com)
Date: Mon, 23 Sep 2002 20:24:33 +0000
Subject: [PLUG] Recursive grep
Message-ID: <20020923202434.NEV21615.rwcrmhc51.attbi.com@rwcrwbc58>

Or you could do:

grep -r --include='*.c' "find.this.string"

From cynical at penguinness.org  Mon Sep 23 18:27:08 2002
From: cynical at penguinness.org (Justin The Cynical)
Date: Mon, 23 Sep 2002 18:27:08 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Syntax to compress a folder with tar
In-Reply-To: <1032673791.13784.1.camel@moochercrew.org>
References: <200209221219.32849.satimis@writeme.com>
	<1032673791.13784.1.camel@moochercrew.org>
Message-ID: <20020923182708.0089c93c.cynical@penguinness.org>

On 21 Sep 2002 22:49:50 -0700
Chris Emery <deathfox at moochercrew.org> wrote:

CE> On Sat, 2002-09-21 at 21:19, Stephen Liu wrote:
>> Hi All People,
>> 
>> Kindly advise what is the correct syntax to tar (compress) a fold (directory) 
>> which contains sub-folders (sub-directories) and files.
>> 
>> Thanks in advance.
>> 
>> Stephen Liu

CE> tar czf <file.tar.gz> <file>


I'm going to pick a nit here...

tar doesn't actually compress anything, it's just an archiver (Tape Archiver).  One still has to run the resulting file through a compressor.

The z flag as listed above just automagically filters the archive through gzip/compress (depending on the case of the letter z).  Check the man page for confirmation.  The GNU version of tar I have (1.13) supports z, Z, and y (gzip, compress, and bzip2), just remember that not all versions of tar have support for these flags.

For example, the tar that Sun includes by default in the Solaris 8 environment doesn't.  Guess which program I replaced with the GNU version real quickly?

--

always makes it through.

  When I send mail to multiple addressees, including one address that is
