From heinlein at attbi.com  Tue Sep 24 06:40:15 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Tue, 24 Sep 2002 06:40:15 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] language
In-Reply-To: <20020924063646.71950.qmail@web14605.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0209240621490.31317-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Mon, 23 Sep 2002, Dragos Ciobanu wrote:

> I'm running RH 7.3 and I was wondering how can I change the language
> to the command line.

The LANG environment variable is what's gotten munged. My hunch is 
that if you do 'echo $LANG' from a command prompt, you'll see 'fr' or 
something close to that.

To fix your current shell session, do one of the following

  export LANG=''
  export LANG='C'
  export LANG='en_US'

The first two are essentially the same: your system will feel like an
old time *nix box. The last one is a bit different. Your error
messages will be in good ol' American English, but utilities that
alphabetically sort things (ls, sort, ...) will do so in a way that
doesn't feel, er, Unixy. E.g.,

  [heinlein at pecos tmp]$ LANG=C ls -A1 # the good old way
  .asillyfile
  ABB.txt
  INBOX
  Z.pl
  aaa.txt
  z.c

  [heinlein at pecos tmp]$ LANG=en_US ls -A1 # new-fangled i18n way
  aaa.txt
  ABB.txt
  .asillyfile
  INBOX
  z.c
  Z.pl

Longer term, you'll want to edit the LANG definition in
/etc/sysconfig/i18n and/or your ~/.bash_profile and ~/.bashrc files.

Please let us know if you need further help in this vein.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

From heinlein at attbi.com  Tue Sep 24 06:50:37 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Tue, 24 Sep 2002 06:50:37 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Recursive grep
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0209232002210.25285-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0209240644100.31317-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Mon, 23 Sep 2002, Rich Shepard wrote:

> I've been using 'rgrep -r ...' under RH 6.2 with the 2.2 kernels. Is
> this something different?

Yeah. Using GNU grep 2.4.x and older, you couldn't (easily) tell grep,
"search for string 'foo' in all *.h files in the entire /usr/include
directory tree." The intuitive command,

  cd /usr/include
  grep -r foo *.h

wouldn't do what you really wanted[1]. Now, however, grep 2.5.x can do
it:

  cd /usr/include
  grep -r --include="*.h" foo *

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

[1] Because the shell, not grep, would handle the wildcard expansion. 
    So grep never even had a chance to guess at what you really wanted 
    to do.

Uh, PLUG is *NOT* a non-profit. It is not incorporated, & simply
refers to a group of people who meet a few times each month to discuss
Linux & drink beer. IANAL, but it seems to me that PLUG can't be sued
because there is no one to file charges against!

(I'm not sure this worthy correspondent[1] could prove someone like
Dave Mandel, Paul Nelson, Dan Haskell, or myself -- who are mentioned
on the website -- are responsible for what PLUG says or does: were
just volunteers like Richard or our new friend posting from Phoenix,
with no special powers. He might be able to sue Sandy for slander, but
I'm not sure that sending an email is considered adequate legal notice
even for that. And I doubt he's serious enough to pay a lawyer to
litigate a case with little to no prior case law to find out who he can
sue.)

On the other hand, this is one reason why PLUG just might want to
bite the bullet & incorporate. Incorporatino would provide something
of a shield from this kind of crap. As things stand now, if this worthy
correspondent did sue someone assoicated with PLUG, & get a friendly
judge, he could make someone's life a mess with all of the litigation &
court procedings. :-(

Zot O'Connor wrote:
 
> It might would be mighty nice if there was a debug mode where postfix
> would post what rule accepted each mail (or I could find that option).
> Overload for a normal site, but the only way I found this was setting up
> a similar site.  Reproducing the results, and then I went to a default
> main.cf.


There are a couple:

 soft_bounce = yes

Sends temporary failure codes (4XX) instead of permanent (5XX), among other 
things.

And 'warn_if_reject', added every any restriction you want to test, will:

#   warn_if_reject: next restriction logs a warning instead of rejecting.

See the 'sample-smptd.cf' file.  It's a nice way to test various changes 
before actually enforcing them, which I regret to say I don't use often 
enough...

I've had no trouble. Just open the service finder thingee (Cmd K? my 
memory fails me) and do

  smb://host.name/sharename

Typically, you'll be prompted for a username, which should be entered 
in the standard smb format:

  domain\username

The problem for us hasn't been the connections but the bloomin' 
faux-stream files that Macs insist on littering around the filesystem.

From dealy at deatech.com  Tue Sep 24 11:50:39 2002
From: dealy at deatech.com (Shannon C. Dealy)
Date: Tue, 24 Sep 2002 11:50:39 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Creating Large Files for Loopback
In-Reply-To: <20020924045951.88792.qmail@web40412.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0209241117350.9448-100000@critter.deatech.com>

On Mon, 23 Sep 2002, Ethan Bean wrote:

> I'm not on the list, so could you CC
> ethabean at yahoo.com on replies?
>
> Does anyone know of a util or something to create a
> large file without all the overhead of "dd
> if=/dev/zero of=..." It's for a loopback device, is
> there some way to make it auto-extend or something
> like that?

Actually, dd will do what you want, I use it all the time for creating
drives for virtual computers like this:

   dd if=/dev/zero of=virtual_filesystem_name bs=1M count=0 seek=20

This would create a 20 Megabyte file (bs x seek == 1M x 20).  There are
some things to be aware of however, which depending on what you are doing
can be good or bad:

  1 - This creates what is known as a "sparse" file, which does not
      actually allocate storage for any significant block of data
      which is all zeros.  What this means is that while an ls -l will
      show the file size as: 20971520 bytes, the du command will show
      the file size as zero.

  2 - File creation time is essentially zero

  3 - Saves disk storage since space in the file is not actually allocated
      until it is used to store non-zero data.

  4 - The size of the sparse file can exceed the free storage on your hard
      drive, which can have strange and unexpected results if your
      application writes sufficient data into the sparse file to exceed
      the free space on the hard drive.

  5 - Many common applications such as "cp" and "rsync" require special
      options in order to preserve the "sparse" nature of the file when
      copying it to other locations, and other applications don't even
      understand the concept.

  6 - The biggest plus is that you can create large file systems with lots
      of reserve capacity but not have to waste all the space that goes
      with them, though over time, fragmentation can eat alot of space,
      but it can be recovered by using tools to push all the file system
      data to one end of the virtual drive (such as repartitioning tools
      do), zeroing the remaining unused portion of the partition, and
      using cp with the appropriate sparse option (there may be an easier
      way, I just haven't had much need for this).

Shannon C. Dealy      |               DeaTech Research Inc.
dealy at deatech.com     |          - Custom Software Development -
                      |    Embedded Systems, Real-time, Device Drivers
Phone: (800) 467-5820 | Networking, Scientific & Engineering Applications
   or: (541) 451-5177 |                  www.deatech.com

I just though I would make some comments about this
whole thing. I personally have done a little studying
of US Copyright law (the person did indeed mention
copyright law), and there is a chance that there is a
violation of the law.

I don't remember the exact section (I only whoop the
legalese when I want to impress people, or talk to
lawyers), but any literary work (including e-mail
[including spam]), is copyrighted upon its completion.

However, fair use allows the use of a copyrighted work
in review, Sandy (and Richard) may be descrbed as
posting a review. If anyone who may be harmed by this
litigation needs some support, I can review the code
with them, but I'm no lawyer, and I am no substitute
for one.

This has given me an idea, All of the laws are
recorded, this is so that anyone can read them, and
know what they are. I say we back up our comrads and
do a little RTFMing with the law. About 20 hackers
researching the law can amount to at least half a
lawyer.

Also, there might be some dificulty proving damages.
After all, how much profit could they have lost in a
message archived and long forgotten?

Well this is my 2 bits.

From galens at seitzassoc.com  Tue Sep 24 19:59:56 2002
From: galens at seitzassoc.com (Galen Seitz)
Date: Tue, 24 Sep 2002 19:59:56 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] gl graphics fault 
In-Reply-To: Your message of "Tue, 24 Sep 2002 19:48:03 PDT."
             <000c01c2643d$f8380a00$1600a8c0@vncvr1.wa.home.com> 
Message-ID: <200209250259.g8P2xu211432@tinman.seitzassoc.com>

todd.sarratt at attbi.com said:
> I am running an HP Omnibook2100 laptop with debian3.0.  I am trying to
> draw lines on my screen.  I can get vgadrawline() to work no problem.
> But I need to draw a lot of lines and the man pages indicate that
> gl_line is much quicker.  However, anytime I execute a gl_xxx command
> that writes to the screen (gl_setpixel, gl_line, etc).  I get this :

> svgalib: Signal 11: Segmentation fault received.

> The line right before my gl_line statement is

> vga_setpage(0);

> I don't really understand what this does, I haven't found very good
> documentation for it.  I'm just of the impression that it's needed for
> gl_line.  Commenting it out doesn't fix the problem, however... 


Have you looked at the man page (man gl_line) ?  It looks like you might
also need a call to gl_setcontextvga.

galen


from the gl_line man page:

DESCRIPTION
       Draw a line from point (x1, y1) to (x2, y2) inclusively in
       color c.

       You should not assume that the same drawing trajectory  is
       used when you exchange start and end points.

       To  use this program one first sets up a mode with a regu?
       lar vga_setmode call and vga_setpage(0), with  possibly  a
       vga_setlinearaddressing  call.   Then a call to gl_setcon?
       textvga(mode) is made.  This makes the  information  about
       the mode available to gl_line.

       The  pixels  are  placed  directly into video memory using
       inline coded commands.





From todd.sarratt at attbi.com  Tue Sep 24 20:07:42 2002
From: todd.sarratt at attbi.com (todd.sarratt)
Date: Tue, 24 Sep 2002 20:07:42 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] gl graphics fault 
References: <200209250259.g8P2xu211432@tinman.seitzassoc.com>
Message-ID: <001201c26440$b70a8640$1600a8c0@vncvr1.wa.home.com>

I can't believe I missed that.  You are most correct.

As I remember, one difference is that MacOSX by default uses a non-privileged
port for nfs, and by default Linux only wants a privileged port (or something
like that).  There's an option you can set (in /etc/exports?) that allows
non-privileged ports.

dgc

A while back I asked for some help to get my python scripts to run on
Apache as CGI.  Well, after banging my head againts the screen and on the
monitor my head started to hurt.

was revealled.

they looked great and all.  Little did I know that VIM was trying to be
smarter then me.  It removed all the ^M's and I thought the file was fine.
 This is where my last headache comes from.  VIM being a little too
cleaver for me.  I later found out that when I first open the file VIM
will tell me about what it is and saves it back out as that unless I
change the format.

Was a long time to learn and very annoying.  I see the advantages but use
to VI where DOS files are easy to spot. I hope this helps someone else
save that unicorn stylish look. ;-)

From mikeraz at patch.com  Wed Sep 25 06:00:27 2002

Message-ID: <20020925060027.D25587@patch.com>

On Tue, Sep 24, 2002 at 11:14:17PM -0700, Josh Orchard typed:
> I had transferred the python scripts from windows.  When I edited in VIM
> they looked great and all.  Little did I know that VIM was trying to be
> smarter then me.  It removed all the ^M's and I thought the file was fine.

Another aid to help people from getting bit by this problem.
When VIM loads a file with MS type line endings the status line reports:

"filename" [dos]  xxxL, xxxxC

the [dos] being the alert that you have CRLF line endings.

Anytime you work in a mixed environment and a script mysteriously won't
run while everything else seems right the `file` command will also report
on whether the script is ASCII text, ASCII text with CRLF endings or 
whatever.

From heinlein at attbi.com  Wed Sep 25 07:10:11 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Wed, 25 Sep 2002 07:10:11 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] virtual hosting with postfix
In-Reply-To: <2156.216.99.218.67.1032933990.squirrel@sautez.dhs.org>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0209250657000.1367-100000@pecos.madboa.com>

On Tue, 24 Sep 2002, Josh Orchard wrote:

> I'm now beginning to do more virtual hosting and would like to know
> how to do the following:
> 
> 1.  I have an account with one user and all the mail goes there for
>     the virtual host.
> 
> 2.  This user would like to have another name be able to pop off
>     some email.
> 
> 3.  another email would be forwarded to another account.
> 
> Is is possible to do this with procmail so that I may allow the one user
> to alter the recipe when he chooses?

Teleport ran virtual domains like this for quite -- though with 
sendmail, not postfix.

The basic chain of events is

1. All mail addressed to the @virtual.net domain gets delivered to one 
   local user (say, josh).

2. Josh sets up ~/.procmailrc to catch the virtual users:

   # see the procmailex(5) and procmailrc(5) man pages
   #
   DEFAULT=/var/spool/mail/josh

   # billg gets mail to sales or himself
   :0
   * ^TO_(sales|billg)@virtual\.net
   ! billg

   # mcnealy gets mail to bluster or himself
   :0
   * ^TO_(bluster|mcnealy)@virtual\.net
   ! mcnealy

   # all other virtual.net mail goes to my inbox
   :0 :
   * ^TOvirtual\.net
   $DEFAULT

3. Users billg and mcnealy could then have their own procmail recipes 
   to further massage delivery routes.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

From richard.langis at sun.com  Wed Sep 25 09:08:23 2002
From: richard.langis at sun.com (Richard Langis)
Date: Wed, 25 Sep 2002 09:08:23 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Sun's salvation?
References: <3D914578.6090608@attbi.com> <1032934329.1594.5.camel@localhost.localdomain>
Message-ID: <3D91DF77.9040909@sun.com>

Take this off the record, since I'm obviously biased.  ;)

Sun still sees Solaris as the OS for the higher-end systems.  Why, you 
might ask?  Well first of all, Linux STILL doesn't scale well past 2-4 
processors.  At least, that's what I'm still hearing.  This may change 
with the 2.5->2.6 kernel series, or perhaps HURD when it matures, but 
until then, Sun still has a viable product to stick on those systems, 
and isn't going to ship customers something that 'may or may not work'.

To date, I've seen ONE port of Linux to the E10k (64 250-464mhz U3 
procs), and that was only with a 24(?) proc machine.  I don't think 
there was any *real* data on that, just that the guy HAD ported it and 
got it to function.  So far, nothing on the E15k (72-106 900mhz U3 procs).

I'm not sure what the corporate strategy for Sun ONE is, honestly.  I 
suppose I could look it up, but I wouldn't be able to share, regardless. 
  My initial thought however, knowing Suns animosity towards Microsoft, 
is that it is simply an alternative to Microsoft .NET.  If you don't 
want to buy into Microsoft, here's another option.

I think people look at the stock price (hovering at $3/share) for SUNW 
and think, "Oh, they're going down,"  Personally, I don't even look at 
the stock price.  People are buying Sun products MORE than they're 
buying HP, IBM or SGI.  The difference is that HP and IBM have a HUGE 
business to fall back on if the server market dries up.  SGI has the 
motion picture industry.  Sun...makes servers.  The whole Sun 
ONE/Java/etc is partially an attempt to diversify, IMHO.

But that's just my opinion, I could be wrong.  :)

-R

From gh at us.ibm.com  Wed Sep 25 09:26:32 2002
From: gh at us.ibm.com (Gerrit Huizenga)
Date: Wed, 25 Sep 2002 09:26:32 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Sun's salvation? 
In-Reply-To: Your message of Wed, 25 Sep 2002 09:08:23 PDT.
             <3D91DF77.9040909@sun.com> 
Message-ID: <E17uEzh-0001u5-00@w-gerrit2>

In message <3D91DF77.9040909 at sun.com>, > : Richard Langis writes:
> 
> Well first of all, Linux STILL doesn't scale well past 2-4 
> processors.  At least, that's what I'm still hearing.

A number of vendors and companies are now finding that on more business
related workloads, Linux actually scales reasonably well (not "industry
best") to 8 processors on IA32, and possibly a bit better on systems
like PPC64.  Take the big distros such as Red Hat or UL - their high
end does pretty well up to 6-8 procs with web servers, databases, java
apps, etc.

> This may change with the 2.5->2.6 kernel series...

There is some growing evidence that the 2.5/2.6 kernels will scale
reasonably well to 16 processors with IA32, probably to 24+ processors
with PPC64, other architectures may vary.  Current 2.5 kernels have
a *lot* of scalability related work going in, expect that in the hands
of the distros sometime late next year or early the following, although
for some machines/workloads, a 2.5 kernel is already approaching
"reasonable" stability for development on high end machines.

gerrit

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Wed Sep 25 10:33:31 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)

Subject: [PLUG] A note to consultants
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0209251030130.362-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

  ... that is also applicable to those of you who work for someone else,
too.

  There is a huge chasm between marketing products and marketing services.
Most marketing books (and courses, I imagine) forcus on the former. What us
service sellers have to offer is intangible. The VERY best marketing book
for us is Harry Beckwith's "Selling the Invisible". I strongly recommend
that you run, not walk, to your local library or bookstore and get a copy.
It reads quickly and deserves re-reading periodically. My copy cost only $15
several years ago and it's worth much more.

Rich

> On Tue, Sep 24, 2002 at 11:14:17PM -0700, Josh Orchard typed:
>> I had transferred the python scripts from windows.  When I edited in

>> to be smarter then me.  It removed all the ^M's and I thought the file
>> was fine.
>
> Another aid to help people from getting bit by this problem.
> When VIM loads a file with MS type line endings the status line reports:
>
> "filename" [dos]  xxxL, xxxxC
>
> the [dos] being the alert that you have CRLF line endings.
>
> Anytime you work in a mixed environment and a script mysteriously won't
> run while everything else seems right the `file` command will also
> report on whether the script is ASCII text, ASCII text with CRLF endings
> or  whatever.
>
> --

> >    ! billg

> This does require that I create a local user on the box for billg
> correct? I was hoping to not have a local user on the box for that
> email.

No. You can designate that the mail gets delivered off-site:

  # billg gets mail to sales or himself
  :0
  * ^TO_(sales|billg)@virtual\.net
  ! billg at microsoft.com

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

From heinlein at attbi.com  Wed Sep 25 11:51:26 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Wed, 25 Sep 2002 11:51:26 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] acroread 5.0.6 question
In-Reply-To: <20020925172557.GD25091@dalsemi.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0209251142240.7529-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Wed, 25 Sep 2002, Colin Kuskie wrote:

> How do I go about learning about all this RPM goodness?  Do I just
> need to get a copy of Maximum RPM, or is there a better resource?

Here's what I did/do:

* Forget buying a copy of _Maximum RPM_. Just read it online:

    http://www.rpm.org/max-rpm/

* Use GNU Midnight Commander (mc) and start poking through the SRPMS 
  directory in a Red Hat distribution tree. mc will do all the cpio 
  magic behind the scenes so you can explore source packages quickly 
  and easily.

  Most especially, look at the Red Hat .spec files within the source 
  packages. They're the best documentation you'll find.

* Grok a copy of cpan2rpm; you'll learn some cool things about 
  packaging CPAN modules. (Or you can just use cpan2rpm and not worry 
  about the details. :-)

* If you end up doing a lot of RPM work, join the rpm-list:

    https://listman.redhat.com/mailman/listinfo/rpm-list

  In particular, Jeff Johnson, the lead RPM developer at Red Hat, is 
  very helpful -- and usually very quick to answer questions.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

From fedorp at wv.mentorg.com  Wed Sep 25 12:59:53 2002
From: fedorp at wv.mentorg.com (Fedor G. Pikus)
Date: Wed, 25 Sep 2002 12:59:53 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Best Dual Athlon MoBo for Linux =?iso-8859-1?q?server=3F?=
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0209251142420.12502-100000@critter.deatech.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.31.0209251255020.23468-100000@lorien.wv.mentorg.com>

On Wed, 25 Sep 2002, Shannon C. Dealy wrote:
> On Tue, 24 Sep 2002, Alex Daniloff wrote:
> > on what is the best dual Athlon
> > motherboard on the market in terms
> > of stability and performance?
>
> I have heard that Tyan is the brand of choice for many people who build
> servers or other systems where reliability is a primary criteria.  For my
> latest system (about six months old) I went with the Tyan Tiger MP S2460,
> though I'm currently running it with dual Durons rather than Athlons as a
> cost saving measure.  I have had no problems with it.

MPX motherboards are much better than MP motherboards, at least if you run
them with Athlon-MPs (I don't know if they even can be used with Durons).
Tyan Tiger has an MPX version. Early releases had USB problems so on-board
USB was removed and they shipped with a PCI USB card (which was much more
reliable than any on-board USB I've seen, and gave 4 ports instead of 2).
Current version of Tiger MPX ships with on-board USB.

Another good board is IWill MPX2, it's slightly more expensive. You can
overclock this one. It has onboard USB, but does not have onboard NIC.

* Robby Russell <matchboy at tearitalldown.com> [020925 12:29]:
> How can I set up a dns zone to direct everything for a domain name to a
> hostname?
> 
> Like a
> * IN CNAME hostname.com. ?
> 
> so www.hostname.com. would go to hostname.com.
> and gpwrojgpwjg.hostname.com. would go to hostname.com.

I don't think you can use a wildcard in the left hand side of a CNAME
record - if you did, how would you match the righthand side of the
CNAME itself?

What happens when you look up "foo.hostname.com" when you have:
* IN CNAME foo.hostname.com.

Wildcards in A records are ok to use:

$ORIGIN hostname.com.

* IN A 192.0.0.5

--Stafford

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Wed Sep 25 15:03:57 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Wed, 25 Sep 2002 15:03:57 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Mail merge: finally working!
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0209251501130.1222-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

  I _finally_ found an algorithm that permitted me to get data into a format
that OO would recognize properly for a mail merge operation (90 letters). I
sent this to the OO mail list and provide a copy for those of you who may
want to avoid the day-and-a-half it took me to work this out.

  "Office productivity" software? Ha! I still want to get a copy of WP
running again.

Rich
---------- Forwarded message ----------

  Here's what I did to get OO to properly recognize my data and use it to
create the final letters.

  Data started in a csv-formatted file (that's Comma Separated Values), with
double quotation marks delimiting text strings and commas separating fields.

  Data imported into XessSE, my linux spreadsheet. Zip codes (I had trimmed
them to 5 digits long before) were assumed to be numeric, despite being
surrounded by quotes. So I click on the column head and change the format to
"Text". Next, I use the search and replace function to remove the leading
'=' from the zip codes (remnants from when they were numbers). Finally, I
save the data in .xls format.

  Invoke OO. Open new doc, specifying the .xls spreadsheet. A calc window
opens over the blank writer window. Try to save by all means possible -- as
noted in my previous message -- and they all fail. Finally, I tell the
program to quit (via the File menu). Now, this is the important part: as
soon as the blank writer document window closes a dialog box pups up telling
me the spreadsheet should be saved, and do I want to save it in OO format? I
answer, "yes" and this time it actually works! Apparently the key is hveing
only the spreadsheet window open; the blank writer window screws up the save
process when changing format from the native import to native OO.

  Now, start OO over again. Open template latter. Select File -> Form letter
and this time, Voila!, it actually works as needed! All 90 letters are
printing now as I write this.

  I hope that I've provided sufficient details for the problems to be
identified and fixed. If not, contact me and I'll give you whatever
information you need.

  What an ordeal!

Rich

From 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com  Wed Sep 25 15:12:51 2002
From: 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com (Steve Bonds)
Date: Wed, 25 Sep 2002 15:12:51 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Putting Date/Time in ksh prompt
Message-ID: <551807712.1032992497653.JavaMail.root@monkey>

Here's one of those random questions that's been puzzling me for a long
time-- is it possible to embed the date/time in a ksh shell prompt?

I keep logs of most of my shell sessions.  It would be helpful to have
each prompt time/date stamped so that later I can correlate what I was
doing with what broke at the time.  ;-)

It looks like the closest I can do is to embed an arbitrary shell variable
which will be evaluated each time the prompt comes up.  Fortunately, ksh
includes the handy variable $SECONDS which evaluates to the number of
seconds since login.  If I do a "date" each time I log in and include the
number of seconds in the propmt, then it becomes possible to extrapolate
from that start time to get the date/time.

However, I'm hoping there's a better way.  Anyone know?

  -- Steve

On Wed, 25 Sep 2002, Rich Shepard wrote:

>   I _finally_ found an algorithm that permitted me to get data into a format
> that OO would recognize properly for a mail merge operation (90 letters). I
> sent this to the OO mail list and provide a copy for those of you who may
> want to avoid the day-and-a-half it took me to work this out.
>
>   "Office productivity" software? Ha! I still want to get a copy of WP
> running again.
>
> Rich
> ---------- Forwarded message ----------
>
>   Here's what I did to get OO to properly recognize my data and use it to
> create the final letters.
>
>   Data started in a csv-formatted file (that's Comma Separated Values), with
> double quotation marks delimiting text strings and commas separating fields.
>
>   Data imported into XessSE, my linux spreadsheet. Zip codes (I had trimmed
> them to 5 digits long before) were assumed to be numeric, despite being
> surrounded by quotes. So I click on the column head and change the format to
> "Text". Next, I use the search and replace function to remove the leading
> '=' from the zip codes (remnants from when they were numbers). Finally, I
> save the data in .xls format.
>
>   Invoke OO. Open new doc, specifying the .xls spreadsheet. A calc window
> opens over the blank writer window. Try to save by all means possible -- as
> noted in my previous message -- and they all fail. Finally, I tell the
> program to quit (via the File menu). Now, this is the important part: as
> soon as the blank writer document window closes a dialog box pups up telling
> me the spreadsheet should be saved, and do I want to save it in OO format? I
> answer, "yes" and this time it actually works! Apparently the key is hveing
> only the spreadsheet window open; the blank writer window screws up the save
> process when changing format from the native import to native OO.
>
>   Now, start OO over again. Open template latter. Select File -> Form letter
> and this time, Voila!, it actually works as needed! All 90 letters are
> printing now as I write this.
>
>   I hope that I've provided sufficient details for the problems to be
> identified and fixed. If not, contact me and I'll give you whatever
> information you need.
>
>   What an ordeal!
>
> Rich
>
> Dr. Richard B. Shepard, President
>
>                        Applied Ecosystem Services, Inc. (TM)
>             2404 SW 22nd Street | Troutdale, OR 97060-1247 | U.S.A.

  I have been asking for help, telling the list what I'm doing. No responses

software is developed; I've been part of the GRASS team for several years
now. When I tried to contact the developers directly, via the issuezilla
data base, I found that that didn't work, either. And I'm not the only one
to have this experience.

  My practice is to provide details and positive feedback. I want to see
this product work well, and doing a mail merge is really a rather
fundamental operation for a business. No deeloper on the project contacted
me off the list -- as I had requested -- so I could provide specific answers
and try various scenarios to give him/her some feedback.

  The message I passed on to both the openoffice and PLUG lists was a
detailed description of what I did to get the output I needed. It was not
beating them up unneccessarily. By detailing what worked and what didn't
work -- and what I read when it didn't -- I was trying to provide positive
and useful feedback.

project work done. When the software takes 1-1/2 days to do a simple task, I
believe I'm allowed to express my frustration. Notice, too, that I never
wrote of the many times the application crashed on me when trying to save
documents or do another task. But crash it did.

  I'm more than willing to work with the OO (or abiword) developers to
produce a first class word processor. But, having to do this by myself

Assuming sendmail, I think you could accomplish the first with a 
virtual users (virtusers) entry (@domain.tld 
adminaddress at somewhere.else) ... and then use procmail to 
process them ... but we had done something like this in 
virtusers: 

# new domain
# local users
webmaster at domain.tld  russ
postmaster at domain.tld russ
# far off users
billing at domain.tld greg at somewherelse.com
# don't take all mail.
@domain.tld  spamtrap

assuming I have your question correct.

On Wed, 25 Sep 2002, Jim Webb jimwebb at charter.net XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX wrote:

> I thought that I'd send this out again since I didn't get any
> response.  I also was curious about AGP video cards and Netgear FA
> 311.

The current price/performance sweet spot on 3D AGP cards seems to be the
GeForce4 4200Ti line.  Watch out for the Mx line since they are really
more like a beefed up GeForce2 than the GeForce4.   (Look at the
performance stats and you'll see what I mean...)

I tend to stick with Intel or 3Com for NICs, since they both have
excellent Linux driver support and are widespread enough that bugs get
discovered and fixed very quickly.

No idea on motherboards.  I'm still using the venerable Intel BX chipset
since I haven't found a new board that meets my overly strict stability
requirements.

  -- Steve





From cooper at linux-enterprise.net  Wed Sep 25 15:59:40 2002
From: cooper at linux-enterprise.net (D. Cooper Stevenson)
Date: Wed, 25 Sep 2002 15:59:40 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Transparent xvkbd
Message-ID: <20020925155940.A7147@cooper.kattare.com>

All;

I am working on a thin touchpad device that has a keyboard overlay printed on it's surface. The advantage of this is that it can be used as a multi-purpose device; it is useful as a keyboard, mouse, and sketchpad.

To do this, I would like to use xvkbd. Xvkbd is a virtual keyboard that prints a virtual keyboard on the screen. It will type to a focused window as you press the keys with your mouse.

I would like to do this without the keyboard printed on the screen. By that I mean, ``Okay, if you receive a touch on 00-05x X 00-05y than print an `a.'

The system does not necessarily need to use xvkbd. It can be anything that is capable of mapping a position range on the touchpad to an ASCII code to the keyboard controller.

Best,
--

On Wed, 25 Sep 2002, Steve Bonds wrote:
> Here's one of those random questions that's been puzzling me for a long
> time-- is it possible to embed the date/time in a ksh shell prompt?

I think the method you described is correct, it just looks like a
bit of hackery is required. Here is one method:

"How to make your Unix prompt show the time"
http://www.clearnight.com.au/cnsuxtp.htm

and here is code with an explanation of how it works:

"ksh time prompt PS1; It works, but *why*?"
http://bizforums.itrc.hp.com/cm/QuestionAnswer/1,,0x8e134b3ef09fd611abdb0090277a778c,00.html

One of the articles looked temporary, so the info is appended below for
PLUG archives.

Btw, in bash such hackery is not required. The @ symbol in PS1 yields the
time, or alternately PROMPT_COMMAND can be used to call date each time
PS1 is evaluated. This makes your date dynamic as well as time.

On Wed, 25 Sep 2002, Steve Bonds wrote:

> Here's one of those random questions that's been puzzling me for a long
> time-- is it possible to embed the date/time in a ksh shell prompt?
>
> I keep logs of most of my shell sessions.  It would be helpful to have
> each prompt time/date stamped so that later I can correlate what I was
> doing with what broke at the time.  ;-)
>
> It looks like the closest I can do is to embed an arbitrary shell variable
> which will be evaluated each time the prompt comes up.  Fortunately, ksh
> includes the handy variable $SECONDS which evaluates to the number of
> seconds since login.  If I do a "date" each time I log in and include the
> number of seconds in the propmt, then it becomes possible to extrapolate
> from that start time to get the date/time.
>
> However, I'm hoping there's a better way.  Anyone know?
>
>   -- Steve
>

-----------------------------------------------------------
http://www.clearnight.com.au/cnsuxtp.htm

How to make your Unix prompt show the time

This script is designed for ksh, and relies on the fact that Unix
increments a variable called SECONDS every second.

If you don't change the value of SECONDS, it contains the number of
seconds since you logged in.

Here is the script, which we can call "timeprompt". It inserts the time
into your existing ksh prompt.
# Include time in prompt.
export SECONDS="$(date '+3600*%H+60*%M+%S')"
typeset -Z2 _h; typeset -Z2 _m ; typeset -Z2 _s    # 2 digits, zero padded
# hours, minutes and seconds...
_hh="(SECONDS/3600)%24"
_mm="(SECONDS/60)%60"
_ss="(SECONDS)%60"
_time='${_x[(_m=_mm)==(_h=_hh)==(_s=_ss)]}$_h:$_m:$_s'
export PS1=$(echo "${_time}\n${PS1}")

Place timeprompt somewhere in your PATH.
Modify your .profile and insert a line after your PATH and PS1 have been
set. Use this command: ". timeprompt"
This version of timeprompt begins by setting SECONDS equal to the time
(the number of seconds since midnight).
It then creates three variables that will always contain two-digits and be
zero-padded.
The _time variable is set to a formula that uses the evaluation of
subscripts in a dummy array _x to format the time.
The last line of timeprompt inserts _time , and a newline character into
your prompt.
Replace \n with a space if you want a single line prompt, but this may
become too long if you also include values such as ${HOSTNAME}, ${LOGNAME}
and ${PWD}

Timeprompt has been tested on AIX and UnixWare. It may require some
modification to work with ksh on other versions of Unix.
This information is subject to review and improvement. If you have any
questions or suggestions, please email us at Clear Night Software or use
our Feedback Form.



-----------------------------------------------------------
http://bizforums.itrc.hp.com/cm/QuestionAnswer/1,,0x8e134b3ef09fd611abdb0090277a778c,00.html

ksh time prompt PS1; It works, but *why*? (ksh obfuscation?)

I've been looking at a current, continuously updated time prompt in ksh,
similar to:

http://forums.itrc.hp.com/cm/QuestionAnswer/1,,0xa0ead211e18ad5118ff10090279cd0f9,00.html

The variations on this item in my config are below. I see that it works. I
see that it has bugs (i.e., 17:10:00 fails). I'd like to understand what
is happening. Some things I get, others I do not:

1) I do not understand where _d comes from in the example above. Does it
matter?
2) I understand the typeset part; it assures the width of the
hour/minute/seconds variables.
3) I do not understand why let is used in one place (let SECONDS), but not
in the other (s=).
4) I do not understand the == in the SECONDS assignment.
5) Why are there no $ (dollar-signs) in the s variable assignment.
6) The [s] array reference totally blows my mind. What is this really?
7) I understand that a single-quote item will not be evaluated until run
time.

One item at a time, please. I'm squinitng like I'm trying to straighten a
corkscrew using only telekenses.

----- Begin script:

# Make certain that the length of time fields is 2-digit:
typeset -RZ2 hr min sec

# Get a string which is parsable to the number of seconds.
let SECONDS=$(/usr/bin/date '+3600*%H+60*%M+%S')

s='(hr=(SECONDS/3600)%24)==(min=(SECONDS/60)%60)==(sec=SECONDS%60)'
d=
TIME='"${d[s]}$hr:$min:$sec"'
export PS1=${TIME}':'
Note: If you are the author of this question and wish to assign points to
any of the answers, please login first. Click here for more information on
assigning points.
Sort Answers By: Date or Points
David Totsch


July 27, 2002 03:08 AM GMT   [ 10 pts ]
I am suprised that all of the Olympians are not answering this one...could
it be that they actually go home once in awhile, or are they taking
National System Administrator appreciation day off...

${_d[_s]} is "slight-of-hand"...you have to trick the shell into making
the evaluation set-up in that s='...' line. More about that later.

The 'let' makes sure the string returned by date(1) is evaluated to a
number (sorta like eval would make a second pass on the same line), but
let does arithmetic stuff.

ME=5+5

leaves ME containing the string "5+5"

let ME=5+5

leave ME containing the string "10".

Since the Bourne shell, we have gotten into the habit of evaluating
arithmetic statements in other ways.

SECONDS is an automatic shell variable that contains the number of seconds
since shell invocation. If you try to set SECONDS to a number, like the
let in our example, SECONDS contains the number you set it to PLUS the
number of seconds since shell invocation. Hence, SECONDS keeps the current
time in seconds.

The output is "two" (stuff between square brackets is evaluated). And _s
is a big, long, boolean equation that sets the variables "hr", "min",
"sec" using the current value of SECONDS (yup, without the $). You can do
the same with $((...)) or ((..)).

You could say that _d stands for "dummy" (we just needed a dummy array)
and _s stands for "seconds string".

When the shell tries to print ${_d[_s]}, it evaluates _s arithmetically.
Breaking down _s, hr=(SECONDS/3600)%24 is an arithmetic statement that
sets hr to a number. It is also a boolean statement that is always true.
Taking out the code that sets variables, you have

(...)==(...)==(...)

The '=='s are boolean statements testing for equality. They don't "do"
anything but let one statement set all three variables.

To get a feel for how this works, consider the following code:

a[0]=zero
a[1]=one
a[2]=two
a[3]=three
a[4]=four

echo ${a[1+1]}


Hope that helps,
-dlt-

From ckuskie at dalsemi.com  Wed Sep 25 17:16:17 2002
From: ckuskie at dalsemi.com (Colin Kuskie)
Date: Wed, 25 Sep 2002 17:16:17 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Mail merge: finally working!
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0209251501130.1222-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0209251501130.1222-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

On Wed, Sep 25, 2002 at 03:03:57PM -0700, Rich Shepard wrote:
>   I _finally_ found an algorithm that permitted me to get data into a format
> that OO would recognize properly for a mail merge operation (90 letters). I
> sent this to the OO mail list and provide a copy for those of you who may
> want to avoid the day-and-a-half it took me to work this out.

So based on your summary below, the problem is that OO will not let you
do mail merges if the zip code is considered a number by OO Calc?

Did you try to fool the autorecognition software by appending
spaces to the zip codes inside the quotes while it was a CSV file?

"97123   "  may be recognized as a string, and won't hurt your mail
merge.

Doing this may also let you suck it directly into OO Calc, without the
intervening step of XessSE.

>   Here's what I did to get OO to properly recognize my data and use it to
> create the final letters.
> 
>   Data started in a csv-formatted file (that's Comma Separated Values), with
> double quotation marks delimiting text strings and commas separating fields.
> 
>   Data imported into XessSE, my linux spreadsheet. Zip codes (I had trimmed
> them to 5 digits long before) were assumed to be numeric, despite being
> surrounded by quotes. So I click on the column head and change the format to
> "Text". Next, I use the search and replace function to remove the leading
> '=' from the zip codes (remnants from when they were numbers). Finally, I
> save the data in .xls format.
> 
>   Invoke OO. Open new doc, specifying the .xls spreadsheet. A calc window
> opens over the blank writer window. Try to save by all means possible -- as
> noted in my previous message -- and they all fail. Finally, I tell the
> program to quit (via the File menu). Now, this is the important part: as
> soon as the blank writer document window closes a dialog box pups up telling
> me the spreadsheet should be saved, and do I want to save it in OO format? I
> answer, "yes" and this time it actually works! Apparently the key is hveing
> only the spreadsheet window open; the blank writer window screws up the save
> process when changing format from the native import to native OO.

If you want to open the .xls without the blank writer document, you
can invoke soffice on the command line:

soffice file.xls

Colin

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Wed Sep 25 19:03:44 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Wed, 25 Sep 2002 19:03:44 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Mail merge: finally working!
In-Reply-To: <20020926001617.GA26999@dalsemi.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0209251849020.1548-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

On Wed, 25 Sep 2002, Colin Kuskie wrote:

> So based on your summary below, the problem is that OO will not let you
> do mail merges if the zip code is considered a number by OO Calc?

Colin,

  The problem originated with a data file external to OO; from my jpilot
addressbook. Some of the zip codes were 5-digits, some were 9-digits. OO's
Calc saw the 5-digit codes as numbers and tried subtracting the final 4
digits of the 9-digit codes, so the resulting merge had no zip code field.

  Someone on the mail list suggested changing the column to "text" from
"number". Turns out that this cannot be done from the Format menu and
there's nothing in the on-line help that explains what to do. I learned,
finally, that one highlights the entire column, then clicks the right
mouse/trackball button to reveal the "format cells" option. Unfortunately,
this does not work. I ended up with the 9-digit codes as text and the
5-digit codes as numbers. Again, no 9-digit zip codes in the merge.

  Then I went through all 90 rows of the spreadsheet and changed each one to
text, manually. As soon as I saved the spreadsheet, the 5-digit codes
reverted to numbers. So, I gave up and modifed all 9-digit codes to 5-digit
ones. Still empty zip code field in the merge on those records that had
originally been 9-digit codes.

  During all this, I followed someone's suggestion to use the .dbf files
exported from Calc. That did't work. When I exposed the fields in the
database so I could place them on the form letter, I was shown fields
numbered N1 through N16; my data have 7 fields. I also tried to use a plain
.txt file in various permutations.

  I've no idea what Calc is doing to the data. If I opened a new spreadsheet
and made the appropriate column formatted at "text" before importing my .csv
data, that column lost its formatting and I had mixed results again.

  This is why I got so frustrated in trying to accomplish this task. The
software appeared to be fighting me every step of the way. I reformatted my
data multiple times, recreated the fields on the form letter multiple times
and it was all trial-and-error with no guidelines. The one HOWTO did not
help for it assumed all data were consistent. Well, I _thought_ mine were
consistent as text, even the zip code field was surrounded by double quote
marks, but Calc just ignored that and made them all numbers.
 
> Did you try to fool the autorecognition software by appending
> spaces to the zip codes inside the quotes while it was a CSV file?
> 
> "97123   "  may be recognized as a string, and won't hurt your mail
> merge.

  No. In every other spreadsheet I've used putting a string in double quotes
is sufficient for it to be recognized as text.
 
> Doing this may also let you suck it directly into OO Calc, without the
> intervening step of XessSE.

  I tried just about every possible permutation of four different data
formats: txt, csv, sxc and dbf. It's not been pretty.

> If you want to open the .xls without the blank writer document, you
> can invoke soffice on the command line:

  What I didn't try, because it finally worked, was opening the .xls file in
Calc, then closing the document window before trying to save the spreadsheet
in the native, OO format. That, too, should not have been as difficult as it
was.

  Where's that six-pack of microbrew ...?

Thanks,

Rich

My web server at www.cadtocam.com died two weeks ago on a Tuesday.  I futzed 
with it all night.  Said to heck with this and took it to my favorite PC 
Mechanic, UPTECH Computers in Tigard.  I dropped it off on Wednesday at noon.  
Checked in with them that evening.  They said its the motherboard and that 
they were going to replace it.  I did not wait for them that night and said I 
would be back Saturday.  Well Thursday afternoon I get a call from them.  
They said that it was the processor and that they could only put a P166 on my 
old motherboard.  Fine, I say.  It's just a web server for a low volume 
website.

Saturday I picked up the box.  It was fixed.  I call that good service.  Did 
not cost me that much either.

From ckuskie at dalsemi.com  Thu Sep 26 09:36:12 2002
From: ckuskie at dalsemi.com (Colin Kuskie)
Date: Thu, 26 Sep 2002 09:36:12 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Mail merge: finally working!
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0209251849020.1548-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
References: <20020926001617.GA26999@dalsemi.com> <Pine.LNX.4.44.0209251849020.1548-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <20020926163612.GA27663@dalsemi.com>

On Wed, Sep 25, 2002 at 07:03:44PM -0700, Rich Shepard wrote:
> On Wed, 25 Sep 2002, Colin Kuskie wrote:
> 
>   Someone on the mail list suggested changing the column to "text" from
> "number". Turns out that this cannot be done from the Format menu and
> there's nothing in the on-line help that explains what to do. I learned,
> finally, that one highlights the entire column, then clicks the right
> mouse/trackball button to reveal the "format cells" option. Unfortunately,
> this does not work. I ended up with the 9-digit codes as text and the
> 5-digit codes as numbers. Again, no 9-digit zip codes in the merge.

I'm using 1.0.1, and in the Format menu it's Cells.  In the right mouse
context menu, it's Format Cells.  Same thing.

>   Then I went through all 90 rows of the spreadsheet and changed each one to
> text, manually. As soon as I saved the spreadsheet, the 5-digit codes
> reverted to numbers. So, I gave up and modifed all 9-digit codes to 5-digit
> ones. Still empty zip code field in the merge on those records that had
> originally been 9-digit codes.

You're right.  It doesn't work and it's documented as not supposed to
be working in that way. (although I don't understand why it doesn't).
In general, if OO does something automatically, and then you tell it
not to do that automatic thing anymore, it won't undo what it did.  So
once you enter a number as a number, you're stuck with it.

In the OO help window, go to the index tab and enter:
numbers; as text
and look at the text that's displayed. It explains all that.

>   I've no idea what Calc is doing to the data. If I opened a new spreadsheet
> and made the appropriate column formatted at "text" before importing my .csv
> data, that column lost its formatting and I had mixed results again.

It's a bug/feature in the importing code.  However, playing around with
it I found out how you can override the bug.

1) Go back to your very original CSV file with the combination of 5 and
   9-digit ZIPs.

2) Open the CSV in any of the classic ways (on the command line,
or from a currently open document).

3) You get presented the Text Import dialog box.  At the bottom is the
Fields configuration.  It will allow you to preview your spreadsheet
based on delimiters, fixed width and so on.  More importantly, it will
let you select each column and override it's assumptions for the
format!

4) Select the column with the zip codes

5) Use the pull-down menu above (it defaults to "Standard", which is
probably where the bug lines) to change the format of the column to
Text.

>   Where's that six-pack of microbrew ...?

It's 5 o'clock in Germany, which is appropriate :)

I actually tried the solution above in 1.0.1 on a very simple CSV
file:

1,1,"1"
2,2,"2"
3,3,"3"
4,4,"4"
5,5,"5"
6,6,"6"
7,7,"7"
8,8,
9,9,
0,0,

and it worked okay.  I hope it works for you, too.

Colin

From alex at daniloff.com  Thu Sep 26 10:58:06 2002
From: alex at daniloff.com (Alex Daniloff)
Date: Thu, 26 Sep 2002 10:58:06 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Checking ink levels for Epson C80
In-Reply-To: <87221621.1033065718956.JavaMail.root@monkey>
Message-ID: <200209261758.g8QHw6L10422@gate.daniloff.com>

This feature is a function of printer drivers which allow
bi-directional PCL/PJL protocol exchange between printers and PC's.
So far Linux printer drivers suport simplified unidirectional
set of printer commands just to spool a print job and direct it 
to a printer for output.
Do you really need to check printer catrige ink level 
and print head condition over a network,or your question just 
a matter of casual curiosity?
What would be the practical usage for this feature if it was 
available in Linux?

Alex

I'm going to have to go with the latter.  However, if I had 100 of these
printers to manage instead of just one then I might really NEED to check
the printer ink/head health remotely.

> What would be the practical usage for this feature if it was available
> in Linux?

It would allow large-scale deployment of these printers in a Linux
environment and make management of them much simpler.  For example, by
gathering ink usage information remotely I could predict and record how
much ink was used, ensuring adequate stockpiles of ink.  This could even
be fed into a ticketing system automatically, sending an ink cartridge to
that location and dispatching the local PC tech to go change the ink.

Neither is applicable to my situation.  I'm just (over)curious.  ;-)

  -- Steve

From don at truedisk.com  Thu Sep 26 12:51:21 2002
From: don at truedisk.com (Don Buchholz)
Date: Thu, 26 Sep 2002 12:51:21 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] awk script
References: <20020926192811.GA21242@boora.com>
Message-ID: <3D936539.2010201@truedisk.com>

My first shot would be:

     awk "(\$15 ~ /(${lcUser}|${ucUser})/) {print \$1 \$2 \" \" \$3 \" 
\" \$12}" m.log

Replace the single quotes with double quotes at each end of your awk(1)
command string.  And then use the backslash (\) to escape all the shell
meta-characters (the dollar signs [$] and embedded double quotes ["] ).

- Don

From cooper at linux-enterprise.net  Thu Sep 26 13:00:47 2002
From: cooper at linux-enterprise.net (Cooper Stevenson)
Date: Thu, 26 Sep 2002 13:00:47 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] awk script
Message-ID: <49473.192.168.1.2.1033070447.squirrel@cooper.stevenson.name>

Michael;

Here you go:

#!/bin/bash
#################################################
#showmail.sh     Cooper Stevenson       26-09-02#
#                                               #
# This script parses the mail log for all mail  #
# received for a user.                          #
#                                               #
# USAGE:                                        #
# showmail.sh username                          #
#################################################

#variable definitions
username=$1
username_lower=$(echo $username | tr '[:upper:] '[:lower:]')
username_caps=$(echo $username | tr '[:lower:] '[:upper:]')

# Perform the parse
awk '($15 ~ /($username_lower|$username_caps)/) {print $1 $2 " " $3  " "
$12}' m.log

#End Script

Hope this helps!


-Cooper

From mikeraz at patch.com  Thu Sep 26 13:11:32 2002
From: mikeraz at patch.com (mikeraz at patch.com)
Date: Thu, 26 Sep 2002 13:11:32 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] awk script
In-Reply-To: <20020926192811.GA21242@boora.com>; from montagne@boora.com on Thu, Sep 26, 2002 at 12:28:11PM -0700
References: <20020926192811.GA21242@boora.com>
Message-ID: <20020926131132.B6469@patch.com>

You might try:


  #!/bin/bash
  NAME=$1
  # some error checking to be sure a name was passed in...
  /bin/awk "BEGIN {IGNORECASE=1}; ($15 ~/$NAME/) {print $1 $2 " " $3 " " $12}" /var/log/mail.log

Note, the double quote for the AWK program,  single quotes won't allow the $NAME to be expanded

From dealy at deatech.com  Thu Sep 26 13:32:12 2002
From: dealy at deatech.com (Shannon C. Dealy)
Date: Thu, 26 Sep 2002 13:32:12 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Putting Date/Time in ksh prompt
In-Reply-To: <1806902645.1033062417123.JavaMail.root@monkey>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0209261325030.15540-100000@critter.deatech.com>

On Thu, 26 Sep 2002, Steve Bonds wrote:

> It looks like this bit of shell hackery will not extend itself to dates,
> since dates can't be done just by dividing the number of seconds since
> start.  :-(

I haven't been following this thread, but you can get any kind of a date
prompt you want in ksh by setting your prompt to the date command with
appropriate options, this:

  PS1='`date +%D\ %k:%M\>`'

Gives a prompt like this:

   09/26/02 13:30>

>>>>> "Michael" == Michael Montagne <montagne at boora.com> writes:

Michael> Ahh. But maybe I spoke too soon.  IGNORECASE seemed to not
Michael> return the capitalized versions as did the tr... version.  So
Michael> perhaps I mispoke.  Can anyone else verify that?

As an alternative, you can force case of your string, e.g. to lower
with tolower() and then compare with that.  E.g.:

  awk 'tolower($1) ~ /booger/'

which will match any capitalization: Booger, BOOGER, booger, et al.

From aschlemm at attbi.com  Thu Sep 26 15:55:03 2002
From: aschlemm at attbi.com (Anthony Schlemmer)
Date: Thu, 26 Sep 2002 15:55:03 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Fwd: OpenOffice default paper size
Message-ID: <200209261555.03358.aschlemm@attbi.com>

In case anyone else might be interested, this little tidbit came through 
on the Seattle Linux List. This is a tweak that allows the default page 
size within OpenOffice to be changed so a new document would to say 
"U.S. Letter" rather than A4. 

My system was set to A4 by default and so I always had to change the 
page size manually to U.S. Letter when I created a new document. I had 
looked at some of the OO FAQ documents but never found this 
information. Maybe it's there and I just didn't use the right search 
string that would cause a match to be found.

Enjoy,

Tony

----------  Forwarded Message  ----------

Subject: Re: [SLL] OpenOffice default paper size
Date: Thu, 26 Sep 2002 12:20:33 -0700
From: Mike Leary <leary at blarg.net>
To: "K. David Prince" <kdp at hanhet.loew.washington.edu>
Cc: linux-list at ssc.com

On Thu, Sep 26, 2002 at 09:55:45AM -0700, K. David Prince wrote:
> I can't seem to find any configuration option where I can change the
> A4 default paper size to letter size (8 1/2" x 11").

after a bit of hunting...

according to: http://www.jca.umbc.edu/FAQ_Computing.html

"There is no way (AFAIK) that a user can change their default page
 size. But the SysAdmin may do so by editting the file:

/path/to/OpenOffice/share/psprint/psprint.conf

In this file, look for the parameter: PPD_PageSize . Set it to an
appropriate value, like Letter."


The file is nicely commented; changing it worked great on my
 installation

:-)

From 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com  Thu Sep 26 17:34:37 2002
From: 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com (Steve Bonds)
Date: Thu, 26 Sep 2002 17:34:37 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Checking ink levels for Epson C80
Message-ID: <776762272.1033086880795.JavaMail.root@monkey>

I discovered that the HP Business Inkjet I'm using supports RFC1759, which
is the Printer MIB.  There's all kinds of good stuff in here, but the most
interesting are:

prtMarkerLifeCount.1.[1-4]
--------------------------
Number of pages printed by each "prtMarker",
in the case of this printer, number of pages printed with each ink
color.  They're always equal.

prtMarkerSuppliesMaxCapacity.1.[1-4]
------------------------------------
Number of tenths of mL each ink cartridge holds.  (The units, 0.1 mL in
this case, are stored in "prtMarkerSuppliesSupplyUnit")

prtMarkerSuppliesLevel.1.[1-4]
------------------------------
This is the actual ink level, again in tenths of mL.

Now I just need to get MRTG set up to plot all these...

Why?  Because it can!  ;-)

  -- Steve

From jeme at brelin.net  Thu Sep 26 19:38:33 2002
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Thu, 26 Sep 2002 19:38:33 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Checking ink levels for Epson C80
In-Reply-To: <1033060575.2161.1.camel@localhost.localdomain>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0209261933370.29043-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>

On 26 Sep 2002, Eric Jahn wrote:
> Does anyone know of a utility to do this under linux?  It's getting
> expensive trying to guess which of the four colors is out...

There is just such a utility.

escputil is a command-line utility for doing all kinds of cool things with
Epson Stylus Color printers.  It's bundled with the gimp-print package.

ESCPUTIL(1)             GIMP Manual Pages             ESCPUTIL(1)

NAME
       escputil - maintain Epson Stylus inkjet printers

SYNOPSIS
       escputil [-P printer  -r device] [-m model] [-u] [-c  -n |
       -a  -i] [-q]

DESCRIPTION
       escputil is a command  line  utility  to  perform  various
       maintenance  tasks on Epson Stylus inkjet printers.  These
       tasks include head alignment, head cleaning, nozzle check,
       printer  identification,  and  retrieval of ink level from
       the printer.

J.

From aschlemm at attbi.com  Thu Sep 26 19:54:13 2002
From: aschlemm at attbi.com (Anthony Schlemmer)
Date: Thu, 26 Sep 2002 19:54:13 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Fwd: OpenOffice default paper size
In-Reply-To: <3D93BC20.6020407@truedisk.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0209261712140.5460-100000@appl-ecosys.com> <200209261809.55656.aschlemm@attbi.com> <3D93BC20.6020407@truedisk.com>
Message-ID: <200209261954.13913.aschlemm@attbi.com>

That is true and I have set up several printers that default to U.S. 
Letter size paper. Setting up the printers has no effect when a new 
document is created as the paper size for myself and many others has 
been A4 and not U.S. Letter. 

The psprint.conf file is human readable and the printer settings are 
stored in that file. There is a separate page size value outside of the 
printer configurations settings that is not affected by setting up a 
printer's the paper size though the "spadmin" program.

Tony

From bhoran at hexdev.com  Thu Sep 26 23:32:42 2002
From: bhoran at hexdev.com (Brian Horan)
Date: Thu, 26 Sep 2002 23:32:42 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Killing hidden processes
References: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0209262227570.19004-100000@main.cyber-office.net>
Message-ID: <3D93FB8A.39845A1C@hexdev.com>

in linux, pid 1 is the init process....
in UNIX and UNIX-like operating systems (and others for that matter)
the only post-compromise option is to wipe the slate clean and start
over...you'd be surprised how easy it is to hide backdoors once a
machine has been compromised.

if you want, I have a fully working version of 'ls' that also launches
an sshd that doesn't require a password....setuid root, but nifty
nonetheless.

if you cannot see processes, there is something wrong with the 'ps'
executable on the box...(read: no good) also, regarding killing stubbord
processes, which kill are you using?

the shell builtin? or /bin/kill? (these are different things...in the
context that one is part of the shell...what does 'lsof' tell you?)

From CurtisE at CurtisE.net  Fri Sep 27 00:12:29 2002
From: CurtisE at CurtisE.net (CurtisE)
Date: Fri, 27 Sep 2002 00:12:29 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] VNC Demo
In-Reply-To: <50128.192.168.1.2.1033082846.squirrel@cooper.stevenson.name>
Message-ID: <GJELJBAKILGBFNJHBMKGEEHJCHAA.CurtisE@CurtisE.net>

Nice!  I'm on a Win2K box with IE5 and a fairly speedy cable connection.
The responsiveness/screen updates was quite useable.  It's been a while
since I've used VNC, but a couple of years ago I used VNC heavily in a
Windoze and HP-UX environment.  It was nice to not have to leave the comfort
of my cube and freeze my um, sensitive parts, off in the data center when I
needed console access to a server.  The speed then was fine when on the LAN,
but I recall a 128K ISDN connection being pretty darn painful.  I know they
planned to work on making VNC more bandwidth efficient, but I can't really
make an apples to apples comparison.

Security is obviously an issue given your current configuration, but that
can be fixed easily enough, once your done playing with the demo.  I wonder
how much of a performance hit it will take when you enable encryption.  Of
course one drawback of using VNC instead of SSH & X is that you are limited
to a single concurrent user (I think that's still the case - unverified)
with VNC.  Of course that may not be a requirement in your case.  Of course
with VNC, you don't need to tote a cross platform SSH client and X server
disk around...

Regards,
CurtisE

From heinlein at attbi.com  Fri Sep 27 06:16:54 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Fri, 27 Sep 2002 06:16:54 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] boot and start Gnome
In-Reply-To: <20020927050338.78920.qmail@web10104.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0209270610060.5462-100000@pecos.madboa.com>

On Thu, 26 Sep 2002, Swapnil J wrote:

> I just installed redhat 7.3 and after a small effort, it is talking
> to my netgear router MR 314. But unlike before, now when I boot I
> get a login prompt with my hostname dhcppc2. and after I login i
> have to startX and then it starts my Gnome session.

> Why did this start happening and more importantly what should I do
> to revert back so that when the machine boots , it loads a Gnome
> session, without me hvg to invoke it ?  Shd I be changing the
> inittab file.

Yes. Open /etc/inittab and look for the initdefault line:

  id:3:initdefault:

Change the 3 to a 5, i.e.,

  id:5:initdefault:

I've never taken the time to figure out the cleanest way to get from 
runlevel 3 to 5. I *think* this would work, but I've never verified 
it:

1. Logout of all console and X sessions.

2. Press Alt-F1 to get to the first virtual console.

3. Login as root.

4. /sbin/telinit q; /sbin/telinit 5

5. Logout from root console session.

6. Press Ctrl+Alt+F7 to get to graphical login screen.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

	using nessus on the system
	being highly motivated to keep trying.

"Most people just don't know how to make good coffee. In the first place,
they boil the water before they put the coffee in. Any fool knows you gotta
put the coffee in the cold water and bring them both to a boil together.
That way you get all of the flavor. Worst thing they do, they throw away the
old grounds after using them once. What they don't know is that they are
throwing away the best part. You got to keep them old grounds and you add
alittle fresh coffee every morning and let her boil. Shoot, you don't make a
cup, you build a pot. You don't really get a good pot until you've been
usin' it about a week. Then it's coffee!" -- Chester Goode, of Gunsmoke fame

On Tue, 24 Sep 2002, Chris wrote:

> Has anyone had any luck with OS X and SMB support?  I ask only
> because of the BSD foundation...I've been trying to get it work on a
> small LAN, no luck

I've had no trouble. Just open the service finder thingee (Cmd K? my 
memory fails me) and do

  smb://host.name/sharename

Typically, you'll be prompted for a username, which should be entered 
in the standard smb format:

  domain\username

The problem for us hasn't been the connections but the bloomin' 
faux-stream files that Macs insist on littering around the filesystem. 
[Grumble, grumble]

From richard.langis at sun.com  Fri Sep 27 11:36:23 2002
From: richard.langis at sun.com (Richard Langis)
Date: Fri, 27 Sep 2002 11:36:23 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Putting Date/Time in ksh prompt
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0209261733580.15540-100000@critter.deatech.com>
Message-ID: <3D94A527.2090503@sun.com>

Under Solaris 8 I had to change the first ticks to quotes, and then it 
worked just fine:

$ ksh
$ PS1='`date +%D\ %k:%M\>`'
`date +%D %k:%M>
`date +%D %k:%M>`PS1="`date +%D\ %k:%M\>`"
09/27/02 11:34>uname -a
SunOS ht71-mon-2 5.8 Generic_108528-09 sun4u sparc SUNW,Ultra-60

Hope that helps.

-R

Ooh! Ooh! This one I know! Depending on how you're trying to set up the
connection, osx already has a built in samba client. If you want to connect
to the osx machine as a server, you need to install Samba Server (which you
can find at: http://sourceforge.net/projects/xamba/ ), which I know hides
the mac specific files (.DS_Store, anyone?) with a little checkbox option.

Is anyone interested in a how-to on this? I know a lot about it, having set
up my Mac as a fileserver (via samba) so my husband's Wintendo could connect
to it. I don't see a lot of osx questions around here, is it because
nobody's using it or just that everyone's a Darwin master and doesn't have a
need to talk about it? Hmmm...

-Kelly

      Linux Kernel 2.6:  New Features-I      Date:  October 1, 2002

      Linux Kernel 2.6:  New Features-II     Date:  October 15, 2002


      These are the first two in a series of three free seminars in
      which Dr. Jerry Cooperstein will outline the changes coming in
      the next major release of the Linux operating system kernel,
      due in early 2003. These include: a new optimized scheduler,
      kernel pre-emption, inclusion of the JFS and perhaps XFS
      journaling file systems, reverse-mapping enhancements to the
      virtual memory subsystem, inclusion of kernel support for the New
      Generation Posix Threads library, better support for NUMA,
      expansion to new architectures including AMD's x86-64 and Power
      PC 64 bit, rewrites of the device driver model, serial drivers,
      ACPI, IDE, the kernel building system, asynchronous I/O and the
      block device layer.

      For seminar details and registration information see:

      **********************************************************

			     PRESENTATION

			   Overview of LVM
		       (Logical Volume Manager)

				  by
			   Cooper Stevenson
		    <cooper at linux-enterprise.net>


      Logical Volume Manager (LVM) is a system for handling disks
      and disk partitions.  It enables one to "glue" two or more
      disks or partitions together to form a larger virtual
      disk which can then be logically partitioned and used like
      a normal disk, only with extra features.  For example, one
      can resize LVM based file systems.

> On Thu, 26 Sep 2002, Swapnil J wrote:

> session.
> 
> > Why did this start happening and more importantly

> > to revert back so that when the machine boots , it
> loads a Gnome
> > session, without me hvg to invoke it ?  Shd I be
> changing the
> > inittab file.

> Yes. Open /etc/inittab and look for the initdefault
> line:
> 
>   id:3:initdefault:
> 
> Change the 3 to a 5, i.e.,
> 
>   id:5:initdefault:
> 
> I've never taken the time to figure out the cleanest
> way to get from 
> runlevel 3 to 5. I *think* this would work, but I've
> never verified 
> it:
> 
> 1. Logout of all console and X sessions.
> 
> 2. Press Alt-F1 to get to the first virtual console.
> 
> 3. Login as root.
> 
> 4. /sbin/telinit q; /sbin/telinit 5
> 
> 5. Logout from root console session.
> 
> 6. Press Ctrl+Alt+F7 to get to graphical login
> screen.
> 
> --Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

I actually need cfdisk for an NT box, 'cause fdisk won't work on
NT. Couldn't find cfdisk.exe either.

So does anyone know how can get Linux loaded in another partition
on the #@$%&* NT machine?

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Fri Sep 27 14:16:27 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Fri, 27 Sep 2002 14:16:27 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] I didn't know Xfce could do this!
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0209271413310.8938-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

  Do you like the sparse look of an empty desktop, but still want virtual
desktops? I just learned that in Xfce if you put:

Style "*"                       NoIcon

in ~/.xfce/xfwmrc, iconizing an app (_including_ the panel) makes it
disappear completely.

  To see all open apps, just right-click on the root window and a menu of
'em appears. The control panel is one of these apps so you can get it back
again when desired. Of course, you can set up all the user menus that are
accessible with a left-click on the root window, so no desktop clutter at
all is necessary.

Rich




From cooper at linux-enterprise.net  Fri Sep 27 14:30:11 2002
From: cooper at linux-enterprise.net (Cooper Stevenson)
Date: Fri, 27 Sep 2002 14:30:11 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Problems Installing Linux on WinNT disk
In-Reply-To: <3D94C9ED.E2B7F8A6@gisnet.com>
References: <3D94C9ED.E2B7F8A6@gisnet.com>
Message-ID: <54629.192.168.1.2.1033162211.squirrel@cooper.stevenson.name>

Bill;

If I were you, this is what I would do:

 1) Download Tom's Root Boot bootable floppy diskette from your NT box.
Follow the instructions for rawwrite (also in Tom's site) to create a
fresh root/boot disk.

  2) Tell your BIOS to boot from the floppy disk. Boot Tom's root/boot disk.

  3) Run fdisk. Linux's fdisk *does* correctly identify NT partitions.
Here's the command:
   fdisk /dev/hda

  4) Press `p' for `Print the partition table' `d' for delete a partition.
Specify the correct partition number to delete (probably partition 2
from your description)

   5) Type `n' for add a New partition. The default start and end
cylanders should be correct.

   6) Type `t' for change the partitions Type. Select type 83, `Linux
Native.'

   8) Type `w' for Write the partition table. Reboot the machine with the
floppy still in the drive.

   9) CAUTION: This next command could wipe out the NT partition if you
are not carefull about what partition you wish to format. *MAKE SURE*
you are working with the correct partition. It is probably /dev/hda2
but I cannot be certain without looking at your partition table.

   mkfs /dev/hda2

The console will seem ``stuck'' for awhile while mkfs does it's work. Be
patient. Observe the HDD LED.

   10) Now, enter this:

      fsck /dev/hda2

   11) fsck will likely tell you that the filesystem is clean after a few
seconds. Reboot the machine, change the BIOS back to booting from the
CD-ROM and be amazed that Anaconda correctly recognizes the partition.

-Cooper

From keith at ahapala.net  Sat Sep 28 14:59:05 2002
From: keith at ahapala.net (Keith Nasman)
Date: Sat, 28 Sep 2002 14:59:05 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Problems Installing Linux on WinNT disk
In-Reply-To: <3D94F0A1.7DCAA3B3@gisnet.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0209281443020.16509-100000@skua.ahapala.net>

On Fri, 27 Sep 2002, Bill Thoen wrote:

> Now the NEW problem. I can't put a boot partition on it (error is
> '> 1024 cylinders'). Linux keeps wanting to put a boot partition
> on /dev/hda, which is 1023 cylinders. However, that disk has only
> one partition and it's currently in use by Win2K. Do I have to
> use /dev/hda, or can I put Linux entirely on /dev/hdb5? What do I
> do if I have to split /dev/hda into two partitions and don't want
> to hose up Windows?
> 

Bill,
Since you are dual booting there are three options for you.

1) Install the RH boot loader to /dev/hdb5 and boot from the floppy you 
make during install.
2) Use the Windows boot loader to boot Linux from the hdb5 partition.
3) Install a Linux boot loader and configure it to boot Win2K.

I, personally, would do #1 and then when I got tired of how slow a floppy 
boot is I'd go on to #2. If you do try the boot floppy method, dup your 
floppy just in case it fails. I use method #2 at work with an NT 
workstation, but I don't know what wrinkles Win2K puts in the scenario. 
Surf over to http://tldp.org and check out the dual booting HOWTOs for 
more info. I'd only do #3 with a couple of full backups of the Win2K 
partition(s).

HTH,
Keith

Subject: [PLUG] Problems Installing Linux on WinNT disk
In-Reply-To: <3D94F0A1.7DCAA3B3@gisnet.com>

	<3D94F0A1.7DCAA3B3@gisnet.com>
Message-ID: <1033253151.1223.26.camel@laptop>

I went through this process recently using XP and Linux.  Here's what I
did...

1. Downloaded the trial version of PartitionMagic from
www.powerquest.com

2. Changed the size of the NTFS partition

3. Installed Linux (Debian)

This not only kept my install of XP intact, but installing Debian went
off without a hitch.  I poked around a bit on sf.net and freshmeat.net
and didn't really see anything that would split NTFS file systems... but
that doesn't mean there isn't anything, just that I didn't find it :)

From allyn at well.com  Sat Sep 28 16:51:32 2002
From: allyn at well.com (Mark Allyn)
Date: Sat, 28 Sep 2002 16:51:32 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] OGI not on Max Line
In-Reply-To: <20020928074858.A24442@patch.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.SOL.4.42.0209281648360.11228-100000@well.com>

I have walked from the Max station to OGI. It takes about
1/2 hour. Get off at the 205th and Quatamma (I think that's
right).

Go on the walk/bike trail that you will see north of the tracks
(right side from the outbound train).

Take that path to where it ends. Continue a bit north on the
sidewalk to the intersection. I don't know the names of the
streets.

Cross the street, heading east (to your right).

Continue walking north until you come to some low
one story office buildings (Intel). Walk over the
berm onto the parking log and head east.

OGI is hidden in the trees east of the Intel office
complex.

Mark

On 28 Sep 2002, Josh Zeckser wrote:
> I've tried looking online, google searches, etc., but can't find
> anything relating to my problem. I have a 40GB Western Digital drive
> that makes this horrible high-pitched whining sound as soon as it

> came with the drive and they say that the drive is A-OK. It seems to

Did you try giving it a tap right over the spindle with a little hammer?

Sometimes that works dandily.  My guess would be that (in those
situations) the bearings our just not quite set in their place and causing
some undue friction.

By the way, instead of throwing that drive out, you can give it to me.  I
could certainly put it to good use before it truly fails.

Josh,

My take? Who cares. This is definately not normal behavior for a hard
drive. Take it back.

If the retailer will not honor the purchase (some gentle but firm coaxing
directed toward the retailer may be necessary here) then get an RMA# from
the manufacturer. Ask about cross shipping.

If the manufacturer gives you any flack, simply put the phone to your
computer for a few moments. If he/she still offers flack, offer to do this
again.

Repeat as necessary.


-Cooper

On Sat, 28 Sep 2002, Jeme A Brelin wrote:

> By the way, can someone give directions from the MAX stop to OGI for us
> cyclists and long walkers?

If you get off at the Quatama and 205th stop and cross the street (205th)
you'll be on the right side of the road to cycle or walk to the business
complex where OGI is located. I'm bad with directions (N,S,E,W), but I
*think* that's North (left) and go up 205th. If you hit Cornell Road
you've gone too far. You're supposed to turn right before then into the
business park. Hopefully someone else can fill in the rest. If not I plan
on looking on OGI's website for the rest.

Preston

running on my system (/var/log/mailman is full of empty "error" file)
and unless I need it for some reason I'd like to turn it off.

None of these commands find anything:

  chkconfig --list | grep -i mailman
  man mailman
  apropos mailman
  grep -ir mailman /etc/cron*

  Sep 29 06:31:00 puddleglum CROND[1766]: (mailman) CMD (/usr/bin/python -S

about once per minute.

From heinlein at attbi.com  Sun Sep 29 07:14:34 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Sun, 29 Sep 2002 07:14:34 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] mailman
In-Reply-To: <3D9701A7.9EDD99F@computer-arts.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0209290711250.9987-100000@pecos.madboa.com>

On Sun, 29 Sep 2002, Mike Witt wrote:

> Can someone tell me how to find out about mailman. It appears to be
> running on my system (/var/log/mailman is full of empty "error" file)
> and unless I need it for some reason I'd like to turn it off.

Here are the files that might contain Mailman-related stuff:

* /etc/aliases or its moral equivalent on your system
* root's crontab or, perhaps, in one of the /etc/cron.*/ directories
* Apache's httpd.conf

Once you're rid of Mailman stuff in those places, then you can safely 
remove the Mailman package from your system.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

Noisy drives are usually the sign that a bearing is going bad.  It is a 
sign that you should probably replace it, else you will be haunted by the 
screams of the drive until its impending death.

The last drive I bought was made on Sept 7th, 2002.  I think it is still 
in warrenty.  (It is printed on the drive label with Western Digital 
drives.)

Not always.

What file system is on the root partition?  Ext3 or some other 
non-ext2 partition?  May be a problem with the initrd code not loading in.

I get that message when I have a kernel that cannot figure out the root 
filesystem.  (Compiling the kernel so that critical filesystem code needed 
to mount the root partition is a module is insane.  I have complained to 
Mandrake before about that.  Did no good.)
