From michaelj at golgi.net  Sun Sep 29 12:58:20 2002
From: michaelj at golgi.net (michaelj at golgi.net)
Date: Sun, 29 Sep 2002 12:58:20 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Linux Firewall with Cisco Router
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0209291244070.18317-100000@localhost.localdomain>

Hello-

Well I figured it was time to lock down my network with a Linux firewall
instead of the minimal firewall provided in my Cisco router.

I have been running my home network with a Cisco 678 modem/router (?) 
hooked up to a Linksys 5 port switch. (DSL with Qwest)

I was recently given an old box so I downloaded a copy of Coyote Linux and
I now have the box running Coyote Linux off of the floppy.

I plugged the Cisco 678 with a crossover cable into one NIC on my box, I 
then took a regular cable and ran it from the second NIC to the switch.

The Cisco 678 showed a LAN link and activity, so I think that is all
working pretty well. The switch shows a link but neither of the other two
lights light up they are called '100' and 'Full/Col'.

The Cisco 678 is 10.0.0.1
The internet NIC on the Linux box is 10.0.0.2
What should the NIC going to the switch be?

The Cisco 678 has DHCP running, the Linux box does not. Do I need to 
swap this around so that the Cisco 678 is static and the Linux box is 
running DHCP?

Would a good trouble shooting activity be to get the LAN working without 
the Cisco 678 even in the picture?


Thanks in advanced for your help-
Michael




From aschlemm at attbi.com  Sun Sep 29 12:52:32 2002
From: aschlemm at attbi.com (Anthony Schlemmer)
Date: Sun, 29 Sep 2002 12:52:32 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Cleaning up cron.weekly/makewhatis.cron
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0209291202040.27859-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0209291202040.27859-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <200209291252.32993.aschlemm@attbi.com>

I've seen people reporting this problem before and it may have something 
to do with existing database caches being out of date, of the wrong 
version, or corrupt.

You might try running:

"mandb --create"

This will cause all databases to be recreated from scratch. 

Tony

From aarghj at yahoo.com  Sun Sep 29 14:04:19 2002
From: aarghj at yahoo.com (john morgali)
Date: Sun, 29 Sep 2002 14:04:19 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Linux Firewall with Cisco Router
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0209291244070.18317-100000@localhost.localdomain>
Message-ID: <20020929210419.29532.qmail@web40805.mail.yahoo.com>

first, the other two lights light up they are called
'100' and 'Full/Col' means that you are not running on
100base tx on that nic, which is normal because the
cisco 678 only has a 10baset ethernet port on it. 
after all, you arent going to see dsl service above
10mb/s anyway, right?

second, the cisco needs to be configured for dhcp, as
it gets its ip dynamically from the isp.  it also
gives an ip dynamically to the cpe(customer premise
equipment).  therefore, both the cisco and the
firewall need to be configured to recieve their ip's
dynamically.  the firewall would have the wan nic
configured this way.  

third, I would personally get the internal network
working first, using static ip addressing.  you can
set this up without worrying about the wan nic and its
address, as they are effectively independant in this
situation.  

hope this helps, and I would welcome any feedback to
my advise from other pluggers!

John

This thread got me curious.  Like you, I could find no reference to 
"mandb" on my rh box.  So..  I got to looking.

The man rpm lists two cron entries.

/etc/cron.daily/makewhatis.cron
/etc/cron.weekly/makewhatis.cron


The only difference I can see is the:

	daily does  "makewhatis -u -w"
and
	weekly does "makewhatis -w"

Supplying a bogus arguement to makewhatis results in:

Usage: makewhatis [-u] [-v] [-w] [manpath] [-c [catpath]]
       This will build the whatis database for the man pages
       found in manpath and the cat pages found in catpath.
       -u: update database with new pages
       -v: verbose
       -w: use manpath obtained from `man --path`
       [manpath]: man directories (default: /usr/share/man:/usr/man)
       [catpath]: cat directories (default: the first existing
           directory in 
/var/cache/man:/usr/share/man/preformat:/usr/man/preformat:/usr/share/man:/usr/man)


So the weekly run runs makewhatis but doesn't update it.  ???


makewhatis is a bourne shell script.  As far as I can determine, the 
makewhatis database is found at /var/cache/man/whatis.


I wonder if running a "makewhatis -u -w -v" would clear this?

alan wrote:

>On Sun, 29 Sep 2002, Russ Johnson wrote:
>
>  
>
>>James wrote:
>>
>>    
>>
>>>I am trying to install the latest Mandrake 9.0 onto a hard drive that I
>>>have successfully installed 8.2 on, but I am getting this error when I
>>>boot from the 9.0 CD:
>>>
>>>kernel panic: VFS: Unable to mount root fs on 01:03
>>>
>>>      
>>>
>>I had a devil of a time getting a good disk 1 burned. I believe I now 
>>have a good disk, it just took several tries.
>>
>>Yes, I *DID* check the md5sum, and it checked out each time.
>>
>>Although, I did get a different error than you, it still points to a bad 
>>burn.
>>    
>>
>
>Not always.
>
>What file system is on the root partition?  Ext3 or some other 
>non-ext2 partition?  May be a problem with the initrd code not loading in.
>
>I get that message when I have a kernel that cannot figure out the root 
>filesystem.  (Compiling the kernel so that critical filesystem code needed 
>to mount the root partition is a module is insane.  I have complained to 
>Mandrake before about that.  Did no good.)
>  
>
I wouldn't think the existing partitions on the hard drive would matter 
at that point, simply because James is trying to boot from the install 
CD and failing to even get the existing system from the CD to start. 
Wouldn't matter what was on the hard drive, or even if it was formatted, 
because there's a whole system on the CD.

It would be different if James were trying to boot from the CD and 
repair an existing system. For that, you do need to be able to mount the 
root partition off the hard drive. For a simple installation, the 
existing contents of the hard drive are irrelevant.

From todd.sarratt at attbi.com  Sun Sep 29 16:58:13 2002
From: todd.sarratt at attbi.com (todd.sarratt)
Date: Sun, 29 Sep 2002 16:58:13 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Linux Firewall with Cisco Router
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0209291244070.18317-100000@localhost.localdomain>
Message-ID: <006d01c26814$1279c500$1600a8c0@vncvr1.wa.home.com>

If you have another way to do it I would remove the 678 router.  I know
historically they're easy to hack / DoS and there's no real need to have
another layer 3 device in front of your firewall.

That said, the 10.0.0.1 network doesn't have to exist anywhere else in your
LAN other than where you have it.  The back side of your Coyote firewall can
point to an internal LAN address of 192.168.0.0 / 24 or whatever.  That's
the beauty of routers : they connect different networks.  In fact, if you
have the front NIC of the coyote box set up for 10.0.0.2 / 24 and the back
side set for 10.0.0.3 / 24, it won't work.  You've assigned two addresses in
the SAME NETWORK to two devices on DIFFERENT physical networks.

Also, you want to be sure that you aren't running NAT on both boxes.  That
would be bad.

I have an older 675 cisco DSL modem which was connected to my linux firewall.

The cisco router needs to be in bridging mode so that all it does is provide 
the uplink to the Central Office (CO).  Then you firewall needs the IP 
address that was given you or, if you are on dhcp, it needs that NIC 
configured to get the IP address.  Follow the instructions as if the firewall 
was the Cisco Router.  You will need to configure the router in bridging 
mode.  The 675 comes with the bridging mode default.  Check you manual on how 
to set up the router.  

Then you need to set up a DHCP daemon on your firewall to dole out the IP for 
your lan on your inside NIC.  This may require editing the startup scripts to 
dole out address from a certain NIC.  You may have to add eth1 to the startup 
script in the appropriate place.  That is, if your LAN NIC is eth1 and you 
WAN NIC is eth0.

The point is set you Cisco to bridging mode.
Set your WAN NIC to the IP configuration your ISP has given you.
Set you LAN NIC up to serve IP address and as you gateway to the internet.

Good Luck.

-- 
Ken Stephens
CAD2CAM.COM
CADtoCAM.COM

  No, I don't. But, the vmware web site has installation directions for all
permutations of host and guest OS. I had to actually read them tracking down
the bugs in my upgrade from 2.0.4 -> 3.1 -> 3.2. Turned out that the problem
was where Red Hat moved the smb.conf (and related files) between RH 6.2 and
7.3. But, the vmware doc exists.

  What to do? Read the doc, then check their newsgroups (they run their own
server). If you bought a copy from them you get 30 days of installation
support by filing in a form on their web site.

  Good people. Expensive software (relatively speaking), but very good
people.

From russj at dimstar.net  Mon Sep 30 01:45:21 2002
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: Mon, 30 Sep 2002 01:45:21 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] VMWare
References: <000801c2681b$5611ad80$02a8a8c0@Jim>
Message-ID: <3D980F21.8050805@dimstar.net>

Jim Webb wrote:

>Does anybody run VMWare with windows as host and linux as guest?  I'm not
>sure about the instructions for installing that VMWare provides.  My disc is
>eide, but it is calling the virtual disc sda and not hda.  It wants to use
>GRUB, LILO, or no boot loader.  Then it wants to install the boot loader on
>MBR (/dev/sda) or first sector of boot partition (/dev/sda1).
>
>What do I do?  Do I continue onwards?
>
The virtual hard drive (inside VMWare) is a SCSI disk as far as the OS 
is concerned, and has no relationship whatsoever to the actual hardware 
in your system.

Install a boot loader. You can install it to the MBR or the first sector 
(boot sector) of the partition. In your case, I can't think of any valid 
reasons to not install it in the MBR of the virtual disk. (/dev/sda).

From michaelj at golgi.net  Sun Sep 29 20:13:49 2002

Subject: [PLUG] Linux Firewall with Cisco Router
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0209292002040.20029-100000@localhost.localdomain>

Thanks!

Your info was just what I needed to understand this thing in my head. The 
problem was that I told the Linux firewall that it was going to be 
10.0.0.1, which is the IP that the Cisco router already had. So I had to 
tell the Linux firewall to use 192.168.0.1, which did not conflict with 
the Cisco Router do it worked just fine. I have dhcp running on both the 
Cisco router and Linux firewall.

>first, the other two lights light up they are called
>'100' and 'Full/Col' means that you are not running on
>100base tx on that nic, which is normal because the
>cisco 678 only has a 10baset ethernet port on it.
>after all, you arent going to see dsl service above
>10mb/s anyway, right?

>second, the cisco needs to be configured for dhcp, as
>it gets its ip dynamically from the isp.  it also
>gives an ip dynamically to the cpe(customer premise
>equipment).  therefore, both the cisco and the
>firewall need to be configured to recieve their ip's
>dynamically.  the firewall would have the wan nic
>configured this way.

>third, I would personally get the internal network
>working first, using static ip addressing.  you can
>set this up without worrying about the wan nic and its
>address, as they are effectively independant in this
>situation.

>hope this helps, and I would welcome any feedback to
>my advise from other pluggers!

>John





From dealy at deatech.com  Sun Sep 29 20:09:01 2002
From: dealy at deatech.com (Shannon C. Dealy)
Date: Sun, 29 Sep 2002 20:09:01 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] VMWare
In-Reply-To: <000501c26828$5171fac0$02a8a8c0@Jim>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0209292000570.25721-100000@critter.deatech.com>

On Sun, 29 Sep 2002, Jim Webb wrote:

> Russ,
>
> When I looked for my video card, it didn't show up.  I have an xtasy which
> uses nvidia geforce 2 ti.  I installed an nvidia geforce 2 generic since
> there wasn't a geforce2 ti.
>
> I'm a little confused by the virtual nature here.  I also chose not to have
> a firewall setup.  I'm basically flying by the seat of my pants here.
[snip]

You don't understand the nature of a virtual machine, NONE of the real
hardware on your computer has anything to do with the hardware in your
virtual machine, you need to think of each VMware virtual machine as
though it is a completely different piece of physical hardware from the
host computer.  A virtual machine has it's own virtual devices which
typically (but not always) behave as though they are one particular
brand/model of real hardware, regardless of what your host computer
uses.  If you look at the VMware documentation, you will find a
description of the hardware that the virtual machine presents to the guest
operating system.  For the SCSI, IDE, and ethernet adapters, they are
standard devices (though I don't remember which ones), for the virtual
display adapter, VMware has done their own implementation and provide
drivers as part of the VMware tools installation once your guest operating
system is up and running.

I see from their site that this is what the virtual system appears as:

Virtual Machine Specifications

Each virtual machine created with VMware Workstation 3.2 provides a platform
that includes the following devices that your guest operating system can
see.


Processor

Same processor as that on host computer
Single processor per virtual machine on symmetric multiprocessor systems

Chip Set

Intel 440BX-based motherboard with NS338 SIO chip

BIOS

PhoenixBIOS 4.0 Release 6

Memory

Up to 1GB, depending on host memory
Maximum of 1GB total available for all virtual machines

Graphics

VGA and SVGA support

IDE Drives

Up to four devices - disks, CD-ROM or DVD-ROM (DVD drives can be used to
read data DVD-ROM discs; DVD video is not supported)
Hard disks can be virtual disks or physical disks
IDE virtual disks up to 128GB
CD-ROM can be a physical device or an ISO image file

SCSI Devices

Up to seven devices
SCSI virtual disks up to 256GB
Hard disks can be virtual disks or physical disks
Generic SCSI support allows devices to be used without need for drivers in
the host OS
Works with scanners, CD-ROM, DVD-ROM, tape drives and other SCSI devices

Mylex? (BusLogic) BT-958 compatible host bus adapter (requires add-on driver
from VMware for Windows XP and Windows .NET Server)

Floppy Drives

Up to two 1.44MB floppy devices
Physical drives or floppy image files

Serial (COM) Ports

Up to four serial (COM) ports
Output to serial ports, Windows or Linux files, or named pipes

Parallel (LPT) Ports

Up to two bidirectional parallel (LPT) ports
Output to parallel ports or host operating system files

USB ports

Two-port USB 1.1 controller
Supports devices including USB printers, scanners, PDAs, hard disk drives,
memory card readers and still digital cameras

Keyboard

104-key Windows 95/98 enhanced

Mouse and Drawing Tablets

PS/2 mouse
Serial tablets supported

Ethernet Card

Up to three virtual Ethernet cards
AMD PCnet-PCI II compatible

Sound

Sound output and input
Creative Labs Sound Blaster? 16, PCM sound compatible (MIDI sound, game
controllers and joysticks not supported.)

Virtual Networking and File Sharing

Nine virtual Ethernet switches (three reserved for bridged, host-only and
NAT networking)
Virtual Ethernet support includes TCP/IP, NetBEUI, Microsoft Networking,
Samba, Novell? NetWare? and Network File System
Built-in NAT supports client software using TCP/IP, FTP, DNS, HTTP and
Telnet

  Since Albany no longer has its annual Timber Festival I cannot learn more
about log rotating there so I'm asking for help right here. I'm missing
something in understanding how the rotation of logs is controlled, and I'd
like to fill in this blank in my knowledge.

  In /etc/logrotate.d/maillog I have:

/var/log/maillog {
    daily
    rotate 4
    copytruncate
    compress
    size=+1024k
    notifempty
    missingok
    postrotate
        /usr/bin/killall -HUP syslogd
    endscript
}

because I want to watch the mail on a day-to-day basis rather than over a
longer period of time. I _thought_ that putting 'daily' in the log would
cause the log to be rotated daily and deleted after the 4th day (line 2).

  In /etc/cron.daily is the logrotate script:

#!/bin/sh

/usr/sbin/logrotate /etc/logrotate.conf

and, in /etc/logrotate.conf I see global variables, including:

# rotate log files weekly
weekly

# RPM packages drop log rotation information into this directory
include /etc/logrotate.d

  My understanding is that the inclusion of logrotate.d, with the 'daily'
command in maillog overrides the global rotation command of 'weekly' in the
.conf file. In any case, /var/log/maillog is not rotated even weekly, never
mind daily.

  If cron.daily calls logrotate and that reads logrotate.conf, is the daily
script ignoring everything in logrotate.d except for once per week? I seem
to be in an infinite loop here and am not sure where I went wrong, despite
reading the man pages several time.

TIA,

Rich

From heinlein at attbi.com  Mon Sep 30 08:40:51 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Mon, 30 Sep 2002 08:40:51 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] compile OPT flags
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0209300753550.32240-100000@skua.ahapala.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0209300831580.9443-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Mon, 30 Sep 2002, Keith Nasman wrote:

> I am delving into RPM building and in there you can specify the
> optflags for building optimally under different processors. Ex:
> 
> optflags: i386 -O2 -m486 -fno-strength-reduce
> optflags: sparc -O2
> 
> Would someone be so kind as to point me to some docs on explaining
> these?  At this point, I'd settle for some optflags I can put in my
> .rpmrc to investigate later. :-)

The optflags macro is read on a per-platform basis. Rather than trying 
to have a single ~/.rpmrc that works on all your platforms, you might 
consider installing a platform-specific /etc/rpm/macros on each build 
host. On you sparc, for instance, your /etc/rpm/macros could be

%optflags  -O3 -mcpu=v9

(Of course, if your host isn't running an Ultra, you'll want to change 
v9 to v8 or something more appropriate.)

I'm not sure that helps. Does it?

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

From John at JohnTelford.com  Mon Sep 30 08:58:01 2002
From: John at JohnTelford.com (John Telford)
Date: Mon, 30 Sep 2002 08:58:01 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] VMWare
In-Reply-To: <000801c2681b$5611ad80$02a8a8c0@Jim>
References: <000801c2681b$5611ad80$02a8a8c0@Jim>
Message-ID: <20020930155801.GA12832@lnx2.labnet>

VMware is great!  One project I'm using it for is testing the zebra
routing protocol suite running 4 virtual Linux routers connected
together with 4 virtual network switches.

The virtual routers are built using the bls (bls.sf.net) Linux
distribution.  The tomsrtbt floppy is used to initially boot a virtual
Linux machine and load bls.

Be aware that a tomsrtbt floppy fails to boot a virtual Linux machine
when the host is Windows.  It boots a virtual Linux machine when the
host is Linux and the virtual floppy disk is set to /dev/fd0u1722.

...John

On Mon, 30 Sep 2002, Kris wrote:

[snip]

The few times I've seen something like this, it wasn't X or the window
manager, but rather some process that was sending alot of display
modification/update requests (in one case a program made the mouse pointer
look like it was on a caffine high, it would just sit there vibrating
:-)  It might not be elegant, but the simplest approach I have found for
this type of problem was to just start "top" in a window, exit out of
everthing I had running, one program at a time and check to see if the
problem went away after exiting each program.  If after this was done it
still had problems, I would start killing anything else that was running
which might have access to the X environment, such as window manager
applets (these are often a source of problems), until the problem went
away, or there was nothing left (so far I have never gotten to the point
that only X was left and the problem was still happening).

From russj at dimstar.net  Mon Sep 30 14:23:07 2002
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: Mon, 30 Sep 2002 14:23:07 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] 2.4.19 kernel + RAID 0/RAID 1/RAID 0+1
References: <GGEILBHDNBMGHFFFEIGOCEGELGAA.mikel@quantecllc.com>
Message-ID: <3D98C0BB.2070708@dimstar.net>

Michael Luevane wrote:

>Hello, pluggers.
>
>I've searched the archives for information on getting 2.4.19 to work with
>RAID, specifically the Promise TX2000 PCI RAID controller card.
>
>I've found quite a bit of information on it, but I'm guessing that I'm
>missing a step.
>
>The kernel has RAID support compiled in (not a module) and I've seen the
>four drives recognized as hde-hdh.
>I've installed the raidtools RPM from Mandrake (that's the distro I'm
>using).
>I've put the append= line into lilo and rerun lilo.
>
>I've also got the Linux ATA RAID HOW-TO and a couple of others, but they
>don't seem to help.
>
>Now, I'm stuck.
>I *think* that I need to mkfs.ext3 on the disks and then use mktab to mount
>them, but I'm not sure. I'm not a big Linux guru type, so I'm kinda iffy.
>
>Anyone else manage to get the Promise RAID card, 2.4.19, and the linux-raid
>in general to work?
>
>I'd appreciate pointers, sites, etc.
>

It sounds to me like you may be confusing hardware RAID with software RAID.

You have a RAID controller card. That's hardware RAID. It doesn't 
require any RAID stuff in the kernel to work, as the RAID array is 
defined in hardware. You only need the module for your controller card 
either as a module or compiled in. Once the RAID is defined in hardware, 
the software (linux kernel in this case) sees the RAID as a single device.

The RAID module is for making a RAID array out of drives on a standard 
EIDE/ATA controller. That's what software RAID is. The kernel would see 
the four drives as individual devices, and then make them a RAID device 
at the software level.

-- 
--
Russ Johnson
Dimension 7/Stargate Online
http://www.dimstar.net

From mikeraz at patch.com  Mon Sep 30 14:28:23 2002
From: mikeraz at patch.com (mikeraz at patch.com)
Date: Mon, 30 Sep 2002 14:28:23 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] 2.4.19 kernel + RAID 0/RAID 1/RAID 0+1
In-Reply-To: <GGEILBHDNBMGHFFFEIGOCEGELGAA.mikel@quantecllc.com>; from mikel@quantecllc.com on Mon, Sep 30, 2002 at 02:01:12PM -0700
References: <GGEILBHDNBMGHFFFEIGOCEGELGAA.mikel@quantecllc.com>
Message-ID: <20020930142823.E13000@patch.com>


On Mon, Sep 30, 2002 at 02:01:12PM -0700, Michael Luevane typed:
> Hello, pluggers.
> 
> I've searched the archives for information on getting 2.4.19 to work with
> RAID, specifically the Promise TX2000 PCI RAID controller card.

This reply came from a co-worker who implemented Promise
RAID a couple of weeks ago.

  Different model controller (mine are FastTrak100 TX2), but likely the same
  issue - they don't make source available, and they have not upgraded
  binaries above the initial kernel (2.4.18-3) shipping with RH 7.3.
  
  These are hardware RAID controllers, so kernel support is not really
  necessary. Linux sees the array/mirror as a single SCSI disk. For some
  versions/models (mine being one) some additional parameters need to be
  provided to the kernel at boot to make it work as advertised.

so you'll need to download the Promise driver from their web site and 
get the 2.4.18-3 kernel sources.

From creelan at engr.orst.edu  Mon Sep 30 16:00:51 2002
From: creelan at engr.orst.edu (Tyler F. Creelan)
Date: Mon, 30 Sep 2002 16:00:51 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] spamassassin tweaks
In-Reply-To: <20020930211831.GA19177@subtend.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0209301554550.8754-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>

> Enter idiotic C exec's (specifically CEO).  Has a list of words that he
> doesn't event want to hit users INBOX.  Claims some legal liability
> (probably bullshit).

FYI, from the spamassassin FAQ:

Stuff To Note: Legal Issues
Note that there may be legal issues with site-wide spam filtering. For
example, in the UK, it is apparently illegal to hold emails for
examination for longer than 2 days. Also, the MailScanner info page
reckons that under section 3(3) of the Regulation of Investigatory Powers
Act, care must be taken to ensure that no-one other than the sender and
intended recipient of any message can read any part of that message.

A possible way to route around this, is by simply using SpamAssassin in
it's default mode, so that it simply tags the mails with their estimated
status, instead of full mail filtering where you redirect or delete mail
without the user's intervention. This way, the user still has final choice
in what to do; and they can also rest assured that nobody on your staff
has been "reading their mail". However, take this advice with a grain of
salt -- I am not a lawyer, so if you're worried, ask one.

http://spamassassin.sourceforge.net/faq.html

From raanders at acm.org  Mon Sep 30 16:06:19 2002
From: raanders at acm.org (Roderick A. Anderson)
Date: Mon, 30 Sep 2002 16:06:19 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Log rolling
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0209301437010.31744-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0209301601450.5004-100000@main.cyber-office.net>

On Mon, 30 Sep 2002, Rich Shepard wrote:

> [root at salmo /etc/postfix]# /usr/sbin/logrotate -d /etc/logrotate.conf 
> reading config file /etc/logrotate.conf
[snip]
> reading config info for /var/log/maillog 
> reading config file mgetty

[snip]

> error: syslog:1 duplicate log entry for /var/log/maillog

You've probably got an entry to rotate maillog in the syslog file.  The 
default is to include maillog in the syslog rotation.

It is again, probably, a multi file rule/specification like this.

--- /etc/logrotate.d/syslog ---

/var/log/messages /var/log/secure /var/log/maillog /var/log/spooler /var/log/boot.log /var/log/cron {
    sharedscripts
    postrotate
        /bin/kill -HUP `cat /var/run/syslogd.pid 2> /dev/null` 2> /dev/null || t
rue
    endscript
}


Rod

References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0209271518500.9177-100000@appl-ecosys.com> <1033253151.1223.26.camel@laptop> <3D98725F.2C3E9404@gisnet.com>
Message-ID: <200209302054.14125.kens@cad2cam.com>

On Monday 30 September 2002 08:48 am, Bill Thoen wrote:
> Thanks for all the help, folks! I did get Linux loaded into the
> 2nd partition of my 2nd disk, but dual-booting won't work with
> this set-up. I had to use fdisk set up swap and native Linux
> partitions (Disk Druid would allow it) and the RedHat 7.1 install
> process took a couple of tries (it locked up just prior to
> actually loading files.)
>
> The dual boot did not work I think because I couldn't get LILO to
> write a proper boot record into the Linux partition (which starts
> at the 21st GB of that 40GB disk.) It kept giving me a warning
> that the boot area was not on the first disk, but otherwise
> seemed to work. However, when I tried to copy the boot record
> into a file with dd, the resulting file would not boot Linux when
> used with Win2K's boot loader.
>
> Anyway I can boot Linux from a floppy when I need it, so at least
> my first objective (to load Linux without hosing Windows2000) has
> been achieved. Someday when I'm smarter I'll tackle the dual-boot
> problem again. Setting up a dual boot machine seems very simple
> in theory, but in practice there's a lot of variables among the
> infinite number of configurations and one needs some genreal
> experience to recognize problems.
The next step is to dd if=<linux boot partition> of=bootsect.lnx bs=512 
count=1.

This gives you your boot sector to load into windows 2000.  Put this file on a 
dos floppy.

Boot <shudder>Windows</shudder> and copy this file to C:/.  The edit boot.ini.  
It is normally read-only so you may have to play with permissions and add the 
following line to the bottom of the file:  C:/bootsect.lnx="Linux"

The next time you boot windows you will have a choice of 
<shudder>Windows</shudder> or <hooray>Linux</hooray>

CADtoCAM.COM



From kens at cad2cam.com  Mon Sep 30 21:05:42 2002
From: kens at cad2cam.com (Kenneth G. Stephens)

Subject: [PLUG] 2.4.19 kernel + RAID 0/RAID 1/RAID 0+1
In-Reply-To: <20020930142823.E13000@patch.com>
References: <GGEILBHDNBMGHFFFEIGOCEGELGAA.mikel@quantecllc.com> <20020930142823.E13000@patch.com>
Message-ID: <200209302105.42056.kens@cad2cam.com>

On Monday 30 September 2002 02:28 pm, mikeraz at patch.com wrote:
> On Mon, Sep 30, 2002 at 02:01:12PM -0700, Michael Luevane typed:
> > Hello, pluggers.
> >
> > I've searched the archives for information on getting 2.4.19 to work with
> > RAID, specifically the Promise TX2000 PCI RAID controller card.
>
> This reply came from a co-worker who implemented Promise
> RAID a couple of weeks ago.
>
>   Different model controller (mine are FastTrak100 TX2), but likely the
> same issue - they don't make source available, and they have not upgraded
> binaries above the initial kernel (2.4.18-3) shipping with RH 7.3.
>
>   These are hardware RAID controllers, so kernel support is not really
>   necessary. Linux sees the array/mirror as a single SCSI disk. For some
>   versions/models (mine being one) some additional parameters need to be
>   provided to the kernel at boot to make it work as advertised.
>
> so you'll need to download the Promise driver from their web site and
> get the 2.4.18-3 kernel sources.

The RAID controller needs to be supported by the kernel like any SCSI 
controller needs its corresponding driver.  The RAID is not strictly 
controlled by the kernel, but the RAID card is.

A search by Google showed this page: 
http://promise.com/support/other2_eng.asp?mode=linux_download&product_id=8

HTH
-- 
Ken Stephens
CAD2CAM.COM
CADtoCAM.COM

just say no ;-)

From zot at whiteknighthackers.com  Fri Sep 20 14:05:41 2002
From: zot at whiteknighthackers.com (Zot O'Connor)
Date: 20 Sep 2002 14:05:41 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Fighting ORDB for 3 days now.....
Message-ID: <1032555940.15627.39.camel@kat.zotnet.com>

I have been fighting ORDB for 3 days straight.  I do not think I have a
confusing setup, but I am lost.

I have a mail server.

It is the local STMP outbound server for a few class C's.
It is the main server inbound for several domains.

I cannot seem to block attacks in the style of:

"marvin at marvin.ordb.org@XXX.ISPREVERSEDNS.com"@MAIL.MYDOMAIN.com
marvin at marvin.ordb.org@[IP.FOR.SERVER.XXX]

I have tried a number of things and now I am likely confused to all
hell.

I am running Mandrake 7.2, postfix-1.1.11-7.mdk7x (built on system)
Postfix has been upgraded, so maybe the main.cf is out of date

It seems like permit_networks is sending an OK, and therefore bypassing
the rest of smtpd_recipient_restrictions.  I have tried moving it
around, but it either blocks me send mail from mynetworks, or allows the
spam tricks on through...

Also do I need check_relay_domains, since I do to relay for anyone (I
accept, process and forward all local domains).


I used to say sendmail was more tricky than postfix, but after the last
three days of painstaking research and testing, I am no longer the sure.

Any help would be appreciated.  Please keep in mind the current setup
below for _restrictions has been changed over 100 times, so repeats and
order oddities are to be expected.

I have read in detail 

http://www.mengwong.com/misc/postfix-uce-guide.txt
http://www.postfix.org/uce.html

and many many other sites.



queue_directory = /var/spool/postfix
command_directory = /usr/sbin
daemon_directory = /usr//lib/postfix
mail_owner = postfix
default_privs = nobody
myhostname = MAILSERVER.DOMAIN.com
mydomain=MYDOMAIN.com
mydestination=$myhostname, localhost.$mydomain, $mydomain,
/etc/postfix/sendmailvirtual_maps = hash:/etc/postfix/virtual
alias_maps = hash:/home/mailman/aliases, hash:/etc/postfix/aliases
mail_spool_directory = /var/spool/mail
mailbox_command = /usr/bin/procmail -a $DOMAIN -d $LOGNAME
mynetworks = 216.XXX.XXX.XXX/24, 216.XXX.XXX.XXX/32, 216.XXX.XXX.XXX/32,
127.0.0swap_bangpath = no
smtpd_delay_reject = no
allow_percent_hack = no
allow_untrusted_routing = no
smtpd_recipient_restrictions = check_recipient_access
hash:/etc/postfix/access.tsmtpd_sender_restrictions =
check_sender_access regexp:/etc/postfix/sender_regex     
#check_relay_domains
smtpd_banner = $myhostname ESMTP $mail_name ($mail_version)
(Linux-Mandrake)
local_destination_concurrency_limit = 2
default_destination_concurrency_limit = 10
debug_peer_level = 2
debugger_command =
     PATH=/usr/bin:/usr/X11R6/bin
     xxgdb $daemon_directory/$process_name $process_id & sleep 5
readme_directory = /etc/postfix/README_FILES
sample_directory = /etc/postfix/samples
sendmail_path = /usr/sbin/sendmail
setgid_group = postdrop
manpage_directory = /usr/share/man
newaliases_path = /usr/bin/newaliases
mailq_path = /usr/bin/mailq

/etc/postfix/access:
